learn_by_undoing.description: Kids learn so much by taking things apart. Consumer Electronics are especially valuable learning tools as they unpack some big questions around power, intelligence, heat management, and much more.
learn_by_undoing.creator: 9d77fe8626eb781b87995ac85ba333cc

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Love this idea! I think many schools and teachers don't have the resources they need for turning theory into practice when it comes to mechanics, computation, so on and so forth. I can really picture a class where children/teenagers put pieces together to build an eletronic device. Like a puzzle! It's something our parents used to have and we don't. I don't know how to fix anything at home. But my father does. Maybe it's because he's already popped a bunch of devices open when he was a child.

I too think this is a great idea and agree that too little emphasis is placed on discovery. It is still possible to buy breadboarding kits (at least here in Australia), and things like crystal radios. Certainly compared to the latest video or computer games they may not seem very exciting but just occasionally they can spark a child's imagination.I guess there must be sufficient 'inventive' students to source the growing need for new devices based on new technologies and materials. Most of us rarely give this a thought, partly because branding is so strong. We tend to think of new devices as being the products of organisations, rather than the fact that a lot of human ingenuity has gone into them. It's a bit like 'milk' - it comes from a carton or bottle, or maybe a factory - but from an animal???Although taking things apart won't lead to responsible disposal per se, it can lead to an understanding that items can:1) sometimes be repaired;2) certainly be dismantled; and3) have components and materials re-used and recycled.Teachers don't need to know the answers either, if they are prepared to explore and learn with the children - and this can be extremely valuable for all.
Thanks Paul and Mariana, I can already imagine some interesting ideas to flesh out in the concepting phase. Would love to think more about how disassembly might lead to responsible disposal.

Hi RobertGlad to contribute and looking forward to collaboration.I also have some preliminary ideas - and a heap of ways to integrate concepts emerging from this and other inspirations.In particular I would like to see teachers challenged to take their classes on a joint exploratory journey.In Australia this would largely have to be primary school where teachers have a class for the whole range of subjects.

This seems to be a key for understanding. I like the idea. Maybe should create something like a authorized "deconstructivist" school, where you can learn do unravel the mystery of nowadays black boxes. Nice one!

Uoo I love this idea! We learn so much when having fun and playing around with electronics because I think the focus of it's complexity is driven away with emphasis of fun + discovery! This also fosters a lot of collaboration and insights between kids.This workshop sounds lovely, thanks Robert!

limited_edition_products_to_encourage_ow.description: Special limited edition e-devices with special features will incentivize owners to keep and maintain the products for a longer period of time rather than trashing an item in favor of the latest and greatest gadget.
limited_edition_products_to_encourage_ow.creator: 9e7c836b8a00e4f83d6e1d8531aecb41

comments.text: Graham and Robert I definitely agree with the track this is taking.  Some consumers really like showing off their latest gadgets and having the coolest things or newest "fashions", and if the mindset of having the newest thing can be changed more to loving what you have and associating a sentimental value to it then consumers may try to fix their electronics instead of trash them.  Graham this is definitely on the right track.  If we could get people to be sentimental with their products then the consumption and the waste that comes form it could be slowed down.

Thanks for your comments Greg. Sentimentality is the best way of describing what I was going for (though admittedly limited edition items can be tchotchkes or they can become sentimental things). I drew from the inspiration phase the idea of watches or old photo cameras as "tech" products that can carry sentimental value. I think the ideal behind this concept is to give value to a tech product in the same way one might value a watch that has been passed down among generations. An item gains sentimental value when it gains a story. Perhaps "limited edition" is not the ideal way of giving a smartphone or a laptop a story, but this is an idea that can be built upon. Then again, you could imagine a limited edition smartphone for musicians (like example 3 above) and the musician keeping the phone for some time because they, say, had recorded their first album on it. I guess we do not really have that type of connection with smartphones or laptops or other hardware but it must be possible to generate. Right now the message is upgrade, upgrade, upgrade.
Great point about cameras and watches. A well made, beautiful camera is not something to part with. Bringing that kind of sentimental attachment to other products would be great.

Graham, I like the thinking. You're attempting to twist the "fashion" of the electronics industry to inspire people to hold onto devices rather than chuck them. Currently companies use people's fashion sense as part of planned obsolescence so I like this way of using it for good!Another challenge to be faced, though, is the free market. Just because one company decided to only provided limited additions, does not prevent a competitor from luring those same customers away on a similar short time scale that we see today. To prevent customers of this limited addition model from being sucked into competitors products, the upgradability will be key (as you suggested). We have to remember that the reason companies push consumers to replace things so often is because they are profit driven. Whatever business model we create here has to be able to generate more profits than the current system or we'll bever get the giants on our side.

Hi Rob. Thanks for your ideas. A few points:- I wouldn't suggest that a company only produce lines of limited edition or special products. That was not the idea here. But the point is well taken that competition will drive companies to create even better special products, and that could just recreate the desire to always upgrade to the newest thing.- I am sure this would be a hard sell in some ways given that a lot of profit is probably generated from people who are upgrading to the newest gadgets before their old device is broken or obsolete. Then again, generating a product that can create more of a story (see my post above - think of an old watch passed on through the family) would potentially be good marketing and could also attract new sales.

I like the story based marketing. Very visual and with sentimental value. It reminds me of a Chevy commercial. They show a man at a shop with a mechanic it's not worth the money to fix it. He goes to clear out his things from the glove compartment and sees a picture of him as a boy with his dad and the ruck. The next thing you see is him handing the mechanic a blank check. (I'm not a truck person but the human element is wonderful)http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VxCpdU3qGi8here's a similar video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WAJT39OO3Qo
What would happen if Apple put out a range of dismantle-able, upgradeable Steve Jobs Memorial Edition products - would they be sought after if they were easy to upgrade?

Really fantastic concept Graham.With today's manufacturing options such personalization adds little cost to the process.It would allow for market segmentation on a national/regional basis too that could contribute to the release of several products essentially the same but differing in their 'special nature'Challenge 1 This would have some effect so it would beg the question should the design and manufacture be slanted towards greater robustness. My son has a Crumpler laptop carry case that he uses constantly so a limited edition MacBook Pro might spawn a complementary case to preserve it but still make it functional. (By accident I also have a Crumpler camera case that I bought for function without knowing it was a 'fashion' item.)Challenge 2This is true but extending the life of a product through limited edition (even through several owners) might bring us back a little towards using products to their potential. (Makes me think of how many people with Office 2010 could still be doing everything they need using Office 3.1)Challenge3If Arash's example of the 'dismantle-able' laptop and Robert's upgradeability were combined with this limited edition concept it would be possible to preserve the 'appeal' of the limited edition while adding to its functionality.Challenge 4While I agree scalability is an issue but if different 'speciality' is targeted in different market segments the total volume of product would possibly be greater.Looking forward to further discussion here and with the complementary concepts.

Thanks for your comments. On challenge 1 points, I like that the idea of ruggedness and durability is raised. This was a point in my inspiration that I posted. A rugged product (or accessories that add durability) can also generate feelings of attachment and maybe sentimentality (think of the Chevy pickup that's been running for 250,000 - a source of pride for the owner). Your points on challenge 4 are spot on and not really something that I had considered. Limited edition does not necessarily have to be high-end. However, how much does cost contribute to the period of time someone might hold on to a particular product?

Really nice idea Graham - and I like how you've outlined some potential challenges surrounding it as well (always good to see our ideas from multiple angles). I'm looking forward to seeing how this concept develops during the challenge!

comments.text: Another thought, on a somewhat different note: I'm very taken by your enthusiasm for the penguins (as proven by my last post ;), however I'm not sure if coloring them would optimally send the intended message? (It somewhat reminded me of the baby seals that Greenpeace used to spray paint, in order to protect them from fur hunters...). I mean, maybe just designing the penguins a little more cartoonishly could already do the trick.Alternatively, one could think about abandoning the idea of penguins (with a heavy heart, I know!) to maybe go for chameleons instead? Of course I totally see why you picked penguins  they are certainly considered a lot cuter and also more prominent as a symbol for the threats of climate change. So obviously there are pros and cons... Hope you don't mind my 'intervention'!Best,Hannes

Hehe - your 'intervention' is welcome and I just added you to my virtual team.While I am rather wedded to the 'penguin' idea I'm also pragmattic enough to realise that if this gets through to the realisation phase it may be greatly transformed and will end up in the most marketable form.I did originally want to use cartoon form but after half an hours effort I realised that to get the concept off the ground I had to run with a modified photo.From my perspective the really important aspects are something that can be applied to the full range of products (hairdryers to fridges, cell phones to server boxes etc.) and is recognisable and understandable by kids and adults alike. The message should champion health friendly, long-lived and fully recyclable products (not just something that ends up as garden furniture and again ultimately landfill).

Hi Paul,Once again: Great and elaborate concept! Thinking about your penguins made me realize how well the word lends itself to a quirky interpretation as an acronym: How about 'Protection of the ENvironment Graphic User INterface'? ;)
You certainly have a great eye for word associations.

Haha, thanks. I definitely enjoy playing around with words. I tend to exaggerate it sometimes, though... And it's always a little bit of a lottery when trying to do it in a foreign language of course. Quite impossible to know and feel all the possible connotations of a word then. (So feel free to ignore any of my suggestions if they just don't make any sense in English! May well happen occasionally...)

Hey Paul!  I think this is a really terrific concept!  In order to get the groundswell of support, I think some targeted advocacy efforts would help to get public support and political pressure on the EPA to take action.  Check out my concept (it's just a brief outline right now) on creating a powerful marketing/social media campaign to raise awareness and provide solutions.  I think your concept in conjunction with a strong awareness-raising campaign could be very powerful.    http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/marketing-campaign-to-raise-awareness-and-provide-solutions/

Thanks Mira - I agree a great marketing campaign is essential to building any of these concepts, I've created a link to your concept using the building-on process and will incorporate your concept in the updated remarks shortly.

Happy belated birthday Paul :)
Happy late birthday, Paul!
Thank you both - I'm glad to say Ik still don't feel my age - at least not mentally :PMust get my skates on in next few hours to do a bit of revision (as promised earlier).
wow, great concept.I really like the connection with educating the younger generations and getting them used to the labels!Have you looked at UK Defra's red green indicator for electronics?
Thanks Olof.Do you have a link for that indicator?

What a great concept, Paul. First - I really like the penguins and I would like to see them on the products I buy. What about integrating the costs of the repair in the repair-pinguine as well? Some ratio of average repair costs for replacing a typical item (like the battery in a ipod) and the costs of the new product? Maybe in this way also people who do not think about the eco-friendliness of a product as a first thing could be involved. What do you think? Im curious, how the concept will evolve.

Yes - that's great thinking Sabine.I am very open to the sorts of criteria that would be required, relying to some extent on the expertise of the EPA in developing them (as they have done for the energy labeling).
Rock on Paul! Loving the comprehensive thinking going on here  right down to the wide appeal of penguins ;^) And loving the QR-code goodness which could easily point folks to more detail.

comments.text: Really great idea Leandra! I imagine Melbourne councils are like Hobart ones with an annual clean-up routine just before Christmas and this would fit well with that. Councils could provide a link to the app/website when advertising their cleanup service. In fact the app/website could be extended a little by making 'electrical', 'electronic' and 'other' sections - making it a 'virtual flea market'.There are some issues with safety but I guess appropriate disclaimers would be included.For items like fridges and washing machines (which still strictly qualify as e-waste) our councils require doors and lids to be removed before placing out - using the app/website people could put up items 'intact' a few days early so if others are really keen they could collect early too. Here it is noticeable that the second-hand dealers roam the streets during the 'clean-up' period, which is fine - but I would prefer to see any working item I want to dispose of go 'direct' to a good home.

Thanks Paul!Some Melbourne councils have a Hard Rubbish Night but here (Elwood) people are meant to ring the council which is a good idea except that it is not well publicised. We have a lot of rental flats and the end result is a lot of stuff is left out on the street. I don't mind it so much - I've collected quite a bit over the years, but it's sad when I see a video recorder which would have probably have worked fine had someone got to it before the rain!

Yes I agree.Video recorders are considered passe with the advent of solid state but I still use one for the minimal TV coverage I need and they are actually good for live recording and audio.We need to ring the council too and receive a booking - if you fail to book by the end of October they bypass you, even if its obvious there is something to collect.

Great idea! There's a lot of room for collaboration - like you said with local governments & charities but also orgs like Freecycle. You could also use Freecycle's safety/disclaimer regulations as guidelines. I could even see this being used within campuses for people to locate things that departments don't need and want to give away for free. I really like that you've linked it with DIY repair/electronics modifying too.

Great suggestion Carol - might also stop the 'Chemistry' department from throwing away something useful to the 'Biology' department. In fact is true of many organisations (especially government) where in recent times asset purchase and disposal has been decentralised so its become somewhat left and right hand not knowing what each other is doing.
Nice one Leandra! I like the idea that this app could connect members of a local community and find new homes for second-hand items.
Thanks Ashley. I've edited the concept a little as I figure the SwapMap could be used by charities, local government and Bulk Recyclers as well.

I really like that this concept is all about keeping a tech product in a consumer's hand for a longer period of time. In my inspiration post, I asked whether consumers have an idea of the product lifespan of a laptop or a phone or another tech item. When we buy a car, for example, we expect it to run for say 15 years or 200,000 miles. I am not so sure about the lifespan of a tech product like a smartphone because we're replacing them (typically) before they are broken. This concept could help to push the idea that a smartphone is something you keep for years, decades maybe, much like we endeavor to keep our cars, trucks, and motorbikes running.However, we are trashing many tech products because they have become obsolete not because they are broken, the points raised in the inspirations for this concept. Even with upgradable devices consumers could face the issue of "planned obsolescence", especially if there is a financial incentive to get tech product owners into the store as often as possible for a potentially costly upgrade. One problem seems to be the way that new software is released in this current model of app stores and constant refining of apps. I upgrade my apps on my smartphone and tablet almost every week and it seems like each month my first-generation tablet gets slower and slower with each new upgrade (particularly upgrades to the OS). If apps keep pushing the computing limits of hardware every other week (an exaggeration I know, but not far off), we will all still need to either trash our products or upgrade every 6-12 months. An interesting question is how frequently would consumers be willing to take their phone or computer into a store for regular "tune-ups". At what point would this become a turn-off and at what point would it be cheaper to just buy a new product?

Fascinating case study Robert.I know this is nowhere near Kalundborg's ecosystem of mutually beneficial symbiotic relationships, but it's interesting to note that back in the early 1800's William Procter's candlemaking business and James Gamble's soapmaking business began by utilizing the waste fat and oil by-products from Cincinnati's large meatpacking industry.These 2 merged into a partnership that would diversify into many new kinds of cleansing solutions, expand into completely different product categories like food and healthcare (often with surprising behind-the-scenes linkages between very different types of products), and eventually become the $80+ billion consumer products giant Procter & Gamble.

Ashley, you got it right. this is B2B reuse of sorts. In its simplest form, this is about Mutualisms. Positive +, Positive + relationship where each party benefits. Kalundborg was really the first, and it happened as an emergent innovation. From my case study: 'Not long after emerging as an industrial center, Kalundborg unknowingly began the seeds of its Industrial Symbiosis. In an effort to minimize the use of the limited local ground water, a new oil refinery wanted to use surface water from the nearby Lake Tisso. The City of Kalundborg offered to build the pipeline, while the oil refinery financed the project. This initial collaboration led to more industrial partnerships, and the idea of mutually beneficial collaborations was born.'There are many more examples of these now called Eco-Parks.

comments.text: Smart and simple! I've posted a closely related concept that points at the temporal aspect, the "urgency" of the recycling or reuse process: http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/revive-old-devices-even-before-they-re-dead(Unused but functional cell phones can basically be seem as left over food that could feed hungry people but is irrationally left to go bad. The food metaphor helps to point out that time is an issue here: The more time an old cell phone spends unused in somebody's drawer, the more value it loses  technologically, economically but also and most of all ecologically: Since as an object that has already been produced anyway, its eco-balance will always be endlessly better than the one of any newly built phone whatsoever.)
I very much like the comparison between food spoilage and electronic products becoming out of date. It's an interesting concept to consider because of the image that it evokes.

Great seamless connection of the begginning and end of two product lifecycles!In its current form the idea would still require altruism from the consumer. It could be even more effective if it was combined with a financial incentive that aligned both consumers and companies. For example, send the pre-paid box in and receive  x discount on your next apple/samsung/nokia purchase.  Companies could now use this as an opportunity to build brand loyalty while consumers would save money. Both actors receive value while creating a positive externality.
I appreciate this comment. Another form of financial incentive could come in the form of a tax write-off associated with waste reduction.

Awesome idea to close the loop, Adrian! Your concept reminds me of the ink cartridge recycling programs that companies like HP popularized (http://www.hp.com/sbso/product/supplies/cartridge-recycling.html). My own experience with the program was in using the small plastic envelopes with pre-paid postage, which were included along with each new cartridge, in order to send back used cartridges. HP developed a pretty robust infrastructure to also allow for drop offs and scheduled pick-ups for more heavy-duty cartridge users. I think that there's a ton of promise in instituting a similar program among mobile phone manufacturers to allow users to return their old phones or accessories. Something that I think is really important to consider in popularizing a program like this though is how it will be messaged to users - Whereas I think you would be hard pressed to find someone who considers old printer cartridges as anything else but trash, consumers might be less willing to discard an old phone in the same way. Mobile phones are after all increasingly becoming a constant companion, alongside users literally from the moment they wake up to the moment they set their alarm and go to bed. As such, in order to increase the adoption rate of a program like this, I think it'll be essential to build a strong marketing story that helps consumers understand the value of sending in their device and the path that it might take from there - i.e. being refurbished for another user, or going to a processing plant for recycling.A.M. Harman speaks to tracking a device's life story a bit in her "Hand me down" concept (http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/hand-me-down-an-educational-campaign-with-placement-service-for-second-hand-electronics-/) Looking forward to seeing where this concept goes!!

My only concern with going down that road would be that subscription fees (as opposed to the phones themselves) account for the lion's share of the cost of owning and using a cellphone.

comments.text: Here is an example of a tremendously successful retail store in Spain (own manufactured products) which has successfully beaten the Spanish market just by designing new toys and tools for children using a more kid-conscious and parent-conscious design criteria: the smartphone named after MO1. It is mobile phone which stocked out really quickly in Barcelona, designed for children and parents. One of the learnings of the new product was that the success of such a product became in turn a tremendous brand equity building campaign for the retail store: consumers would be the ones talking to other about how cary the design process was (in this cases thinking on children and parents). I think the way to implement this concept needs to follow a similar approach: by giving it it's own identity (i.e Disassembler1) a company can build brand equity and break into a market.http://www.imaginarium.es/900014/ecommerce_1/900014

I was recently talking to a senior VP in an advertising multinational company in Barcelona,Spain, and he was telling me how scary were the figures regarding the decreasing amount of people that show care for a brand. In the FMCG market, for instance 'private brands' are increasingly gaining market share over company branded products. One of their conclusions was that companies should be finding a way to create meaningful brands to consumers. One of the waves we see today is being 'socially responsible' or being 'environmentally friendly' ... but how many companies are really doing meaningful actions in this respect? I think this concept is a truly branding opportunity for a company that truly wants to build a meaningful brand for consumers. Implementing such concept can break molds in the current digital/electronic sector, and the first successful implementation can clearly appear to be a flagship service for a truly environmentally friendly company, and can act as the grounds of a new revolution in the digital / electronic design criteria. And bringing actors together to create the new generation of devices is also a challenge that can be understood as a market barrier for new entrants: aligning providers with a new design criteria is not easy, but such difficulty also results in a difficulty for competitors to copy the proposal. We've recently seen how easily Samsung has released a new smartphone that successfully competes with the iPhone; copying a device that involves several different providers cannot be done in a short period of time. It's about heading the race in the devices and services of the future, even before regulation walks in (usually later than we would like to).

I understand the way the concept is also presented to the company and the value chain also has an impact. The way it is presented now ('Responsibility Shift') is driven by stating how we solve the challenge we have ahead, but may not be a sexy way to convince a company to go into it and can instead contribute to resistance. Saying 'Responsibility shift' and seeing the 'responsibility' falls on you does not contribute to welcoming whatever is proposed, really, but rather to asking one-self Why should I be doing this?Perhaps the concept should be rephrased to, for instance, 'From product-based business models to service-based business models with ready for dis-assembly design'. So the stress is not so much on the responsibility but on a business opportunity in line with a market need. Companies do not shift for responsibility purposes but for business performance purposes.Comments on this are welcome!

I have attempted three times now to post a response... bug perhaps?What we are talking about here is a cultural shift -- which concerns how people relate to their practices and how they are perceived. Fundamentally, in my view the key tools here would be to identify and understand what this means for people -- which includes what anxieties, aspirations and ambivalence are aroused.As a psychosocial researcher, I find it best to approach this sort of thing from the "inside out" rather than "outside in." This means engaging in a process to better understand what this 'means' - through dialogue, low-key conversations, associations, etc, so you can recognize what is latent and there. It's a different approach to presuming there may be a 'tough sell' - which sets up a sense of uphill battle. Rather, we can presume there are latent desires, energies that we can tap into. But to do this, we must have a fine-grained sense of where people are in relation to this topic.I recently engaged in a messaging/branding project concerning green electronics. The essence was about acknowledging both the not-so-great aspects of electronics and the more exciting potentials (i.e. service). This is more truthful for where we are, perhaps - a mixture of anxiety (what does this mean for business? etc), aspiration (I want to do right!) and ambivalence (hmm, things seem to be working OK as it is). So my suggestion here is to design social platforms as tools for initiating these conversations. Figure out how to ascertain where people are at around this topic and what it means/represents.

Hi Renee! Thanks for sharing your view. I totally share your view on the cultural shift and addressing the psychological issues / concerns / process that this change brings inevitably along, which requires a deep understanding on where employees and consumers psychologically stand with regards to this topic, and start working from there. Your inside-out proposal makes complete sense to me, and your projects findings are certainly interesting. Four years ago I did some research on consumers too, and we came to the conclusion that at that time the consumers did not care much for a potential 'green feature' such as 'low energy consumption PC' although they complained about how often they need to change their PCs, and the problem that an obsolete PC would cause them. And I am sure that if we repeated the research now, consumers would not stand in the same place. We do need to understand were we stand.So in this line, I cannot agree more with you that facilitating tools that allow people to:1) Be aware of where we are going to if the market does not change, for both companies and consumers. Consciousness activates consumers to new proposals; consciousness activates the market 2) Be aware of the potential change, if they have never thought about it. Some consumers may not have even thought about this ... and generally speaking absorbing a change and integrating it into a daily life demands time for people (some need more time, others less, but we all need time)3) Discuss openly on the advantages and disadvantages of the new model, concerns, issues, etc. This would allow for having on understanding better the starting point.Another interesting tool to consider to create the cultural shift is to create a consumer trend. Whether we like it or not, many people do jump on rivers and follow the stream, without really thinking much on where the stream goes, as long as there are certain people in it, they jump. An extreme example: if Barack Obama purchased such service, milions of other would. I understand we should see this as a 'multiplier' factor if we think in terms of Marketing communication campaigns terms. If Barack Obama's slogan is 'Change we believe in', then the green service would also reinforce it's campaign (similar values). As for the employees and companies my experience in the consumer electronic sector is that for the some key devices, such as computers, there has been a long-term price battle which have resulted in many manufacturers having their margins absolutely eroded, with more than one even burning money already. These manufacturers should be open and willing to differentiate in order to have their margins back by re-thinking their business model in a way or another. A new proposal to the market, such as this one, which comes with a new cost-model should be at least attractive to them. And for employees the excitement of leading a positive change can result in higher productivity. In Spain for instance, in the mobile space, operators have been using mobile device offers to capture new clients. The game has been on for years, but it now appears to be shifting, because smartphones are far too costly, and such business model are no longer feasible. This can also be a door for the new proposal to come into the space.My experience also tells me that the best way for employees to absorb a change is by making activities that involve them in creating the change ... so that by the time the change is detailed, they are have already digested it.

Yes... I think 3) is perhaps the most important, and most easily, often overlooked. We already know that social interaction - "openly expressing concerns" - is profound (think, AA and any other simple form of social platform). Yet this is often missed out. Even focus groups are opportunities that are often missed, given our desire to 'direct' and 'get answers' ... I agree as well re: trending. However I tend towards an integrated approach that does consider how to tap into existing, latent desires.
Hi Renee, I understand you think this need for a better understanding of where we stand sits more on the consumer side than on the employees / company / providers side. Is this correct?

Actually - no. It is desperately needed on the side of employees/company/providers. I am not actually sure why this assumption would be made (curious) as all stakeholders involved will have concerns/etc that must be addressed, or else we risk facing resistance/deflection/etc.  It's actually making that link (insight re: employees/company/providers/stakeholders) that I think is so critical. Not only on the consumer side.

OK, thanks for clarifying. I kind of made the assumption myself because of the word used 'people' and also because you mention some research that I have typically seen on consumers, not on employees; but it was clearly me ;-) and I was not even sure I could assume it, that's why I asked.
Yes, I totally get it. This is usually viewed in the context of consumer-only research, which I believe is a limited view that needs to change ...

I have worked for a Telco Operator in Brasil who commercializes PCs under a rental agreement to businesses, and it took me a long time to make key employees shift from using the term 'product' to the term 'service'; although they were commercializing a service they would refer to it as a 'product'. And this misleading wording went further into the customer side, with many customers being disappointed at the end of their contract as their understanding was they were actually purchasing the PC. Unbelievable, but true. Many consumers do not read contracts, they are led by the trademarketing material, and as long as it is ambiguous, they can easily miss-interpret it.May be one option to start the shift within the company employees is to do a research on consumers that explores the need for consumers to buy a service not a device, or the need for consumers to make a statement to society through a device. Other industry case studies could also raise awareness and interest.

This is a great idea. Selling a full cycle service will certainly encourage manufacturers ('solution providers') to take more responsibility for their products' impact.This is a particularly good idea because it doesn't just appeal to 'caring for the environment'  but to the bottom line, which is likely to be more appealing to most companies.With this in mind, it would be good to think of a few business models which give electronics manufacturers both a competitive edge and an incentive to be responsible. (Although I think that if a model does the former, it will likely do the latter because the company will have to disassemble/reuse components in an efficient way). I just wrote up a quick business model for a company with the following plan: - Lease new phones to customers - Lease second hand (when the first customer wants a new one) phones to other customers- When this chain ends, send the phone to be recycled or for parts to be reused- (Bonus) Design phones with modular/reusable partsThe big win here is that phones can be leased MULTIPLE times = more revenue + better for the environment.Check out my business model: http://i.imgur.com/TvxmC.jpg(I used leancanvas.com)Finally, the here is a great article on how products are shifting from 'sold once' to being 'solutions provided'; this is already happening! http://blogs.hbr.org/cs/2012/08/understanding_customers_in_the_solution.html

Hi Alex, thank you for your insights. They are just great. On the one hands it shows that there is already a stream going in this direction and trying to find its way, while on the other hand, we see that in other industries the same concept is already a reality. The examples given in the article are just brilliant and they do show very well that the business opportunity is really solving a customer problem (the need for a service) rather than providing them with a device to them that solves it. I am confident this happen sooner or later in the tech industry, and will be a disruptive market opportunity for many.The business plan shot you provide is great to kick-off for MOBILE PHONES. It makes me think that the new customer proposal needs to also be taken to the market with a coherent positioning. This are some the points that come to my mind:- We do not lease phones; we offer a service. For instance we offer 'Calls'+'Email' for X$ a month; or 'Calls'+'Email'+Internet'.- The device is branded accordingly. Today, when consumers buy a mobile phone, they choose it in between other reasons for what the statement that the mobile phone does for them. For example, some people want iPhones and not Blackberrys, and the other way around, because if the statement to society the device does. So in our device, the mobile phone should be branded accordingly so that allows a user to state steadily to society, for instance, 'I am environmentally concerned and I choose and accordingly'. Consumers must be proud to show the brand, just as may are proud to say 'I have an iPhone'- Channels to introduce this model should also be chosen coherently with its brand positioning, for instance through virtual mobile operators which purely offer services to customers and have never entered into the device-game game.By reading your post, I also see more clearly that the figures need to stand out in this model too. And I do think that there is a manufacturing cost opportunity. There is already a lot done in the design industry in this respect, which can be used as a starting point. Have a look at this guide ... it already provides guidelines to do a design ready for diss-assembly, which is really something that this concept needs:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tQY1VdpHF4c&feature=relatedThe difference is that not many of these designs are thought to be commercialized as a service. They are still on the 'device era'. So we can add the next step on it: the service approach. It is really much more feasible that it may appear at a first glance.But in any case it is true that the whole value chain needs to be aligned. The business model needs to provide profits to all actors in the chain. On mobile phones, for instance, it means that at least manufacturers and operators work together to build a consumer offer. And within the manufacturing chain the model can go deep into different levels within the chain. I would assume that at a first implementation, we can think the model only goes into the mobile manufacturer and not any further (so, a CPU provider for instance, would remain out of this new model and would continue to operate as it does today).

Hi William, thanks for your challenging question.I think your proposal fits the industry, at least for mobile devices ... the mobile phone has already a meaning in our society, so using this meaning as a tool, as I understand you propose, is powerful.Your challenging question also makes me see more clearly that each device has a different meaning in a society, and therefore the model needs to be different to each case. A mobile phone for instance symbols something very different from what a printer in a company symbols.And by the way, in the printers industry we have already seen a shift in the business model, which is close to the one we discuss here: HP offers printers under a 'service agreement' as opposed to 'selling the device'; companies just pay an amount for the number of copies / prints, and HP does all the maintenance and upgrades of the machine.It seems that in industries where the cost of the device may be a barrier, the change is more likely to happen. So may be we could identify other barriers that could foster the change.If HP is already not that far from the concept, may be we are not as far from making it happen as it may seem.

Thank you! I am really happy to see there is light for this opportunity to create a more conscious manufacturing and consumption pattern. There is nothing wrong with consuming, as long as the whole chain is responsible.It is true that the proposal is a bit brave as it encompasses changes on both sides, the manufacturing chain and consumer buying criteria. But then I do think there are symptoms already in both spaces calling for the change, just as we have seen the same symptoms in other sectors (i.e using plastic bags on supermarkets) Even within the manufacturing chain the new direction would enter into a positive spiral. For example: an OEM such as Intel, could start designing a new CPU that can be easily reused from one device to the next ... therefore long-term durability thinking design criteria could eventually come back into space as it would make sense again as a business driven criteria. In the model that we use today, this criteria does not add value to a business (in the current model as long as a device is sold, that's fine for the business).As in many other disruptive market changes, I do believe the change needs to be driven from the consumer request and then all the way up to the value chain. Companies are desperate to cover a market opportunity, so I understand that to make companies open their eyes to this change, an effective tool would be one that shows how there are consumers ready for this, that there are successful cases in other markets with many similarities, and there are also significant cost savings in their manufacturing process (i.e opportunity to make an assembling design chain that allows for easy later device de-assembling to re-use some of its pieces for a new model).I will think over this to refine it and the questions below, and will certainly go over the links provided.I take the chance to thank IDEO for this platform. The world does need a platform for thinkers across the world to share and discuss challenges!

Great thinking! Your idea reminds me a lot of the Interface carpet story - basically going from a selling carpet/flooring model to a leasing model. Here's one writeup I found that explains more: http://bit.ly/QNhD1f. It might provide even more inspiration for your concept.

Thanks for the business case Ashley, it's an amaing read! And I do think it shows very wall how an industry can be re-organised in order to survive in a context where we will run out of natural resources and we cannot avoid anymore the problem generated by mass consumption trash. There are a couple of points I think it's worth taking away from it: 1) It states that they realized there was 'very few people wanting  to own the carpet', which is probably a green light to making the business model shift a reality, and to me it probably explains how this model has come to market so early ... and I say 'early' because the same article even states that the carpet is not even marketed as 'environmentally friendly', as it appeared to be an attribute that would put off customers. To me this first point is important as when I did some research for a PC manufacturer back in 2008 we did found out at that time that being 'environmentally friendly' did not seem to be a factor in the consumer's mind when it came to choosing a PC in a shop. This was 4 years ago, and I believe consumers mind may have evolved and have become more conscious of the trash problem. But in any case I understand the way the concept should be marketed should stay away from addressing whose property the device is ... or whether it is a 'sell or lease' model ... to avoid still potential barriers ... it's not so much about a product and how to exploit it (sell vs. lease), it's about a service. Nobody questions whose ownership is a service. I have recently purchase an IPTV service and the Set-Top Box I have been given does not belong to me ... and I hardly even notice this in the process. Why do they do this this way? A Set-top box is expensive so if they sold it, nobody would buy the service. Is the Set-top-box sold as a lease agreement? No. Do I care about what Set-top box they give me? No, as long as it does its function. So to me it's about getting rid of past business frames and focus on value and service.2) The business model builds on the fact that trash has a value for the manufacturing chain ... and this is something that somebody else brought up in another concept (the marketplace one). And to me this is another key hidden asset on which the concept should build on. If a computer was 'sold to us' so that if it does not work it is replaced, we would really not care whether a microchip inside of it comes from another computer or if it is brand new ... what we need is what the computer does for us; as long as the company would take responsibility on ensuring that it works, we'd be fine.

I certainly will complete the concept with a picture tomorrow, and possibly more details on inspiration from other sectors. I had to unexpectedly leave my workplace and could not save the thoughts, so I published it; sorry about this.

Just received some junk mail in my letter box saying, in part "Want to rent a computer and save some money at the same time?""Re-Rent laptops from $16.95 p/w"The fine print makes the rate unattractive here (minimum total payment over $1800) but I guess a good part of that includes a buffer for 24 hour repair and replacement guarantee, together with Anne's data transfer and elimination at every changeover..

Great idea Greg!Dell and a few other companies are already doing this with ex-rental and bulk contract clients who turn over recent product quickly (while they are still attractive on the secondary market) - see ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/inspiration/electronics-companies-getting-involved-today/ ).Setting up something more general makes good sense - this could be a marketplace for locally 'regenerated' items where the regeneration is achieved through a network of 'recognised' refurbishment firms with access to the spare parts database. This is done in the auto industry where parts are catalogued for trading between repair shops. So an PC with a sound motherboard might only need another video card - or alternatively the motherboard might become a component in a refurbished PC elsewhere.The Philippines has a thriving secondary market for some 'repaired' electronics even to replacing laptop screens.I have a Dell laptop with an (almost monochrome) red screen - a company in the US has quoted me on supplying replacement components to fix it myself (which I may get around to doing).

I agree - but it need not be based entirely on the brand of the refurbished items - clearly the importance is to establish a link between the REGENERATE brand and reputation for reliability and guaranteed work.When I mentioned the Philippines there is a certain amount of 'potluck' about purchasing on the secondary market but, ironically, some repair/refurbishment shops seem to have a better attitude to 'after sales service' than many Philippines retailers of new product.

Interesting, Paul. To clarify  when I said 'brand' I meant the way authenticity, trust and reliability, etc are built into an enterprise  and communicated. You can read more in the great book The Brand Gap  or check a bit of a lowdown here: https://vimeo.com/7185200

Interesting concept, as certainly there are is lot of e-waste from items that still work, but simply are outdated, or that could easily be repaired and used again. I'd see an extension to your idea: Refurbish centers owned by the manufacturers that give old/repaired items to charities for people in poor countries who do not even own a PC/laptop/cell phone yet. With increasing pressure on companies to show social commitment and to act environmentally responsible, this could be a good opportunity to do so. However: The e-waste still exists, and at the end of the chain, it would still need to be collected again and disposed of. That would require some further thoughts before the implementation, e.g. people benefitting from returning their old items by getting earlier access to the next generation items or by getting a small recompensation. The benefit for the company would be 1) that they can show their social commitment 2) that they gain a few years time to improve their disposal systems  and to think of a better reusability of their future products  3) that the people benefitting from the items get better informed, more educated and hence obtain a higher living standard and buying power. When taking a purchase decision, they are already used to the brand, which they trust.

Great suggestions Veronika. I have just done a quick calculation of the value of electronic items as 'scrap' based on some figures available through Franklyn Zhu's concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/golden-e-waste-a-commodity-more-valuable-than-gold-ore/ ). As a rule of thumb you can generously weigh your item in kilograms then apply approximately $1 per kilo to its value. So a 1kg laptop is worth about $1, a 100g cell phone about 10c etc. Any item that can still provide someone with service is therefore worth maintaining and extending its life. At the final end of life the $1 per kilo simply represents profit to the recycler on goods donated or collected for free.This says to me that proposals like this to extend life of electronics are very worthwhile.

Hi Meena,Thanks for the kind words.  By the end of product life I mean something that a grade school child would understand. comments.text: David--you have proposed a simple concept with a great scaffolding to back it up.  In my opinion, ideas like yours tend to be the most solid and practical solutions to problems like this, where the ultimate level of corporate success is not directly dependent on participation from the masses.  In today's age, it is far too easy for large companies to 'put in their share of the effort' and then leave it to their end users to complete the task (the often disregarded #1-7 recycling symbols exemplify this well, I think).  By initiating a b2b program, you can effectively control a higher level of participation with a more stable and predictable outcome than you might have if you were to deal directly with consumers.  Every time a middle man is added to a supply chain, there becomes a marginal profit loss toward the manufacturing end and this can be greatly problematic when dealing with low-value scrap such as e-waste.  Separating, cataloging and transporting e-waste to third-parties is often financially prohibitive, which is why e-waste is such an issue--it doesn't have enough value to begin with in order to warrant that amount of effort.  It is very commendable that you seem to understand that the underlying goal with the e-waste issue is indeed to get e-waste out of the hands of the populous in an efficient manner, such that the number of 'middle men' are lessened; surely, this will maximize potential profit.  In my opinion, creating reverse supply chains (such as those which would tediously deliver scrap electronics back to the original manufacturers) is almost always cost prohibitive. This is why business like used-printer-cartridge purchasers are most often run by third-parties, rather than the initial cartridge manufacturers--the number of middlemen are drastically reduced.  Many US Post Offices offer plastic bags with prepaid postage just for the sole purpose of reducing the middlemen who might otherwise be involved in ink cartridge recycling.  The cartridge goes directly from the end-user to a third party with a relatively small amount of sunk costs.I am particularly fond of your idea because you seem to have a solid grasp on the fact that targeting b2b groups might really be the way to go here, and I am with you 100%.  Many of the concepts which I have read are more focused on b2c (and even c2c, in some more localized propositions).  Your idea is much like mine in the sense that our concepts can co-exist with non-b2b solutions without causing a large amount of counterproductive competition, which is important when trying to make a maximum dent in the amount of discarded e-waste.  The more feasible (and of course, profitable) options there are to manage e-waste, the more proactive people will be in acquiring and dispensing it.The reason why bottle redemption is efficient is simple: there are no middle men.  The entire process begins and ends with the consumer, so there is is no real loss to the consumer--the consumer does not have to pay an additional fee for the service.  Essentially, this type of 'closed-loop' is what it sounds like you are proposing and I have to agree that this exclusivity makes a whole lot of sense.  In terms of planning for a long-term up-start, having a closed circuit of buyers and distributors is probably the best way to ensure that there will ultimately be a profit margin.  It is very respectable that you haven't loss sight of this important facet.  While goodwill does seem to prevail a bit more every year in terms of encouraging pro-Bono recycling initiatives, an industrial-sized operation like yours requires a much larger amount of capital than volunteer-run mom-and-pop recycling centers, but it has the potential to make a much larger impact with lesser overall effort.  With that being said, I think that your closed-loop b2b concept will be able to appeal to potential investors in ways that less-centralized e-waste recycling initiatives could.  Best of all, I think that your idea (like mine) could attract a more diverse group of investors than most b2c/c2b (and certainly, c2c) operations could.  As much as I hate to lay-down the reality of the situation, large corporations don't generally want to be bothered by minimally profitable initiatives if the incentives show even the slightest amount of risk.  The grand part about your idea, however, is that the more predictable outcome of dealing in a closed-loop means that the types of investors that would normally shy away, might take a second look, simply because the exclusivity lowers the risk for loss.  Despite a faltering economy, electronics sales are still on the rise.  The fact that your concept could (in theory) allow you to reign control over your own financial infrastructure--whilst maintaining a steady flow of e-waste product coming in--means that your position as the banker in your own economy cannot be spontaneously (or easily) taken away from you.  That notion in itself would undoubtedly tantalize more than a few venture capitalists if you played your card right pitching your proposal!Abbreviated notes on terminology for enthusiastic readers...Please don't hesitate to correct me if I am wrong with any of these!  :)*b2b commerce:  When one business transacts directly with another.**b2c commerce:  One business transacts directly with the consumer***c2b commerce:  End-user consumer sells to business; ex. Pawn ****c2c commerce:  (Comparatively uncommon) when two end-user consumers transact with one another--bartering non-professionally*****Venture Capitalists:  Professional investors who provide the up-front funding necessary to initiate a new up-start business******Supply Chain:  The collective businesses involved in getting a product into the hands of the consumer (end-user)--this can include every participant invested in the acquisition of the raw materials to the delivery personnel.

Hi David, I do like your perspective that trash has a value. I have worked for other industries, such as the cement industry, where this is coming to surface. One of the key strategic business issues in this industry is the lack of mines for one of the key raw materials required to produce cement. And what do they do? They are working hard to find the way to recover this material from buildings that are torn down. So they end up buying 'the trash'. We are going to run out of raw resources sooner or later, and we will have to extract those raw resources from 'human manufactured' trash. Some trash will be having an increasing value. And we may not need to wait until mother earth is exhausted to do this. The market place can start earlier. And building on this, if there was a marketplace right away, companies would have an easier way to take on the responsibility of what happens to the material of a device they manufacture (which is in my opinion a key weakpoint of the industry we've created and the starting step of the overall problem ... ).

Great idea David and very relevant.We seem to have focused (fairly naturally) on the "electronic" aspects of e-waste but it is much broader than that (and I should broaden the focus of my concepts accordingly).Somewhere in my research I came across a very big company recycling plastic - in the article they admitted that their recovery rate was exceptionally high because the figures were based on recycling electric kettles almost exclusively. Notwithstanding that electric kettles are as much a part of the e-waste stream as i-phones.Your idea extends the reach of an existing marketplace in a really useful way.

That's really interesting that the company was so focused on recycling an electronic device I hadn't even thought of as part of the problem. I'm looking forward to seeing what concepts you can come up with based on the wider scope of everything that makes up e-waste!

That's partly why my recyCOOLable concept is based on the Energy Star labeling concept (apart from trying to make it kid friendly too) I see smart fridges, washing machines, microwaves, clock radios, scales etc. as part of the wider problem. The more connected our homes, businesses and industry become electronically the more there is to consider. Certainly the mobile phone, computers and peripherals are enough problem in themselves but if we took a holistic approach there is probably enough waste in most communities to make recycling a viable 'paying' option.I'm still of the opinion that whoever comes up with a small scale process that can eliminate the long distance transport of waste will make a killing - and be able to feed material back into the emerging bespoke manufacturing like 3D printing (hence my other underdeveloped concept).

Good thinking David. Industrial recycling is key. Post consumer content is only a fraction of the big picture, and as Paul pointed out, we've been focused on those electronic products in the hands of consumers. Last summer I interned at a manufacturer of high tech airplane components (from passenger airliners to fighter jets). All of the parts were made on CNC (computer numerical controlled) milling machines so there was a lot of excess metal after each run. For them it was as easy as keeping each scrap pile separate out back and calling in a recycler. At first I thought this idea wouldn't be necessary given how easy it was to get rid of that waste, but with electronics it's not so simple. The idea of this open marketplace where companies can find others who will use the waste both creates new opportunities for recycling and eliminates some of the middle-man costs.

Given your experience at the tech components manufacturing company, what do you think would make them more or less likely to participate in such a marketplace? and what are possible concerns/opportunities that I'm not thinking about?

comments.text: Hi there, I think this is a really interesting concept. I frequently travel to The Gambia and one thing I have learnt there is that if you can't open machines up, it's easy to understand how they can be repaired,  and you can't get replacement bits for broken parts that work, they quickly turn into obsolete junk. There you find donated computers in clinics that locals call 'ornaments', ultra sound machines that cost a fortune but don't work because one tiny part has broken and on the other hand you have cars that are 3 decades old but still run because they don't require software to be repaired and replacement parts don't have to be a perfect fit. Could you maybe look at gadgets such as phones not necessarily to be modular but to be repairable. I think this would open it up a bit more. Maybe this means that components have to be modular but it might also mean that not just the outside (buttons, etc) follows a particular colour coding for usability but also that the inside is designed for usability that allows easy repair.

comments.text: Another great option Ashley.Again scalable so that simpler aspects can be introduced earlier in the education stream and lead to broader knowledge of sustainability.
Thanks Paul!

I took an Economic Geography class recently. It didn't offer solutions for sustainability but it did force students to confront global issues related to unsustainable practices. It really gets the mind working on solutions. It is set up as an elective at my university but has been recommended by some of my business professors because it provides such a good perspective.

Perhaps too abstract but using implicit curriculum to help students become more conscious consumers. I teach a course called Consumer Happiness.  We explore the origin of and the mutation of happiness in modern, hyper consumer world.  The trick is this course is offered in Marketing department. 99% of courses are about how to market, not how to consume.  All other courses I teach, examples are about sustainable consumption.  When something is taught w/o an explicit title, learning can be more organic, hence more effective.  It works in my classes, of which majority are jaded seniors of marketing majors who want to get a job in some big shiny marketing firm.

Hi Ashley, I just commented on someone else's concept that it really bugs me that sustainability is not even compulsory for design students in the UK. I absolutely think it should be a mandatory part of the curriculum but I also see Anne-Laure's point that it should probably start earlier.

Ashley, I like the idea of making this "mandatory"... part of the "basics"... I'm wondering if this should not even start earlier. You raised important issues regarding who would be involved and what should be required. I don't have an answer but I think it is important. Could it be a multidisciplinary course? involving science, technology and humanities... economics and history could also be part of this... You could imagine a project aspect of this where students would have to evaluate their own behaviors...

Agreed ALSustainability is probably a sufficiently important topic to introduce at middle school level where it integrates naturally with a range of subject matter across disciplines. Even at that age there is sufficient scope to draw on life experience to draw out principles.

I love the idea of starting even younger! It's definitely a topic that kids should be exposed to as early as possible. AL - I really like your idea of it being a multidisciplinary course that brings together lots of viewpoints and perspectives. I have to keep thinking about how it would be implemented/funded etc.

Great idea Ashley! I love that this idea would be part of a broader initiative and reach very large audiences. I agree starting early is important too. It seems like people who are younger are already exposed and own so many electronics early that knowing the steps to be more sustainable is great!

Ashley, at the university level, you could imagine rather than a course per se, maybe a series of workshops / sessions during induction at least as a prototype / pilot. It indeed creates some issues when it comes to having faculty involved (how does it fit in their teaching load), and to the students' commitment (is it graded? does it count for credits?) etc.At the school level (middle school or high school), it might be easier as there are no credit issues. Yet, you still need to find a way to include it as a part of the curriculum. You might be able to find some schools with some project learning philosophy which will include it in their curriculum. see for example the exploration program at MS447: http://www.ms447brooklyn.org/exploration-program.htmlMany of the projects already touch to issues related to sustainability and they are very multidisciplinary. You could imagine a topic focusing on sustainability.

comments.text: Hi Karen, I studied product design in the UK and sustainability is NOT a compulsory part of the curriculum which really bugs me. Therefore it is taught at varying degrees in different design schools throughout the country and you still end up with graduates who think making a chair out of pile of plastic bottles is designing sustainable products. It's interesting to see that you have a similar issue in Norway.

This is an extremely important point Anne.Without 'core' status a subject like sustainability is open to enormous interpretation. I work for a company that uses boxes for its products made from recycled material, encourages its customers to recycle responsibly but does not encourage its suppliers to be as responsible, and itself discards recyclable materials in the landfill stream.

I think this is a great concept! As a current business student, I benefited tremendously from a course on ethical & sustainable business practices. Your concept could easily be expanded and adapted to provide relevant courses/seminars to all members involved in product creation (engineers, artists & designers, strategists, marketers, etc.).

Love it. As an engineering grad student I would attend something like this in a heartbeat, given that the motives were clearly advertised and the program was well crafted. What about starting something like this online. I have something like iTunes U in mind as a way to distribute free lectures.  And since a video lecture isn't interactive maybe there could be a vibrant online community where students could participate in design activities (maybe something as nice as OpenIDEO). Obviously real life seminars and workshops are more fun and engaging, but an online method could be cheaper to implement at first. Or it could just supplement the local events and provide greater access. Curriculum material could also be distributed for free in the same style as MIT OpenCourseWare. (http://ocw.mit.edu/index.htm)

I did not know that MIT had curriculum material online, thank you! Yes, great idea, it could definitively start of as an online community, and it would be a great, all year thing that students could do. In addition to seminars and events.

Great idea Karen! I think that education is a absolutely key component in whatever model gets adopted. Do you think an organization like the one you have proposed could begin to influence students at even a younger age (high school or even junior high) so by the time the choose a college and a career path they are already informed about this different way of thinking?Also, would you propose that this organization try to influence the actual curriculum of higher education institutions rather than spreading the message through seminars?

yes, students from all ages could get invited for a quick lesson or to see different demonstrations. Or that the organization have talks and demonstrations at the high schools, getting in touch with them as well. I think the organization will inspire to change the curriculum, and when more students and professors get in inspired and involved, it would be natural for a uni/college to want an up to speed curriculum. And hopefully, it will end up being a subject of it own.

Great thoughts on awareness building, Karen! And I wonder if there might be an online network which connects global students to support seminars, etc. Maybe something along the lines of Designers Accord? http://www.designersaccord.org/

Thanks for the link, I hadn't heard about that network before. I think they can be a great inspiration for the concept, but I really think it needs to me even more out there, and contact the schools, making sure people hear about the cause.
Yes - perhaps we need something to challenge the academic institutions to alter their thinking. Something like a perpetual international award for the institution with the most holistic curriculum.
Great observations Karen and absolutely fundamental concept.It is essential that design thinking embraces reduction reuse and recycling principles from the outset.

encourage_consumers_to_bring_back_electr.description: Apply an old school method of ensuring beverage container reuse/recycling to consumer electronics. Have consumers pay an extra deposit when purchasing electronics that they will be refunded for recycling.
encourage_consumers_to_bring_back_electr.creator: bca5a1676971e1534f137a71b1ca7fa6

comments.text: The tricky question is how much is charged as a deposit. If its high enough to cover the costs for the manufacturer/retailer, incentivizing them to participate, it might be too high for consumers to accept when they're buying. On the other hand the deposit has to be significant enough that consumer's make the effort of sending the products back to the manufacturers. There needs to be a transparent splitting of costs to hold everyone responsible for the recycling process.I wonder though whether this system will promotes selling and constant trading up for new models while discouraging re-use... I would consider an alternative where people who donate or gift usable products also get some of their deposit back.I think this proposal is great but there are intrinsic differences between FMCG and durable goods that make it tricky to translate. more questions than answers...

I like this - it is true it relies on phone manufacturer / retailer and government to support this but this is the only way you support sustainable behaviour longterm.a few thoughts  1)to make sure collection is easy you could have a "recycling your old phone bag" in the box of the new one and you drop it in a mail box and the refund will be done on your next bill - this way if you dont want to give your old phone right away ( if you still have pictures on the phone for example) you can do it in your own time. if you haven't done it by your next bill you'll get a reminder on it ...2) the same way you can recycle medecine or glasses for countries  that cant afford it or even start a new life for your plastic, maybe recycling your phone can be useful and this also increase the incentive ( as well as monetary reward)

Great idea and excellent discussion / comments so far. I believe legislation must be enacted and enforced in order to successfully implement. Retailers must add more value and take on the responsibility of accepting recycling returns on behalf of their customers. In order to succeed on a large scale, everyone in the supply and consumption chain must benefit from the program.All Consumer Electronics (CE) Products should carry an Eco-rating, similar to the Energy Star rating. This will allow consumers to have a way to evaluate the eco footprint / impact of their purchasing decisions. Much like Energy Star has done, Eco-ratings will also help drive industry wide advances in energy efficiency, material selections, and design for disassembly and recycling. Better Eco-rated products would benefit by having lower deposit 'taxes' added on (as a percentage of MSRP, not 'sale' price) in a given product category. Thus, manufacturers will be financially incentivized to create more sustainable and eco-friendly products.So where does the money from the deposits go? Perhaps into federal trust funds collecting interest that in turn are used to cover the costs of managing the program? Also, some of the deposit funds will be needed to refund consumers who return items for recycling.Participating retailers (smaller ones can optionally register but participation would be mandatory for major retailers over a certain size) of consumer electronics that register into the federal CE Recycling Program must accept deposit returns of any qualifying product. CE products that don't qualify for deposit refunds should also be accepted for recycling, but no deposit will be paid out. Retailers will pay deposit returns to consumers, and later be reimbursed on a monthly? quarterly? basis by the federal government. Retailers will have to factor the costs of this program into their overhead, which I'm sure will get passed back onto consumers, probably raising prices of goods. This is not such a bad thing, as the low cost of goods is one reason why consumers are so quick to dispose of them, regardless of their actual working conditions. So what's the incentive for smaller retailers to register and participate? How about corporate tax breaks for being 'greener' corporate citizens? Also, looking at bottle recycling as a parallel business model, offering a take back service can also drive increases in consumer retail traffic. No one wants to go one place to drop off their deposits and go elsewhere to shop. The convenience factor will give retailers that accept returns and pay deposits a competitive advantage over those that don't.Did I capture all the stakeholders? Let's see... Consumers? Check. Manufacturers? Check. Retailers? Check. What have I missed? It's getting late here in Shanghai, so my brain is shutting down. I can't wait to what brilliance comes from everyone's comments when I wake up tomorrow :-)

Congrats on making the Refinement phase Top 20 shortlist! We loved your analogous thinking to find inspiration and insight in bottle recycling programs. As you collaborate during Refinement, we'd encourage you to consider how to better understand what kind of deposit consumers would be willing to pay  and how we might educate them to not only understand what the deposit is used for, but how important their involvement is in the entire recycling ecosystem. For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/ewaste-top20 and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine(Note: We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!)
