Hey Rob - I definitely agree that monetary incentives are one of the strongest forms of incentives out there. I also agree with some of the contributors that this simple concept would require the cooperation of many entities. Instead of hitting consumers with a deposit at the time of purchase, one monetary incentive would be for the mfg. (or maybe even the retailer) to offer some sort of small discount when you return your old phone and purchase a new one. In this scenario, there would be the incentive to return/recycle the phone to get a discount. The mfg. could either re-sell the old phone or make money by recycling the scrap (metal prices are on the rise!), and also the retailer/mfg. would then have you as a repeat customer for a couple more years. Everyone would win!

I think that this is an excellent idea, and could potentially solve the 'collection' stage of the E-waste recycling process.The more ideas I read the more I feel many of these could be linked together! With regards to this idea (which I very much like) I think it would be effective to first get backing of at least a few big brand names. Perhaps in the implementation stage we can try to see if big retailers like Radioshack would be interested?But of course, we would need to convince them and bring them benefits.Firstly, I think that it is important that we inform key people and communities. I think the "Life of your Phone" idea (http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/the-life-of-your-phone/) is a great project to begin informing people. A minimalistic website, interesting, very aesthetically pleasing. Try viral videos, do it KONY style. Also, any college students here? Start awareness campaigns in universities, based on some of the excellent ideas posted already. A student community is often a great place to start, and to galvanize people into action.With key people and communities behind us, I think we would have more leverage. For instance, if, say, a student at Stanford were to get the community interested in E-Waste, we may be able to get enough publicity to get to higher corporate powers from our local 'radioshack'.If we are able to get corporate interest or even support, we may be able to bring this then to a governmental level. Talk with our local representatives, see what they can do to encourage this.I think that it is essential that we combine this idea with public, and eventually government support. I agree with Ali that unless we are able to get many companies to do this, it would be difficult to effectively implement.--This is a key step of the overall process. But there are other areas to consider, such as the actual recycling of the E-waste. Who collects the Radioshack waste? Why would they have the incentive?Pascal and my idea talks a bit about this step of the process (http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/golden-e-waste-a-commodity-more-valuable-than-gold-ore/). The concept may shed light onto the actual recycling step of the process and how it may be profitable. In order to provide the generic Radioshack with more than just moral incentive, perhaps we can talk with established recycling companies such as ERIsee how they purchase their e-waste, and how much e-waste we would need have in order for it to be financially feasible to collect.This is an idea that I would be interested in helping implement. I think it is a GREAT ideaapplying a tried and true concept to E-Waste.Throughout this process, I believe it is absolutely key that we keep in mind the many different interests and incentives involved.

I think that unless every company did this (and i'm not sure we want that kind of regulation), many consumers would purchase from the companies that didn't collect the refundable deposit - in short, consumers don't like money out of their wallets (even if they can get it back) and so it would be bad for business for the electronics companies who participated.

Great concept--if you lost your phone (and had to get another one) would you have to pay an additional deposit? If so, then what would happen to the original deposit?Also, the bottle deposit has enabled others (not the original consumer) to make a living (or at least some spending money). How would cell phones already "in the wild" be handled?Perhaps a credit could be issued for bringing in/trading in old cell phones under this program.

Also very valid points Andreas!In the case of cell phones I guess proof of ownership is difficult (but not impossible) but I suspect the value of the deposit would need to be a balance between something that would make you keep it on a leash, so to speak, and something that would not make theft attractive.Loss would then be total loss and a new deposit payable.Others may have a different view.A better than beverage bottle deposit would make it attractive to keep them out of landfill (one way or another). Based on information from another concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/golden-e-waste-a-commodity-more-valuable-than-gold-ore/ ) California's deposit based beverage recycling system uses a variety of existing infrastructure, which might be a good basis for this too.For other e-waste it would vary too. Exploring all the variables and what is practical for each type of e-waste is raisson d'etre for this challenge.
Great concept! Very simple and great way to transfer practices from beverages to electronics. I also think that offering an easy to "implement" opportunity is very important for the users.
Very valid points AL, especially regarding making the solution easy for users to implement.

This is a great idea!  Meena is absolutely right -- simplicity is key!Perhaps the company receiving the old devices could also be responsible for wiping the memory and any remaining data (most important for cell phones and computers).  I've hung on to old computers before because a) I don't know what to do with them, and b) there is person information saved on them and I am perilously afraid of identity theft.  It would be great if people could easily return old devices with the confidence that the information on them would be wiped.

Great thoughts Mira - linking this to Anne Schiffer's concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/digital-data-transfer-and-elimination-service-/  ) also the possibility of transfer of that data to the new device (which often has greater data capacity anyway).
Lot to like here  simplicity rocks!

In Germany there are recycling centers to collect electronic waste and (at least in our area) there is a van that comes around periodically to collect waste from those who can't get to one of the recycling centers.  Batteries are collected through a different system with containers for spent batteries in the stores that sell them.For batteries the system works fairly well, because the manufactures have realized that it is cost effective to recycle.  But for other electronic items the cost effectiveness is less evident. Reports about electronic waste that was supposed to have been recycled ending up in open landfills in Africa or Asia surface regularly in the German media.  Apparently private sector self-policing doesn't work very well in all cases.  Therefore a robust enforcement regime will be required to make sure that the electronic items that are returned do indeed get recycled.

Yes you are right Greg - that's why I think it is important to acknowledge those manufacturers who incorporate recycled material into their new product. It is in this that your 'Bulk Flow' concept comes to the fore since that is one way in which it would be possible to know which manufacturers are using recycled materials and to give them acknowledgement which could be a financial incentive. Mira Rae posted a concept for cap and trade in e-waste management( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/inspiration/cap-and-trade-treating-e-waste-like-air-pollutants/ ). The difference between e-waste and green-house gases is that the recycling of e-waste is well within or control if we choose to do so.From my reading of the R2 concept (Responsible Recycling) adopted by EU and some other jurisdictions this requires a take-back component and responsible handling of the materials but does not per se guarantee feeding the recycled materials back into a manufacturing stream. Perhaps a new R3 standard incorporating your 'robust enforcement' is required.

I also like this concept, Rob. I think that a robust recycling program also has the potential to change how electronics developers (and others sectors for that matter) think about their product's design and price points.  If there is a significant increase in parts or materials that can be reused, that can bring down the costs of production.  Rather than take this savings out of the overall cost of the product, I would suggest that this savings becomes an increasingly large rebate for the recycled material. For example, rather than adjusting the price of a smart phone down from $500 to $400 (hypothetical) because it has a refurbished/recycled shell, I would love to see the phone still cost $500 dollars at the outset, but now when the consumer brings it back for recycling he or she could receive $100 + whatever recycling reimbursement was originally offered. The incentive to recycle would increase as the payment goes up.  As the incentive increases the amount of material that is brought in for reuse resulting in an even more consistent supply of material that can be factored into design processes and possibly begin a virtuous cycle.

Here in Finland the recycling system works really well. I can return any given plastic bottle or soda can bought in Finland to a collecting machine in every major grocery store. They work by recognizing the barcode and the returned deposit is also based on the type of a bottle returned. Deposits make also others collect abandoned bottles because they can profit from them.Although the system works really well it doesn't accept bottles with missing or unknown barcodes. Bottles bought outside Finland cannot be returned here. (In Finland all shopping malls have collection stations for glass, metal, energy waste, paper and batteries)Thus, there lies a problem in identifying the phones with the deposit already paid. For example too old phones don't have deposits that could be refunded.Making business out of returned phones could make it easier. Because they might profit from the phones returned they could actually pay a certain amount for every phone returned and in that case there could be refund on every phone and the returning locations could be separate from stores and they could accept any model on earth!

Great input thanks Oskari!Particularly interested in the bottle barcoding - I wonder if it might be possible to recognise an embossed barcode or the number representing the type of plastic from which it is made.Also could you tell me what proportion of purchase price is refunded? For example purchase price is 1 Euro how much deposit is returned?

Excellent Robert!This concept has always made sense to me and I would love to see it implemented not only for electronics but for a whole range of things.It will need a great shift in thinking in some places but very worthwhile pursuing.Here in Australia the mobile phone market (not the smart phones) is based largely on call cost profitability so many phones are advertised as zero cost provided you take a particular service plan. Most consumers therefore see their mobile as 'worthless' at end of life.It would probably be necessary to mandate a deposit through legislation.On the plus side there are political rumors about deposits on plastic containers so if we could extend it to other goods that would be really good.

Thats a great point. I was focused on electronics when I was writing this up, but you're right it could be applied to so much more! I've always wanted to see a return in the US to glass Coca-Cola (and other beverage) bottles that are refilled rather than recycled. Everywhere in Europe i ever ordered a Coke, it came in glass. If it works there it should work here!As for the 'worthless' phone mentality, its similar here in the US. At this point you really don't pay for the basic models. It's even starting to creep into the smartphone market. The lower end models are starting to come free with a 2 year contract on some providers. And I agree that legislation would be key to a successful implementation. It could prove to be a major hurdle here in the US though.

Encouraging the consumer to recycle is certainly important - I touched on this in the inspiration phase:http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/inspiration/incentivize-recycling-for-the-consumer/I think there are a number of ways to encourage the consumer - offering refunds or discounts for example.To me, though, the real challenge is how to encourage the manufacturer/retailer to take part. As it would reflect well on a given corporation, the desire to be seen to be concerned with the e-waste problem might be incentive enough. I fear, though, that it may, as you say, be something that will require legislation.I think the cost of recycling is a burden that should be shared by the manufacturer and the retailer - both, perhaps, being obliged to recycle a unit for each unit produced/sold. This means that market leaders would be responsible for recycling their share of the waste & this might encourage them to make products that are more readily recyclable in the future.

Return for deposit is a great concept and certainly applies across a whole range of consumer products. We need a hook to start the ball rolling and a campaign to give it speed.I too would love to see a return to glass bottles (particularly where they have been displaced by plastic).The challenge (in a free market) is the input cost and price resistance.There may be some clues in the South Australian system here( http://www.epa.sa.gov.au/page.php?page=262 ) which my son-in-law just told me may be extended Australia wide this year.For e-waste specifically there are political hurdles here - what should be straightforward legislation has (presumably) suffered nationally from business lobbying but things are moving a little ( http://www.environment.gov.au/settlements/waste/ewaste/index.html )
Just heard that beverage container deposits are to be debated nationally here in a few days and was interested to hear also that 40 states and countries are using beverage deposit systems.

Great idea! I really like the deposit idea and it definitely has been in place for different products. I also think that retailers would definitely benefit from people coming to their stores to return their electronics. It shows that these companies care about this issue. It's a great step in the right direction! I think the challenge is how to implement this - maybe as other comments have noted this could be rolled out over time and focus on certain electronics then branch out to much more.
I am a firm believer of encouraging behavioral change through incentives and the simplicity of this concept is great!
Just to explore a wild thought about value and pricing - what if the deposit was somehow tied into the value of warranty.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks!

Great concept!  This idea can certainly become as "everyday" as deposits are now in some states.  Since reading your concept, I've been thinking about this idea and I definitely want to see it happen sometime soon.  I'm not sure how deep into the details we want to get in the concepting phase but here are some of my thoughts:The challenge will be with the implementation, specifically with the retailers.  (Using phones as an example, consumers might be turned off by inconsistencies among retailers. They also won't initially understand the idea that they'll only pay once for all the smartphones they'll ever own, and instead they only see the additional price.)  However, much of the problem could be solved, as has been mentioned, if this is introduced as a law (as opposed to a program one company starts and others adopt).  Some details remaining to be ironed out would deal with the return of the deposit: Using the soda can deposits model as an example, in Oregon (and I'm assuming elsewhere) certain brands of soda cans (usually off-brand) need to be taken to specific grocery stores in order to get the deposit back.  Translated to this electronics deposit idea, what happens when I purchase a more long-term electronic device that's not so quickly phased out like smartphones (such as a stereo receiver)...and years later I can't remember where I purchased it? Where do I get the deposit?  This problem could be solved by the law, but as experience with the soda deposit law in Oregon shows, not all cans are accepted everywhere, even with a law.Anyway, I love this idea.  The above comments are not criticisms but rather additional (and admittedly nit-picky) details to consider as you further develop this promising concept.  Good luck!

Sorry to crowd your space with more comments, but just one more thought:  You might consider phasing this in. Maybe it begins with cell phones (because, as you pointed out, those seem to have a 2-year-max lifespan). Then it expands to include all mobile/hand-held devices.  By the time it reaches the computers and televisions, it is a tried-and-true program with all the bugs worked out.  All right, I'm finished :)

Great collaboration Andrew and just what is needed in the concepting phase. Not all concepts will reach the refinement phase so the more we can contribute to improve and expand concepts in the concepting phase the better.As for criticism I find most suggestions that indicate potential problems and directions for solutions are very welcome.Keep the comments coming - 'crowding' them in is what its all about.

comments.text: This is a great inventory. How much do you think you could get for selling the working stuff? Working items that are low value could be donated to local causes. The rest - you could just recycle it!It's hard to part with items we paid a lot for - but if we don't sell them on we could lose the value they do have.WRAP research (http://www.wrap.org.uk/content/value-re-using-household-waste-electrical-and-electronic-equipment) shows that old items thrown away by UK householders at recycling centres have a potential re-use value of over 200 million.

Thanks for sharing Ginny!My position is similar, if somewhat older.When I left the Australian Taxation Office after 15 years in ICT I determined to provide assistance to people with legacy systems.This was fine for about 12 months but quickly the pace of change outstripped my knowledge, my equipment and my capital.On top of this I like memorabilia - consequently I have 2 Microbees (that I shall not part with as they are the only authentic Australian designed and built personal computers ever made) but I also have:two cartridge drives,  286, 386 and 486 machines, 14,15 and 17 inch CRT monitors (the last still in use), 6 CRT televisions 3 of which are still working. Probably more than 1000 3.5 inch floppy discs, hundreds of 5.25 floppies, some software on cassette (for the Microbees) and even some 8 inch floppy discs.I'm glad now I was outbid on an A0 plotter about 10 years ago but at the time I was very disappointed.With Australia's haphazard recycling of e-waste if I do dispose of many of these I know most of it will end up in landfill.I totally agree with you, Meena and Ashley - and a solution is urgent A couple of weeks ago my sister-in-law wanted to replace her printer cartridges - the salesman easily convinced her that (at a price of $70) she was better off buying a new laser printer (at a price of $44). How can consumers resist such price differentials? Knowing my sister-in-law I am sure the servicable but cartridgeless printer is already occupying landfill.

Nice one on taking up the Get Active mission, Ginny! Telling isn't it?! We're looking forward to the connection that this helps us make to the notion that we are all part of this challenge and as we move on to the Concepting phase that perhaps we can all be part of the answer. Great solutions start with people-centered insights. Cheers for sharing.

Interesting insights Ginny. It sounds like you've hit on a clear pain point for consumers like you (and me, for sure) - what to do when something needs to be fixed and the easiest solution is to buy new. Seems like an opportunity area we can design for in Concepting later on!

comments.text: agree with Gail - many job opportunities here recycling are the jobs of the future !!! I really like the idea as this also fit in most big companies Sustainable strategies of managing the entire life cycle
Definitely agree, thanks Gwenaelle!

This is a fantastic idea, especially creating partnerships at a city level. The minor refinement I would recommend is to design the system with an incentive for the manufacturers to want to participate in the "take back" program, rather than legislating them to "have to". I know I always like to "get to" do things, than "have to". This is obviously much more easily said than done, but if the manufactures designed products with a similar style to the Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1, and the components could be transfered to next generation products, then when Joe looks to replace his HP computer, HP offers him a discount if he returns his old one. HP benefits by getting their valuable modular components back (which would be returned through the existing supply chain that brought the computer to Joe in the first place) and Joe saves some money on his next purchase. HP also keeps a loyal customer and the landfill misses out on all that valuable e-waste.
Thanks for the suggestion and update to the story! I think it is true that enforcement isn't always the best or easiest way. It would be great to have companies take the initiative on this concept!

There may be job creation opportunities for individuals and SME's here too.  Why not open up an avenue for people who might like to become and 'Agent' or 'Middleman' between the suppliers and the consumers.  They provide the drop-off points in cities to acquire the old electronics to look at fixing them for resale, use some of the components to fix other equipment, donate a percentage to disadvantaged communities/countries and then they deal directly with the original suppliers for the remaining components which are not able to be recycled.  This would mean that income is generated for the Agent and the supply companies may be more co-operative if they only have to organise collections from specific agents in cities rather than millions of packages arriving from all over the world. This may mean that wastage is minimised, supply companies only have to dispose of a measured amount of waste and agents may earn money.  Just some thoughts!  Like the idea :)

Some excellent suggestions Gail!T.Annie - I just suggested that the NYS design could be adapted to cover the broader range of WEEE and then form part of the basis of a marketing campaign utilising Mira Rao's concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/marketing-campaign-to-raise-awareness-and-provide-solutions#c-5a2e6ebb2eb64ec26cffbaf73afb91c4 ). Perhaps some collaboration on both concepts could enhance each of them. We could have a TIB campaign in which the intermediaries Gail has suggested could become TIB Partners.

T. Annie, nice find on the NYS design.  I love that it is using the already easily recognizable recycling triangle but incorporates the e-waste element.  It follows a very important rule for social change marketing -- keep it simple!  I'm going to incorporate this as an option for the marketing campaign.Thanks for the connection, Paul!

Gail - those are some fantastic ideas. The jobs that could be created for 'Agents' or 'Middlemen' between the suppliers and the consumers could even be turned directly into a "new market". If these SMEs started referbishing the devices and re-introducing them back into the market for the niche customers that don't need the newest devices. A mobile from 6 years ago makes calls just as well as a new smart phone, and I suspect there would be an entire market that is being overlooked, who wants a simple phone that only makes calls. The "agents" you recommend would be able to fill that opportunity and create jobs (while reducing waste).
Thanks for all the great ideas to make the concept even stronger! Great idea to collaborate on related concept too.

Great job on your Top 20 concept T. Annie! We're really excited about the idea that businesses can play a role in managing the life cycles of their products, even after they leave the factory or showroom floor. During Refinement, we encourage you to think about how we can help more companies understand the 'business case' of taking care of their electronic products. Since mandating this kind of behavior via government legislation can be difficult and slow-going, how might we inspire companies to see the financial or business benefits of helping consumers responsibly dispose of their devices after they've finished with them? For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/ewaste-top20 and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine(Note: We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!)

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

I was thinking a lot about that idea. But there is a big issue - it should be complex international model of cooperation. Because future computer parts are extracted in one contry they can be put together in other country, they will be sold on other continent and they might be recycled againe in other place(im hardly belive that they will do it in US of western Europe) or as worst scenario as usually they can be "kindly donated" to Ghana and become a pollutive e-waste there..

Hi Valentina, That's a great point and I agree it should be a bigger international effort! Right now it's difficult since every state in the U.S. has different laws (currently 20 states have laws have bans on electronic waste in landfills), however, parts and electronics are still be exported to other countries. I believe Federal law and restrictions on exports to put responsibility back on manufacturers. There are also different level enforcement in other countries, which should be stronger from government to citizen level. I believe things will change, but starting anywhere is a good start.

T. Annie you raise some very important points about what incentives there would be for companies to make their products repairable if they were required to be responsible for the total life of those products.I agree too that this is an international issue.Great thinking once again ladies.
Thanks Paul and Valentina for adding feedback!

comments.text: Great points here - it's interesting to think about production from the manufacturers' point of view. What are their goals? Speed is definitely one. Keeping costs low is definitely another. What else? I like thinking that tapping into these goals and motivations might help us design some great concepts later on!

I think it varies from company to company, but the rules of manufacturing are: Good, Fast or Cheap -- pick two.working with India and China, I believe it is cost (design -- its cheaper to put in a million plastic parts than one metal one -- cost of labor and manufacturing) speed (can this product make it ship-dates so that the cost doesn't skyrocket or miss its window of opportunity - eg: christmas toys, 4th of July blinky lights, release date)  And I think "Good"  manufacturing manifests as "pretty", "usable", "durable" -- replacement or parts re-use isn't really even in the picture.

comments.text: Great to see you include social business  a topic we learned about recently in another challenge http://bit.ly/grameen-brief  in your concept!

Thanks Ashley for your comment! I work at a consultancy firm in Brazil and we are now currently working on developing a e-waste logistic solution. We're benchmarking other countries and we found that many places are turning e-waste a business, but why don't it be a social business? In the landfills we've visited, we saw so many families catching up things on garbage to sell. Obviously with lack of minimum conditions of labor and health. I have not found a social business concept to the e-waste problem, but it fits so great that I couldn't miss the chance of discussing it here! Please guys build on this!

As Ashley says welcome to OpenIDEO and great to see you looking at this from a social business perspective. The link Ashley has given you is to an initiative in Colombia in part sponsored by Grameen Institute ( http://www.grameencreativelab.com/ ) who may have some perspectives on this and other similar initiatives.So far as I can determine, here in Australia, (with comparatively low volumes), the economics don't yet add up. I think this must be true of most other places too, since e-waste continues to flow into landfill. Whilst recyclers are happy to collect e-waste (and transport it) they are less likely to collect it if it is not free (even if they voluntarily put some profit back into the community). Ascribing value along the return chain would mean less profitability for those currently recycling and reprocessing.We need an economic model that will provide value to the original consumer (or collectors) and the recyclers. To do this we need some means to make e-waste more attractive as a resource than traditional sources of raw materials.I don't have any answers (and I'm not an economist) but some mechanism to generate demand for recycled materials would seem appropriate.

Hello Paul, thanks for adding! I have studied some e-waste business models, like in Ontario, Canada (http://www.ontarioelectronicstewardship.ca/), Japan (http://www.aeha.or.jp/) and Europe (http://www.erp-recycling.org/).We can see in all these cases that a legislation pressure (fines to manufactures, retailers and importers) and some fostering activities in the first leg of the reverse logistic make the business profitable. About economics, it is possible to see in all those cases that they turned into a profitable activity for recyclers - as manufactures, retailers and importers are responsible for paying the costs. The problem: if they have to pay, the consumer will pay (directly or indirectly).Here in Brazil we have some cases of companies that are earning money on recycling e-waste - but we also see that many of these companies are not doing it right. There is a huge difference between recycling 80% of a computer and then 20% of it goes to a eco-approved landfill, or recycling 98% of it and just 2% goes to disposal (recycling methods and efficiency). For the problem you said about giving value to the collectors (first leg reverse logistic) and then to the recycler (second leg logistic), as the business may be profitable for recyclers, they can pay (and so make a free market) to collectors. In Ontario, each collector receives a pre-defined amount for each ton of e-waste they deliver at recycling centers.The e-waste business model is possible, but I still think it could be more: it could be a cause-driven business!

Thanks for these insights Guilherme.Looking at the synergies that might come from building community (or social) collection services in conjunction with awareness initiatives like DFA's E-Cycle Trucks ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/e-cycle-truck/ ) and Carol Shu's Farmers (or community) markets booths and pop-ups - those sort of initiatives might increase viability of such social businesses too.

comments.text: Graham, I love this inspiration! It's so true. I've just been at an adventure bike weekend (Horizons Unlimited meet) and the most popular bike was definitely the Cub 90! People were giving talks of how they've been all over the world (literally) on them... durable, cheap to maintain, safe to ride and now a collectors item!

Thanks for your comments and for answering the questions! I think that vehicles and other machines (a watch is a great example) demonstrate that rugged can be cool, that durability and practicality are selling points for expensive items. A couple of other points:-- Ruggedness can also create feelings of sentimentality and attachment to the product. And of course the longer we own a product the more it becomes part of a story. -- A consumer's perception of a product's quality and of its longevity likely affects how that item is ultimately used, for how long, and in what way it is disposed.-- We generally have a perception of certain products' life cycles, such as vehicles. I am not sure I have an expectation about how long a smartphone or a laptop should last. I am sure that makes me more likely to throw away (or "recycle") a smartphone or laptop before its time (whether obsolete or broken/dead) than the likelihood of me getting rid of my motorbike.-- We would cut down on a lot of e-waste if consumers tried (even considered it a source of pride, like driving an old truck or motorbike) to get 2, 3, 4 more years out of their phones, televisions and computers.

Really nice provocations Graham! To answer your questions:1 - Definitely don't have an original mac, but I have gone through my fair share of computers2 - for some reason the first 'tech' product that comes to mind, that's also rugged or cool, is some sort of men's waterproof/sports watch. I can't think of a brand, but something really durable and sleek comes to mind.3 - in my experience laptops or phones last no more than 2 years4 - I've never even thought about handing down a tech product! comments.text: In conjunction with the recy-cool-ability concept proposed earlier, I think this is right on track. While we can't forcibly change people's minds, we can influence their decisions by providing them with relevant information.This e-label is very similar to eco labels devised by some of the clothing manufacturers to highlight the carbon and chemical impacts generated during clothing production. Not only are significant amounts of water used, but harsh chemicals are often not completely filtered before disposal.For communication, the simpler the better. When people scan packaging or lists, you only have a split second to catch their attention. A great example to use as a model is Timberland's "Green Index," which rates their products' production and waste footprint (no pun intended) only three things using a 10-point scale:1) Climate Impact2) Chemicals Used3) Resource ConsumptionA simple search for "Timberland" and "Green Index" yields plenty of great information about how they went through several iterations before they got the label right.

This structure is an easy way to start organizing group events.

Thanks for posting it!One question - did you foresee the 'nerds' in this network getting paid for their services, either by the customer, the coffeehouse, or some other entity?  Or is your theory that reducing e-waste, helping their community, and fixing things for fun would be strong enough incentives to recruit the network of nerds?Either model has potential, I'd just like to hear your thoughts on it.

comments.text: This is a great idea. WRAP research [www.wrap.org.uk/content/demonstration-using-recycled-content-uk-weee-plastics-electrical-products] shows that e-waste plastics can be closed-loop recycled into new high-value electronic products with a cost saving to the manufacturer. I'm really keen to see how this can be scaled up across Europe and the world. I think there's a great opportunity for brands to use the existing producer responsibility laws in the EU to extract this value from their existing e-waste processes.

Thank you for your comment.  We have world-scale plants in Austria and the UK largely because the EU has responsible recycling legislation, unlike the US.  And we are quite familiar with WRAP as well.  If you visit our website or see my TED talk, you will see that we are close-looping plastics from e-waste right back into new electronics, IT and appliances.  We are the world-leader at doing this.  http://www.ted.com/talks/mike_biddle.html  and www.mbapolymers.com

Great presentation Mike and welcome to OpenIDEO.Your company certainly seems to be at the forefront.- unfortunately the low speed of my internet connection prevents me from viewing the video but you explanation is comprehensive.Looking at your website -How (down) scalable is the process?I note that the Richmond facility is described as a small-scale production facility which (presumably) required up-scaling for viability.in the broader marketplace.Also some reports place the monomeric components in the category of hazardous carcinogens. This presumably requires specialised handling. Is it a further significant factor in resistance to the production of co-polymer materials in the USA, or is labour cost the other major limiting factor?Are the capacities quoted in the 'Plant Size and Capacity' paragraphs 'input' or 'output' capacities?

Thank you for you comments and questions.We are working on "down-scaling" the process with what we call "pre-processing" to upgrade waste streams. As you can probably imagine, we need large volumes to pay for large capital investments.  Monomers are usually not very much present, especially in recycled plastics due to multiple heat histories.  Not being in the US is a big frustration for me and Tom Friedman dedicated 3 pages to me and my company in his latest book, "That Used to Be Us", highlighting this issue - how other countries "get" CleanTech better than the US.  The US doesn't have take-back and responsible recycling legislation like Europe, Canada, Japan, S. Korea, Taiwan and even China and India (the last two are more recent).  Our capacities are quoted as "inputs" because output depends on the quality of our feedstock, which varies greatly.   Thanks again!

Thank you for the replies Mike and I echo the sentiments of Meena and Vincent.There was a serious purpose to my questions as I live in Australia and specifically in Tasmania, Australia's island state.On a world scale our market is obviously very small, although per capita is probably greater than most since, as a nation, we are early adopters. Hence my questions about down scaling and capacities.The cost of transporting e-waste out of Tasmania is greater than mainland operations, to the extent that a specific 3-day collection was co-ordinated earlier this year, apparently in order to make it economically viable. We don't have a formal take-back policy either but local councils attempt to re-cycle operational e-waste while those items that are not immediately re-saleable often continue to landfill.One of the barriers to re-processing of e-waste is a lack of public perception of its value (on several levels). The presence of active re-processing in a community (even a community as geographically large as a state) can generate support both conceptual and active.I would hope that even amongst a tiny populous (about half a million), a pre-processing operation might be worthwhile.I note the co-location of your production operations with complementary services, and in particular its proximity to your output market in China. If you can successfully establish small scale pre-processing closer to your input market that seems to make some sense to me.Whilst mainstream manufacture will probably continue to focus in places like China I would be interested to know what extent you see the emergent 3-D printing micro-manufacturing industry as a potential output market too.

comments.text: This is well outlined and really resonated. I've commiserated with countless people about how 'they don't make x like they used to.' Our environment is really suffering from the stripping for cheap temp products and so are we. Some thoughts to add are that we also have a culture of needing the latest gadget and apathy towards recycling to deal with as well.

Absolutely great points Laura. Thanks for your thoughts. I wonder what inspirations might point to what's working  especially, as you said, when it comes to needing the latest gadget or apathy towards recycling? I'm going to try to surface some examples we can learn from - maybe you can join me? :)

I agree, Annie Leonard is a great storyteller and manages to get the message and problem of e-waste across in very easy to understand terms for those who are unfamiliar with the issue.Though I would like to argue that most e-waste isn't merely an issue of things breaking down. Most electronics usually become obsolete and inefficient before their end-of-life at the rapid pace of technology development. I think one possible solution is to modularize technology so that cannibalizing parts is much easier. That in itself is a very difficult problem, but it's probably the one thing that would reduce e-waste the most. I'm specifically thinking of cables and chargers since you don't need a new one every time you buy one (other than the fact that each phone has a different plug), the function is the same, transferring a set voltage to the phone. We just need to standardize the ports. Much like how USB has become a standard data transfer format, we need one for energy/charging.

Jeffrey, this is a great thought, and I think electronics manufacturers would be open to it. It's exactly one of the things that European organizations and governments hav formalized with regard to cell phones. The Micro-USB is now the accepted standard for cell phone charging, eliminating the accumulation of incompatible, device-specific charging plugs. http://www.engadget.com/2010/12/29/european-standardization-bodies-formalize-micro-usb-cellphone-ch/
I've read it's supposed to go into full effect this year but I'm not sure if most companies have complied yet. As far as I know, Apple still uses their proprietary port.

When the news of the micro-usb standard came out in 2009, Fast Company discussed some of the anticipated problems of using the micro-usb as the standard. The article seems pretty spot on 3 years later: http://www.fastcompany.com/blog/kit-eaton/technomix/universal-phone-charger-standard-good-idea Also, without Apple it's not such a universal standard.

Hi Ashley! Sorry about the delay in getting back. If you'd like I would love to! I actually tried to dig up a bit more today to see what I could find and I'd look forward to your thoughts. The effects of behavior and attitudes on drop-off recycling activitieshttps://www.msu.edu/~lupi/Drop-off_recycle_Sidique-Lupi-Joshi_RCR_2010.pdfRecycling Success StoryBeaverton, Oregonhttp://www.epa.gov/osw/conserve/tools/localgov/success/beaverton.htmConsumer Electronics: Trends in Recycling (Podcast Transcript)http://www.epa.gov/osw/partnerships/plugin/podcasts/trends.htmnot sure about this one as it's a unique casehttp://www.army.mil/article/80844/Recycling_successes_shine_at_Fort_Hood/Cynthia hit good points about market forces that resonated with what I was finding too.
Interesting piece in wired by Kyle Wiens http://www.wired.com/gadgetlab/2012/06/apples-unfixable-devices/

Great video! The role of consumer market forces on production is an interesting and complex interchange of profit-chasing, benefits-analysis, and competition.What I didn't see addressed in this video--only skimmed--is the guiding role that big box retailers and superstores play in the flawed product design pathway. This animation seems to point the finger primarily at the product manufacturers themselves. However, so much of the disposable electronics design they create is dictated to them by their partner retailers (think Costco, WalMart, Target, Best Buy), who demand that they provide them with a continual stream of new products each quarter that they can market, which also must span a range of specified price points (ex: $500, $750, $1000, $1300). From the retailers perspective, what we consumers are demanding are new products that give us the latest technology at the lowest initial out-of-pocket cost. So, this means much of the design work comes from walking backwards into retailer marketing schema rather than a rational design plan to produce goods that serve human needs. Keeping up with the assembly line while maintaining a profit margin means that designers & manufacturers cut corners, swap internal components for the cheapest options, and compromise on aesthetics, green design, or usability.Our solutions should look at ways to educate consumers to demand well-made green products--not just cheap ones--that have longer lifespans. This means our electronics might cost more initially, but they'll be carefully designed for a better expandability in the long run, to keep up with changing technology, without feeding into our disposable culture or contributing to environmental decay.

Such fantastic insights Cynthia! I'm so glad you're onboard for the challenge and I look forward to thinking about some of your points as we move into Concepting later. In the meantime, I wonder if we can surface successful examples of consumers demanding a certain product quality or standard that has actually changed what and how producers and retailers sell to us? You've definitely got me thinking :)

Thanks Ashley! This is such a relevant challenge to our future economic activity, and its message is resonating with me on a personal level at the moment: I'm moving out of my apartment and am absolutely disgusted at the number of unused and obsolete electronics components, cables, and devices I've accumulated over the years! There must be a better way!Your question of finding examples is an interesting one that's worth doing a deep-dive on. I'm curious myself! So many corporate "green" initiatives are just marketing speak in disguise.Apple is one of the primary consumer electronics manufacturers leading industry discussion on electronics sustainability and environmental responsibility. They offer free e-recycling at their retail stores, have elevated minimal packaging to an artform, and charge consumers more money for (what they call) a more reliable product. While it's debatable how effective Apple has been in its actual practice, and there's no question that there's still a long way to go, I do appreciate that my 5-year-old Macbook still works like the day I bought it. http://www.apple.com/environment/

Great points about Apple  although I think sometimes this might be a 'beauty is in the eye of the beholder' question. Case in point: I was so frustrated when I recently upgraded to a new iPhone and they gave me a second set of ear buds and a new charger, even when my old set worked just fine. I even asked the sales associate if they'd keep the second set because I didn't need them, and he said no! Proof that every company has room for improvement :)
Indeed  will be interesting to consider how effective storytelling might be used to frame *solutions* when we dive into our upcoming Concepting phase!

comments.text: Ashley, I've personally tried to recycle electronics and it isn't easy. I had to find a place that would dismantle them, had to drive 20 miles, and then pay them to take it. One of the major factors limiting more electronics recycling is  economics. We have loads of supply, but no demand. Though commodity prices are rising, (thanks to inflation by the Fed), the labor costs in North America are prohibitive.

Great insights Scott. I completely agree that e-waste recycling isn't easy for consumers (definitely an opportunity area for our future concepts!). Regarding supply and demand, I also think you're right. It's expensive to recycle e-waste responsibly and also to manage it locally (versus shipping it overseas to be processed). I think that's one of the reasons why I was impressed by what Green Citizen is doing - they're creating a business model around doing the right thing *and* making money in the process.

Paul...good point. For all their advances in material considerations, when giants like Apple or HP (for years known for their planned obsolescence,) create products that can't be upgraded, the battle becomes more difficult. "You mean my two-year-old iPad can't take this year's software?"http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2012/jul/04/apple-ipad-software-updateCould a shell be produced, with an easily swappable internal technology drawer? Replace the ram, transistors, screen, etc, so that software doesnt have to dictate hardware?

We used to have slots for cards in PCs, some of us still do, so, as you say, why not make some features hot swappable on exchange. This could become a new industry for retailers - swapping out parts and then pooling the recyclable items for reprocessing.Sure the cost would rise but it would also grow the economy at the same time.

Here our municipal councils have an annual collection of household items too large to put into ordinary trash - some get refurbished and resold from the municipal depot and I think others go to recyclers (but we aren't told if this is the case). Of course this still means all the small items still get trashed.Sims is a worldwide recycling firm (originally just metal but now including e-waste) and I suspect they are the final repository for our material, they have a large but I guess unheralded presence in USA. As Scott points out the issue is demand - as Mike Biddle points out in his inspiration ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/inspiration/responsible-recycling-of-the-difficult-material-to-recycle-from-e-waste-plastics/ ) there is strong resistance to recycled material for input to manufacturing (despite improving cost advantages). In the case of plastics perhaps the demand can be improved through growth in the micro-manufacturing industry exemplified in 3D printing and modeling.Terracycle emphasizes upcycling (although the environmental movement would call it down-cycling) as a means of reusing some materials whereas companies like Mike Biddle's MBA Polymers look to true recycling.I absolutely agree it is a case of education being required but I think more than that we need a way to make it 'cool' to buy items that have a high percentage of recycled product. Perhaps some of the consumer electronics firms could offer locally customised casings for their products or better still personally designed 'skins'. In one of the other inspirations there was a suggestion for releasing parts designs for repair - maybe the purchase price of a new smart phone could include a choice of locally manufactured casings or the design to make your own.

Great catch, Ashley. I was reminded over the weekend how often people are keen to do the right thing but have no idea how to go about it. Two friends were talking about how they had old, functioning TVs and didn't know how to get rid of them. You can't take unfunctioning TVs to the landfill here either. Neither were keen to sell online & have just anyone come to their homes to pick them up. Your call to educate consumers might certainly help in cases like this.

Computer shuts down like an old television (that circular flash of white). After a a moment, the computer spits out an ID card that has the organ donor sticker on it... "Your computer is an organ donor.  Take it to the e-waste recycling center (or other recycling/reusing concept presented on OpenIDEO) and use his parts to help other sick computers." #eOrganDonorIt is based on Sana's concept of personalizing the device (the ID card in this ad could have a fun name and characature photo of the computer).That was just one idea.  What are your thoughts on something along those lines?

There are some interesting comments about sentimental attachment to computers and devices on our blog, I think most came from Asian design students - perhaps this is some kind of clue https://www.facebook.com/RestartProject/posts/268171449953570We would love to work with you on something like this campaign - we had some ideas that are similar, but more around commemorating and sharing moments in the lifecycle of devices. Naming is cool, could be the first event in the life of a gadget after purchase. People name their cars, right? While I think the idea of having people share or create a "network" of named gadgets, I think perhaps part of naming is about encouraging people to aesthetically customize their computers/phones, and promoting a sense of attachment from the beginning.And especially love the idea of "organ donation" for parts. :-)
Great stuff Janet! If you & Mira decide to work on something together in future  do drop us a line so we can share your story with our wider OpenIDEO community. We're excited at where it might lead!

Janet, I would love to work with you on this!  Sana Altaf's concept touches on the sentimental and humanistic attachment that the students described on your blog.  Check out her concept here: http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/meet-my-laptop-her-name-is-emma-slate/I love your idea of creating a network of named gadgets and devices.  It really touches on the basic human connection we seek while using these incredibly technologically sophisticated devices.  At the core, most of us want to feel connected to each other and the things in our lives that we touch, including our computers, ipods, televisions, etc.How do you see a campaign developing around the "Name Your Device" theme?  To me, it seems naturally fitted for a social media-focused effort.  What do you think?

Some toys have a tag with names already attached but others have a tag for you to give them a name.I agree that social media is a 'natural' for this type of campaign (despite my personal dislike of a number of present social media platforms).

Don't get me wrong, the 'tangible' and offline are really important here. I think an online effort alone would be tokenistic and not generate the attachment and real feeling. We are working on the assumption that our work online must be grounded in real community building offline! So, along these lines, naming and customizing, together, in person as often as possible - and then share that online. (For this it would be cool to link into the growing networking of maker and repairer groups around the world.)

Great refinements here too Mira!A little irony for me as one of the refinements for my 'penguin' concept was to set up a competition to name the penguins.The 'organ donation' analogy is great - with good positive positive words - healthy, life, renewal - all the good health associations on which to draw.'Naming' also reminds me that school folders often used to be personalised with favourite film stars, pop groups, etc. There might be an opportunity to co-market e-waste awareness utilising celebrity endorsement. Also things like phone, tablet and netbook sleeves.My younger son has a 'Crumpler' laptop bag - maybe manufacturers of these support accessories could offer personalised, named accessories.
Yes I agree Janet.Relying on social media alone would run the risk of simply being overlaid by the next viral or trending phenomenon.

Absolutely agree with the suggestion that social media alone is not enough.  I envision a multi-platform, multi-dimensional campaign (like the Designated Driver campaign) to really get people to change their minds and behavior.
Great call on partnering with folks like Crumpler Paul. Freitag could also be a good fit given their focus on recycling: http://www.freitag.ch/

Great concept Mira! I think this can work great as a part of a complete life cycle of a product.  Gauri posted a comment on my concept and she talks about the cremation of the devices which kind of got me thinking. Maybe along with the marketing a call of action can also be implemented to reinforce the behavior that the campaign is being designed for.

I'd love to delve more deeply into the call of action you mentioned in your comment.  I'd like to hear more about what that means to you and how you envision people/companies experiencing the message.

Hey Mira, great to hear from you! So I was thinking about this concept the other day and I agree with the steps that you have created.  These steps can easily become a part of your life.  And it got me thinking maybe when we talk about call for action while through your marketing campaign we can get people to start thinking about their behaviors towards their gadgets, but we also have to give them the alternatives.Let's say Roma has been using her cellphone for the past three years and its now at a point where the buttons are falling off, so she goes and buys a new one. But what if she was following your campaign and was aware of the e-waste problems, she would know what to do with her old cellphone.  Either she can donate it, or take it to Ashwin's "The Hacker's Cookbook - Refined! From the Cookbook to the Kitchen! By the OI Chapter @ NYU-Poly"So with a campaign try to provide users with easy, accessible solutions so they know how to have a better impact on environment :)

In Refinement, we encourage you to think about what aspects of this campaign you might be able to prototype now  a social media plan with a specific hashtag? Mock-ups of posters or stickers? And who would 'own' this campaign  an NGO, local governments, someone else? For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/ewaste-top20 and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine(Note: We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Just another thought - a 'named' device campaign would provide some opportunity to connect with the youngest generation and influence future thinking (even sans Penguins lol).

Great call Mira - I'm sure they are out there to help!

The 'pet' analogy (like tamagochi) would go down very well in some cultures too.

OpenIDEO prompted me to start thinking about who would 'own' the project.  I think that the government (EPA or other federal agency) would have ownership over the project and the brand, but would fund and empower local organizations (maybe a youth-run project as discussed in the youth unemployment challenge) to develop locally and regionally-specific programs.  So essentially there would be one "owner" of the campaign, but it would be largely designed (with brand guidelines) and implemented by hundreds of smaller NGOs or community-based programs.Thoughts about this?
Loving your notion of empowering local organisations here, Mira!

This is definitely not a one-size-fits-all solution.  Meena, I'm a little new to this, so I have a few questions -- How much more detailed should we get during the refinement phase?  Should I formally incorporate the discussion into the concept itself?  Does my concept need to be more specific, or can it be left open-ended.  Thanks!

The problem with leaving the ideas in the comments alone is that those evaluating my not notice the comments and rely on just what you have added to the body of the concept.

I like it a lot.  None of the other concepts really amount to too much if there's no awareness of the problem. A campaign that really points out the common sense in recycling/reusing electronics -- or that points out the real problem we have here -- should be what's necessary to transcend those political lines (so to speak).  I guess my point is this is exactly what is needed. :)

My apologies Mira I seem to have perpetuated a typographic error in spelling your name in a few places. I am correcting it in my concepts now.

What's great about the Energy Star system is its simplicity -- it could be useful to explore how your e-waste penguin system could be simplified even further.  As a consumer, we have so many choices as we navigate the shopping, selection, and purchasing process for our tech gadgets.  I would be hesitant to add too many levels of complexity the user may have to stumble over.I'm going to think about this a little more...

That in part is why I included things like single penguin with three stripes. don_t_debate_granulate_turning_e_waste_i.description: There is an unconventional and seemingly unexplored solution to managing the dilemma of non-biodegradable (and often, hardly reusable) e-waste. Pulverize it into a fine powder and mix that product with an epoxy resin, then shape it into bricks.
don_t_debate_granulate_turning_e_waste_i.creator: 1691f21c8eac0bac1060f5f6d77982b4

comments.text: Welcome to OpenIDEO Max and thanks for posting this as a concept!Several of the inspirations in the earlier phase explored this theme but its good to see it included in the concepting phase too.While I personally prefer the options to extract as much re-usable and toxic material first this is a sensible ultimate use for e-waste that cannot be processed in other ways (of which there is a great deal).I imagine the cost of setting up Super Granulators is still smaller than the cost of differential recycling so might be suited to processing of materials recovered from existing landfill.

Paul--thank you for your comment and I agree with you.  I think that the cost of establishing and maintaining some type of organized network of Super Granulators would indeed be less than that of initiating (and maintaining) a large-scale differential recycling infrastructure.  Additionally, I think that it would be particularly practical for recovering e-waste which has already been discarded into landfill sites.  Most of all, however, I think that the beauty in my idea is that it can coexist with others.  It is not so much a competitive strategy as it is a cooperative solution; I suppose that makes it a symbiotic answer to the e-waste dilemma in terms of synergistic problem-solving.  Cheers!

Hi Max! Thanks for your post! I was wondering if you have any info you could share on the likelihood that any of the components of e-waste (especially things like heavy metals that may be bad for humans and the environment) incorporated into building materials would leach out of the solid substrate? My hunch is that some materials would likely to be much safer than others and it would be interested to see how the safety properties line up with other important considerations like structural strength, cost etc.

Emily, very nice work!  You seem to know your stuff when it comes to material science!  I completely agree, I think that there are certain materials (particularly in older electronic devices) which could (and would) leech out of the substrate.  Undoubtedly, there is some nasty stuff in electronics, probably too much to list here.  Without going off on a tangent about PCBs, BPA and every other deadly three letter chemical acronym under the sun, I think that you make a very good point.  As I mentioned briefly in my concept, I think that there are certain items which would have to be exiled prior to granulation.  Mainly, I would think that batteries, coolant fluids (especially from computer heat sinks) and large aqueous capacitors (like those from older computer power supplies) could cause problems relating to the safety of the product generated by my proposed concept.  Then again, I think that this is indeed a dilemma which plagues the vast majority of e-waste recycling initiatives.  I suppose for my concept, it is especially pertinent because, as you have mentioned, the product being produced from my idea would be directly in-contact with people on a daily basis.  This undoubtedly propose an issue of public safety, domestic well-being and of course, liability if nothing were to be done to remove certain ingredients from the recipe.  At the same time, however, I do not necessarily think that removing the toxic substances from the mix is prohibitive to the concept.  I think that removal of toxic materials would be completely feasible.  Some of these chemicals could be neutralized in the (pre-resin) powder with the addition of liquids that could target specific compounds, bonding with them on contact (like sodium and chloride for instance--both of which are relatively nasty elements).  I know very little about hazardous materials recovery and management, but I should think that for at least some of the less-desirable chemicals which make it through to the powder (assuming there will be several), the proper combination of conventional and unconventional measures in sequential steps could really do a great deal for materials separation.  I don't have the expertise to really say what types of e-waste should be excluded from the granulation process.  What I can say is the rule-of-thumb that I use when bringing my haz-mat to my local facility: it seems that the more aqueous a substance is, the more likely (and more rapidly) it is to spread a dangerous amount of chemicals into a virgin area.  The way that I see it is this Metals (least concern)-->Plastics and Glues (medium)-->Liquids (highest).  I believe that both the FDA and CDC publicly list acceptable toxicity levels for certain substances, so it would be interesting to try my concept out with low, medium and high levels of care for haz-mat removal and then leave it in the elements for a while and see how it tests on the surface and in a controlled leeching area.  Thanks for your post!

Hi Maximilian, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

I should be able to upload a few images shortly.  I have beenexperimenting with some of my proposed theories on mixing epoxies and cements with Silica to see what types of rugged substances I can produce.  In my spare time, I recently took-up stone carving, which (depending on the rock being sculpted) produces fine-grade Silica powder, which I have been diligently accumulating.  This powder has been my test-subject for the past few days.  If I find an interesting combination of Silica and adhesive, I will post an image of the mixture and write a bit about it.  I can then grind-down a small chunk of an old motherboard and see if it acts similarly as a substitute for the stone-dust in the mix to test my theories.  Thanks for your comment!

Very interesting idea. Perhaps it would also be possible to create a product to replace ceramic tiles? With the granulated waste + resin replacing clay, and a coloured glaze on top? On the one hand getting the appearance right would be more challenging, but strength would be less of an issue.
Fascinating research and interesting suggestion Daniel.I wonder if reconstituted ABS might be a suitable binding agent, since it too is a recoverable product.

Daniel--I really like where you are going with the glaze idea.  I collect vintage cast iron cookware (of all things) which is generally known for its brightly-colored and long-lasting enameled coating.  I don't know too much about glazes myself, but I have several friends who are deeply involved and invested in the glass and ceramics industries, respectively and they might be able to offer me some words of wisdom on the matter as they have for some of my personal idea concepts and projects in the past.  I will have to do some more reading to find out what exactly constitutes a typical glaze to see how feasible this would be.  Off-hand, I would expect that it could be challenging to find a colorizing pigment that would have a broad enough melting range to provide a consistent color among different batches of the e-waste powder 'slurry'.  My thinking is that different batches of powder are going to have melting temperatures which vary widely, depending on the random things that went into those individual batches.  This could be problematic for colorizing pigments that have more sensitive temperature ranges because the pigments might not get hot enough in the kiln, or, in some cases, they might get too hot and lose all of their desirable properties.  It could be the centuries-old dilemma of overcooking the stuffing and under-cooking the turkey, or vise-versa.  Then again, I think that could be a problem with the powder itself too if it were heated rather than turned into a cement, so there will need to be some type of control over the different general categories of the powder if it is going to be altered chemically via melting.  I really like your idea though--it brings up a whole new layer of possibilities.

Hello Max, I really like your approach to the problem, and I fully support the solution you suggest here! By using the properties of materials of different parts of the devices, you actually do upgrade and you can create a profitable business out of it. As technology becomes cheaper, extracting working parts from broken devices and trying to re-use them is not a very long term, fast, or profitable way to move on.On the other hand, it would be great if you prepare a video where you narrate your thoughts because people, including me, using this platform are very busy people, and there are a lot of concepts to check:) According to me, this is more important than trying to find the right material to prove your idea at this moment.

comments.text: This I like very much because it assumes that as technology advances so quickly, certain things are destined to become outdated and need to be replaced. This makes sure there is somewhere for them to go. Credit/debit cards really make this possible so that you could lease a product for a period of years and pay up front or as you go and so that they can charge if you don't return. Another thing to consider is that if companies provide a good incentive for returning to them rather than reselling on ebay or something, they can also lease more "certified refurbished" versions for models that are slightly outdated but still functional for a discounted rate.

Keyphrase: "overlaying new methods over existing infrastructure" synthesizes nicely. It's like:1) Strategy=choice (Already late to the game) e.g. MSFT to limit new tablet sales to its own (few) retails stores.2) Kodax tried to do new things with familiar competencies! rather than doing truly new things.

Hey Arash! Congratulation for having such a good start. I totally agree to your idea. I think that for E Waste management it's the manufacturers and designers who should be taking the major steps. Your idea communicates that completely.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Welcome Arash and great thinking.How do we progress such business models and their products to compete in the existing market place?Apart from the environmental benefit (which so far has not proved sufficient in itself) what can we offer to the consumer?Here (in Australia) we have hire firms that provide the consumer with exchangeable/upgradeable items and the used items enter the secondary market or the waste stream. I'm sure similar firms exist everywhere - could they be leveraged somehow to shift the focus from consumer ownership of hardware to purchase of utility?Can it be regulated?Can we regulate the innovation process or will it be self limiting?The current life of laptop technology (what it does, rather than what it looks like) is just below 2 years. Ten years ago lifespan was about 5 years. Some in my generation have grown up with the adaptability of desktop computers - undertaking hardware upgrades while retaining cases, keyboards, mice etc. This was great until manufacturers began playing with form-factors, CPU slots on motherboards etc. in order to enforce proprietary use of some components. Would love to see the old 'freedom' return in the DIY marketplace.

Paul, it seems it keeps coming back to this same theme. The idea that form factors really only change in terms of fashion statements and not new functionality. If we could remove electronics from fashion, people wouldn't lust after new designs, just new components.

Paul,I believe the products and businesses would be regulated on the same level as automotive guarantees are. When you lease (or purchase) a car, it generally comes with some sort of a warranty for let's say 100,000 miles. We could extend this model to all electronic goods. You purchase a 2 year license on a new TV for example and the manufacturer will service it within those 2 years you are under contract. Your TV breaks, you bring it back to the manufacturer and get a new one. Your old TV goes back into the waste stream and its usable, functioning parts (which in most cases will be over 90% of the product) go into new TV's. The manufacturer can even offer the same insurance plans that already exist to cover the cost of accidents where the consumer is at fault. This way companies can compete and differentiate themselves on price, innovation and this new model of service. Robert,Although it could be cool to remove the lust out of design and the conspicuous consumption of fashionable electronics, I just don't think that is a realistic expectation. Great design and ease of use is one of the biggest reasons why Apple has been demolishing Microsoft over the past couple of years. There is something inherently geeky and technical about lusting over new components and upgrades and I don't think most consumer will buy very much into keeping up with that. Just because electronics have entered into every aspect of our life doesn't mean that the average consumer is invested on how they work on the inside. They just want something that looks nice and works when they want it to.

Arash,Agreed. While I wish we could stop viewing them as fashion accessories it's a pipe dream. When the iPhone 4S was announced it had upgraded internals and great new software features but the body was the same. It still sold well, but people didn't like the lack of an industrial design update. So i agree, calling for an end to case design updates may not be the right approach. In my post, I was thinking that you could design devices so that the internals could be transplanted to a new case. I originally thought of this as a way to deal with damaged cases, but easily it could apply to sleek new looks.

Yes I have to agree that the fashion cat is out of the bag. More's the pity, but I come from a generation where fashion in electronics was (and is) of little interest.Can I ask how effective existing warranties and insurance are in  the US both for cars and electronics?My experience here in Australia is that most retailers and insurance companies who carry the warranties (rather than the manufacturer) are strongly resistant to honoring them. However I acknowledge that it is coloured by the (low) residual value of the item. I don't know what the market is like in the US but the resale value of a new vehicle here drops by between $5000 and $10000 within a week of purchase. Computers are proportionately similar.

As for warranties, my current (and first) computer is a MacBook Pro from Apple. Their warranty is great (especially when you buy the extended version). I started experiencing Kernel Panics (mac's blue screen of death) about 2 years after purchase and they replaced the entire logic board for free. Now that it's out of warranty, I've done some self repair, but the one time I went in to ask about something the technician gave me a free part and said that if you ask the right way you can always get discounts on repairs from them, even after warranty. Similar experience with the iPhone warranty.As for depreciation, it always varies from item to item. If I wanted to sell my iPhone today (which I paid $200 for) I would get less than half if it was damaged but almost full price for a mint one. I sold a used PS3 a year after I purchased it for more than I had spent (it had a feature sony later removed so this is a special case). The general trend is rapid depreciation though.
Welcome onboard, Arash! A bold start and we're excited about collaborative conversations around the seeds you've planted here.

Arash, I totally agree with you. I guess the most sustainable way to revert the e-waste problem is changing the way designers and producers think when they first start having ideas about a new product. Worrying about the entire product's life is really something we must start doing now. Yes, it requires new business models to support the whole chain. But the sooner we start, the smaller will be the damage. Many thanks for your contribution, that's really nice!! And welcome to Open IDEO :)

Hi Arash, welcome!Check out the inspirations, there have been a lot of ideas been shared about that - it seems, that there might be a stable base of designers, who think like you. You've got a great example there, I totally believe in the cradle-to-cradle process.This process allows - absolutely - to actually live your lust, but also add good conscience. On the business side it makes more sense, too. You get to keep more of the resources you once paid for, and you create a club of users, who is trusting your products. Makes business more sustainable on every level - as you already pointed out, as well.

Hi Arash! I'm also pretty new (first post only a few days ago). I like your thinking. A major part of the change needs to come from the design phase. I like the idea for a business model that is focused on returning the machine (or parts of it) to get new functionality. I touched on this in my concept "Stop outmoding and start upgrading" where I proposed a business model based on manufacturing, servicing and upgrading the machines to extend the lifecycle indefinitely. Maybe the consumer electronics industry will start to resemble the automotive leasing structure. With things like 'scheduled maintenance' being replaced with 'scheduled upgrades.'
