Hi Ashwin,very nice concept and I think you are pointing to 2 important issues:- a trend to keep changing our devices (which is supported by the technology industry) which tend to be overpowered- the shift from a product to a service mindsetCloud computing as you present can indeed offer a solution to both.Yet, as noted by Paul and Lluis in their comments (and as you also highlighted it), there is also a need to reassure people. I'm wondering if Lei's concept in the Amnesty Challenge could not be a way to address this: http://www.openideo.com/open/amnesty/concepting/decentralize-the-network-own-and-protect-your-data/I personally tend to be like your mum, keeping all my pictures on my laptop and Iphone. Yet, recently I downloaded all my pictures from my iphone to dropbox (prompted by dropbox)... I'm wondering if based on the 2 scenarios, you could not develop your challenge a bit more and think about specific options...

Hello Professor, I'm actually trying to come up with more scenarios, I just posted one more as a comment. What you say is right, the most important part is to reassure people. In a way,it's already begun because a lot of our data already exists on "the cloud".

Hi Ashwin,I like the kindle fire scenario. I think that it would be great to focus on the 2 contexts: the IT / company example and the individual story (your mother example) and show how some of the current services / devices can support the storing of data. Maybe the core of the concept is then to think about how to educate people and prompt them to use cloud computing.

I am in agreement AL.Continual reassurance is as essential to the success of remote data storage (whether you call it the cloud or your accountant's server) as it is to the care taking of money by banks and other financial institutions.Lei's distributed network is a great example of steps towards making  some remote data storage more secure. In the Amnesty challenge we focused, largely, on lack of trust between individuals or minority groups and governments (or particular arms of government). Now we have an increasing lack of trust in business at various levels and in particular those manipulating social networking data. Whether this is well founded or not it is the perception regulates behavior. Unfortunately frequent perceived breaches of trust keep this issue 'on the boil' .It will be interesting to see, in a few years, if a 'unique' selling point develops in some quarters predicated on avoidance of the cloud.Interesting times.I'm sorry I am somewhat "off the track" as far as combating e-waste is concerned - just interesting points to debate.

Here's a scenario from a currently existing product actually: The Amazon Kindle Fire. It's tiny, slim, light, cheap, doesn't take up much resources. It also has a browser called Silk. Except it isn't a traditional browser, it's only an interface. What Silk does is runs subsystems like page rendering and HTMl remotely on the Amazon EC2 cloud servers (using split architecture and Google's SPDY protocols). This means that you don't need to hold the physical infrastructure in your hand. So that's less of a product to begin with. Then, there's also no need to update your device as processing and memory can theoretically approach infinity, it's pay as you use. So if devices aren't outdated, there's no reason to buy a new one, thus reducing e-waste. Check this video out: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_u7F_56WhHk&feature=player_embedded

This is an interesting example Ashwin and illustrates the tension between platform dependence and freedom of choice. This tension will always be there (thank goodness) as a hedge against market dominance.

Interesting Ashwin. As you say convincing us (including me) of the benefits of entrusting valued information to the cloud is a tall order. Yes I use Google services but these days anything I really want to keep (or keep private) I still store in at least one personally accessible place offline. But then I avoid Facebook too.

There is certainly data we all want to keep with us and data that we just want it to be private in its full extent. Imagine for instance what would happen if linkedin all of sudden shut down and we could not export our network contacts! I believe there's still some way ahead to go in the cloud computing space, but it is certainly a great service which empowers ourselves and reduces the need for private resources (therefore e-Waste). I do avoid Facebook as well ;-)

I admit to being on Linkedin too (but rather tentatively).Part of my initial response was prompted by wondering what happened to information in MySpace and by drawing (mental) comparisons with financial institutions. I can see advantages to using the cloud for things like the songs and videos etc. and for things like the shared documentation that would be involved in something like the "LawMaster" concept from the EU entrepreneur challenge.

A lot of confusion exists between Privacy and Security. Privacy and Security have distinct features, Privacy is the what and Security is the How. Security is a requirement for privacy and not vice versa. Privacy is not a subset of Security and Securitys primary purpose is to protect privacy. Most often, privacy is confused for security to voice concerns with cloud computing. While security can be assured by conducting due diligence, privacy is assured by the careful drafting of the SLA contracts. It's our duty to protect our own privacy.

Ashwin, you are right to make the distinction. That is precisely why I personally, and on behalf of my clients, am circumspect in my use of the cloud which, of course, has really been with us since the introduction of the internet.

Thanks Ashwin, great read! Addressing the issue of overpowered devices I think is a direction to take for companies to integrate 'responsible design practices' and contribute to building less needless 'resource intensive' devices, therefore diminishing the e-waste problem. I have actually worked for a PC manufacturer re-inventing the PC line of products, and carried out some empathic research with consumer at their homes in different countries. And I cannot agree more on the fact that there are many features offered today that are not really necessary for the use consumers give to PCs / laptops at home. However the industry comes from a past where the tech game is understood as a selling advantage point, and we found that is not so easy for a manufacturer to open to a new mindset, to another type of competition game (changing the game requires a bit of braveness). This was back in 2008. Today we are seeing that many of the 'light designs' originally manufactured thinking of the developing world market are successfully being sold in developed countries. It seems that we are gradually moving there. And as you introduce, Cloud Computing is another interesting design tool to be considered for reducing resource needs.

Exactly LLuis, I feel that devices aren't as designed these days as they are just following Moore's law and becoming smaller and more powerful. As Clayton M Christensen predicted, we're caught in a technological mudslide that will disrupted when products come out that addresses the actual needs of most people in the world. Cloud computing is just an enabler to shift to a service economy where memory and processing are ubiquitously allocated through the network based on needs rather than pumping out millions of devices each year and dumping them immediately afterwards.

Well, actually, the cloud is more secure than storing data on-center. I can walk into a university's server room and have access to the physical mainframe. But with large companies owning data-centers, they maintain and secure it physically. The VP of CA technologies spoke of server farms that are middle of Arizona, protected by a 12 foot fence, attack dogs and watchtowers with armed guards. The data itself is encrypted, distributed and backed up by redundancies. With the NIST standardizing the technology and ETSI regulating the SLA contracts and documentation, we are fast approaching cloud as the next standard rather than an option. The cloud is not only for storing data, but also processing it. With a lattice-based fully homomorphic encryption scheme, you can encrypt the data before sending the packets, having it processed on rented infrastructure and platforms, still encrypted before receiving and decrypting the ciphertext in-house. Thus, you send, process and receive gibberish that no one can mis-appropriate.
Great to read a couple of user cases for this idea, Ashwin  including that of your mom!

Thanks for the thought-provoking questions, Graham.- Extra rewards beyond lifecycle: Interesting point! My idea was to keep the program simple so anyone could easily understand what it is. Maybe a modification could be done to allow the slow adopters to sell their extra credits on eBay (I could actually see this happening)?- Calculation of expected lifecycle: I guess it's similar to the minimum fuel requirement in that the consumers should be able to replace the electronics when it's reasonably worn out - no need to wait until the device completely crashed :). I would say it would be something around 80% of the average duration of a product life under normal wear and tear circumstances.- Warranty: the company would have to replace the device and take on the enterprise penalty on green deposit.If you have further comments, I'd love to hear them!

Fantastic concept and great practical discussion around it.Can we extend this to the full range of WEEE?Presumably retailers or manufacturers collect the deposit as part of the purchase price - where does the money go from there and who administers it?I don't know the proportions between private and corporate ownership of electrical and electronic devices but would be good to have this apply to corporate ownership as well as individuals.I especially like Grahams suggestion of extended lifespan which might, in part, be funded by those who 'can't wait'.Having done a quick, back of envelope calculation on the value of WEEE as recycled product it works out to be about $1 per kilo (50c per lb) of whatever you discard (that is profit to the recycler with no return to the consumer). This concept places an appreciating value on the product, at least over its notionally useful life.

Marie, to your point about the calculation of expected lifecycle: One thing to consider is that over time there would need to be an increase in the expected lifecycle of products. How could your idea help to push ever increasing expectations for the length of time that consumers hold on to products?This idea made me think of something like a "cap-and-trade" system for e-waste producers. The government could set a minimum life expectancy target for particular categories of devices with penalties for failure to meet targets (and rewards for those that exceed targets).  That's to say that your idea could be applied at both the consumer and production sides.I look forward to your responses to Paul's questions. Good luck developing this interesting idea!

Good points Graham - I mentioned cap and trade in another concept recently but for the moment can't remember which one - it was floated in the inspiration phase.Another question which applies to some other concepts too is - what happens to items passed on either gifted or sold for others to extend their life. My son bought an ordinary cell phone to use while his I-phone was being repaired - then passed it on to me to replace my broken flip-phone.Sorry to raise complicating issues - will try to work through possible solutions too - I guess that's the essence of collaborative development.

Hi Paul and Graham,You posed some interesting questions on how the credit would be transferred through subsequent ownership of the devices. Hmmm... does the credit come with the electronics, or could your son keep the credit and only gift you the device? How would the devices and associated credits be tracked - through a universal database of all IMEI and serial numbers out there in the market?Once the green deposit becomes a mandatory program, I could also see a good potential for a secondary market for trading these green credits.

Great to see this make the Top 20 Marie!On reflection I think credit remains with the purchaser initially, unless the person receiving it as a gift is also registered for credit.If a person becomes registered for credit (through purchase) then a secondary market can be established where both device and credit can be transferred either as gift or for consideration. This could effectively produce the 'cap and trade' system suggested in one of the inspirations.There are other concepts that would benefit from the kind of database that you propose, e.g. Joe Lee's 'Mint for E-Waste)( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/mint-for-e-waste-management-what-s-my-electronic-footprint/ ) and possibly Fabio Calsavara's Recycling Network ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/the-recycling-network/ ).

Talking of The Recycling Network I think these two concepts are compatible and complimentary - this one potentially extends product life whereas Fabio's look to reward the recycling process too. There could be a 'final' credit only available on recycling with purchasers/owners eligible for this whenever the product is recycled, but if the product is recycled 'early' then the other credits are lost.One thing that might be necessary is for OEM's to provide a 'transferrable' warranty for the lifetime of the product not just 12 months - this might help to encourage them to design products with 'realistic' lifetimes.I can also see this concept being complimentary to Robert Caruso's Deposit Program too( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/encourage-consumers-to-bring-back-electronics-with-a-deposit-program./ )- they could simply be applied at different price points.Both concepts could be applied across the full range of e-waste including electrical products like hair dryers and fridges.If the database is created (based on product/serial number or similar unique identifier) the Recycling Network could be used to monitor extended use through Hacker's Kitchen and Rewire.com too.

Great discussions here, Marie! If there are folks from the OpenIDEO community who have helped to shape any Refinement phase updates for your concept  you might like to add them to your Virtual Team field. You can add names there or make any updates to your idea by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right of your post.

Congrats on your Top 20 concept Marie! We really liked your take on a deposit program to encourage people to hold on to what they own. During Refinement, you might want to think about how you'd message this to consumers to get them to buy into it  maybe there's a social media/gaming element to add some friendly competition among social groups to see who can own their devices the longest? Also, you've done a great job outlining the stakeholders involved  but who might actually pay for the creation of this program? For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/ewaste-top20 and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine(Note: We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!)

I love the idea of creatively and somewhat playfully slowing down the pace of consumption! That's awesome! And all the people who previously jokingly complained about and occasionally apologized for how old their technology is, would suddenly be turned into role models and resilient little heroes. And get rewarded!Plus, the costs for the incentive would be fairly minimal. Of course the manufacturers would probably suffer to some degree, but they would have to cope with it competitively and would be encouraged to produce longer lasting technology  all of which is great for the society as well as for the environment. Great concept, Marie!

Thanks, Hannes.Yes, considering the recent multi-billion dollar lawsuits among tech manufacturers, I could see them complaining about reduced profits. I think that's why government intervention is needed. The slow pace of consumption might in fact help these companies focus on genuine innovation, and longer lasting technologies, as you mentioned, rather than on cranking out new products every quarter.

This actually meshes very well with Sabine Kuznik's Pure-Tech concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/slow-tech/ ) which grew out of thinking about the 'Slow-Food' phenomenon. You might like to add her to your virtual team and compare notes. If you think some of the ideas in her concept are relevant you might like to link the two using the 'built on' process.

Hi Marie, great thoughts! I like your idea of having the overview and tracking how long you use your devices. As Paul already wrote I suggested a labeling of long-lasting electronic products. I think this matches very well with your concept. Thank you Paul, for bringing this concepts together.

Yes, Sabine. I like your "Pure Tech" label (it looks as if you settled at "Trusty Tech" now. They both sound great) - giving it to participating tech companies & their products. Btw, how do you use the "built on" process?

Hi Marie, thank you for your great feedback. Which one would be your favorite name? When I create a concept and find existing concepts where my concept is build on, I drag-and-drop these concepts from my bookmarks in the concept description. Then you can visualize them in the collaboration map. You also can include concepts afterwards using the "update entry" button on the top right side.

It's great to watch concepts emerge independently or out of inspirations and other concepts then see them fit back together as integrated parts of a comprehensive solution - and even better fun to participate in the process.

Hi Marie,Building on a discussion with Paul Reader, I just had an idea for some add-on to your suggestion of a mobile 'Green Deposit Tracker' app. What if it not only kept track of your 'Green Deposit', but also of the device's current resell and recycle value at any given time? Such an app could come pre-installed on every mobile device, regularly gather 'real-time' data through the Internet and thus inform the owner of the phone's actual value. On the one hand knowing that value might allure owners from buying yet a new device, I think. On the other, it could encourage them to actually resell, recycle or donate their old phone in the case that they actually decide to buy a new device nevertheless...I remember several people/concepts here suggesting some kind of mobile app or other. Apps that let you know how to recycle a phone, where the closest collecting point is etc.Maybe we should simply connect all those suggestions to one ingenious pre-installed green meta-application, with a highly recognizable green icon/logo of course. Wouldn't it be great if that could be implemented by law in any mobile device whatsoever?

Hm, I have been trying for a moment to come up with a name... Not easy. Maybe 'Screen Green'? Or rather 'Green Screen', in spite of the ambiguity then? Or maybe something less playful, since the app would need to come across a bit more seriously?

Ah! Another integrator - good thinking Hannes - I agree that some of the suggested apps/websites (I included websites coz I don't have a smartphone) could hang off a single interface.That was my thinking in creating recycoolable.org as part of the labeling concept (that some people are now just calling my 'Penguin idea') - largely as a portal to other information (one side for the next generation:the kids and one for the current generation:the adults)As for the naming - its great fun to play with the words - and generate things that catch the imagination - I'm still thinking along the lines of integration with your suggestion for Sabine's (Trusty Tech) branding.
In relation to the 'real-time' pricing how would we achieve this beyond the US market (which is obviously the largest)?

Well maybe getting it started nationwide in the US (or even just in one state) would already be a great first step, and could then become a model for additional/wider markets. (Of course, the bigger the project, the easier would it be to actually establish the pre-installation requirement.)
Oh, and I just checked out your 'Penguin Project'! Good job! :) Will comment over there about one or two small ideas it made me come up with.

You are right about the 'pricing' and the question (as with others) is intended to extend our joint thinking.Looking at the car market again here we have red and green book prices for used vehicles (I think the two differ only really in who produces them). Whilst this might not happen for cell phones I can see a marketable value emerging for other items.

Hannes and Paul, I love how you integrated and built upon the concept into a comprehensive pre-installed meta-application! As for the resell value, the app could aggregate pricing data from participating second-hand electronics sites and provide real-time info on average or best pricing with links to those actual sites (these referral fees from user click-throughs could be put back into the campaign fund). Unlike retailers/wireless carriers, most major manufacturers have global presence, so the job of pre-installation outside of the US would be much easier if the OEMs participate. One caveat is, however, that out of the two groups of decision makers, the OEMs would have less of an incentive to support this campaign. So the guiding force should really come from the "people - the consumer groups", who would push these manufacturers to support the cause. I guess this makes the importance of what Phil Suh points out in the above comment about the social aspect more pronounced.

Yes, and never underestimate the social aspect.  You could aggregate data by green groups to see how a group of people are doing.  You could either create your own groups, import them from google+ circles or Facebook groups, or use standard ones like a school campus or a city.  Members could see how they are doing compared to other groups as well.  Also, a feature could also be to set up green drives where teams compete to sign up people to grow their green credit pool.  Winners could be awarded extra credits. Those credits (in addition to others in the pool) could be used for stuff (from retailers or other merchants), or to donate to worthy causes.

Thanks for pointing out the importance of the social aspect, Phil. I love your ideas here and could even see them serving as a basis for a grassroots campaign that starts from a Facebook group growing into a campus-wide initiative that spreads to other campuses until it eventually reaches the legislators.Building on your idea about the social groups, they could create an unofficial version of the green deposit system, where the members would voluntarily pay green deposits to be used as the campaign seed fund, while pledging their advocacy in reducing e-waste through responsible consumption of electronic devices. The green drive could be a used to spread this idea to a campus or city and ensure that this is a community experience.Your further feedback would be appreciated!
Great thoughts on creating positive status from green behaviour, Marie!
Thank you, Meena.

comments.text: Inspiring thoughts about both redistribution and raising awareness. Plus loving your dual pilot suggestion. Looking forward to input from others here and watching this idea grow!

thanks, Meena! I hope the dual pilot idea can be refined a little... one thing I'm thinking about now is how much interaction there should be between donors and adopters, and whether a relationship aspect could convince people to engage more with the educational campaign...

The dual pilot is a very strong idea, especially the opportunity to compare the trials in San Francisco against those in Rio de Janeiro. Would you be looking to run identical pilots, or would they serve as platforms to trial opposing ideas against eachother?The relationship between donors and adopters will likely be the primary driving force for people to engage with the educational campaign. In addition to the donor/adopter relationship identifying additional stakeholder relationships (ie. donors/schools, adoptors/social media, donors/retailers)could really help this reach a critical mass.

Congrats on making the Refinement phase Top 20 shortlist! Cheers on this fun and cross-cultural concept A.M.! We love the idea that our devices have a story, much like a pet, and the connection between donor and adopter to tell a story of an electronic device's life. During Refinement, we'd love for you to think through what it would take for consumers to sign up and use a program like this? You might even want to draw up some sketches of what this website would look like! For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/ewaste-top20 and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine(Note: We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Thanks so much! Hand Me Down team: welcome to the top 20, guys!! Things to figure out now are:--user experience for the website platform--country specific incentive structures to get people to enroll in the program (USA, Brazil). More updates to come soon, let's brainstorm! Seeking feedback as well as any visualizations of a website scheme... I'll submit some concept sketches soon. x

Nice idea which indeed is very much aligned with Sana's concept.It also reminded me of Aswhin's concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/the-hacker-s-cookbook-to-be-updated../Maybe there could be a way of connecting the 2. While I can see the motivation for the donors, I'm not sure about the motivation for the adopters. I'm not really sure about the learning part and the essay writing and how you can motivate people to do this. You could focus on the donors/ adopters program and then rather having people writing essays, you could imagine to have people posting tips, stories or "recipes".

What do you think about letting people re-sell their device? It seems part of the diplomacy of trans-national hand me downs could involve creating economies that participate with real market share. In Kiva and micro-financing, financial independence motivates adopters while "robin-hooding" and redistributing wealth motivates donors. But I really love the educational component and the not "selling out" of "giving". Would love hearing more about the value of not re-selling so as not to conflict with consumers' authentic values?

Thanks for linking Ashwin's concept Anne, that's really interesting... I love the idea of recycling as recreation. Thanks also for the insight re: different types of sharing in terms of stories vs. recipes. The issue I see with the Hacker's Cookbook, similar to Hand Me Down's, is how to recruit a good cohort of committed users. Hmmm so how can we hook people?

Good point! I agree that getting a group of committed users is crucial. I guess that comes from creating awareness, a user-friendly platform and recruiting passionate, self-motivated users ... such as openIDEATORS or people writing entries on wikipedia... I will therefore start with a small core group, an open source platform.Once you have enough good content, you can then create a campaign to develop awareness among a second set of users who will not necessarily add recipes but will be willing to use them.Does that make sense?

Jenny thanks for such a great comment-- I think you've raised an important issue, namely that it's important to have a clear idea of value vs. money (and the difference between the two) in this concept. I would love to flesh this out further, I think your thoughts are helping the way I think about this.I might take some time and try to map out the whole system with value vs. money columns. Beyond the electronics themselves, things of value I see in this experience are human connection, public "brownie points," and feelings of altruism..One thought: How much is the extra $100-500 worth to a person of affluence? Is it worth the hassle of finding a buyer or the potential stress of even thinking about money? I feel many people shove their electronics off on younger siblings or friends to avoid this.Do you think I'm thinking in the right direction here? x

Awesome!! I love the idea of getting good content hosted on a pilot website before opening it up to attract more users with a larger publicity campaign. Perhaps there could be some reward for those early adopters based on their enthusiasm. That's really smart to think of getting the actual users to generate website content, huge potential... I wonder if there are any existing services that use this idea? (Wikipedia was a nice thought-- anything more niche?) I'm trying to think...

What a neat concept! I really love the idea of developing a "life-story" of the devices that are handed down through the platform. I think this really speaks to the emotional connection that many consumers develop with the electronics that are increasingly an ever present part of our lives. Accompanying the donation with a story seems as though it'll really enrich the process for donor and adopter alike!Similar to Anne-Laure, I'd be really curious to learn more about how you'll motivate adopters to apply for the program. I foresee one potential limiting factor in the scale of the program being the number of adopters willing to go through the application process. The potential of receiving heavily discounted electronics might be reason enough to apply, but I'm interested in learning more about your plan to recruit adopters as the concept develops!

Thanks so much for the comment Marina-- I think you're absolutely right about the bottleneck on the application process, great point. As is, it would also require quite a lot of time for someone to oversee that process, which might not be feasible... hmm.Thanks also for the insight into strengthening the recruitment strategy for adopters, we'll have to make sure not to overlook that.Glad that the storying component is sounding good to people so far, it seems like the roughest issues are these incentive structures... sounds like we should map these out more!

First, I like your concept of an exchange uniting people together but I have several questions:Why did you decide to have the donors (as opposed to the adopters) pay? Do you foresee any aversion to having people pay a fee in order to donate a device?Would your concept be comparable to donating the electronic device to a charity for of tax/accounting purposes?

Hi Andreas, thanks for the feedback. The original thought of getting donors to pay was to market it as a placement service and try to get electronics owners to pay for the social value of this service (eg. attention from friends or peers and a feeling of altruism or human connection). However, I feel this is clearly best suited to a wealthy electronics owning population. What do you think? Is that feasible or too limiting?I worry that without this strategy, it would be too easy to look at continued engagement with the platform as a hassle-- eg. in my mind: "I'm donating my computer, isn't that enough? Why do I have to go do something on a website, I feel exploited or undervalued instead of interested and curious"The thought is that with the right incentives, this could turn into "I paid to have something cool happen to my old computer. I wonder what happened to it..."The electronics donor will no doubt experience the feeling of charitable giving at some point in the process-- the trick is how to maintain this feeling long enough to promote more in depth interaction...What do you think? xx

Thank you, that's fabulous!

comments.text: Sure seems like an interesting *track* to explore, Rob!
Thanks!

Boom! This is great, I like how the tracking can lead to more responsibility, like if a cell phone company sold 30,000 of one type of phone but only 1,000 were recycled then diagnosing markets for e-waste recyclers to move into would be easy.  Also Im sure recyclers would appreciate the information on their BOMs (Bill of Materials)
Thanks!

I was just thinking about this idea myself, until I saw that you put it up already. :)My only suggestion here is to flesh out the "track waste stream" particulars. Having a passive RFID would allow the detection of an e-waste product within a bag of trash, allowing the waste company to separate it from the other trash and then filter out the e-waste for recycling. You could even have the detection of e-waste be done at the curbside, before the trash is even collected.Moreover, passive RFIDs are so cheap now that they can be attached to anything--even single disposable batteries. I like your innovation in how the RFID would contain information about the product to help recycling.

When I was thinking about this concept I was  focused on using the RFIDs once the device was in the hands of a recycler to track and provide better info about each device to ensure they get where they need to go. Using them to salvage landfilled devices opens up whole new doors! Thanks for the suggestion!

Hi Rob, I think this is an intriguing concept. I guess one question I have is how much resources, energy, virtual water, etc. are used to manufacture the tag and if every electronic device had one, would the environmental impact of the tag itself outweigh the benefits? I don't know the answer and I don't expect you to either but it might be worth exploring. This might be relevant: http://news.cnet.com/2100-1001-964721.htmlIn the refining stage, it might be useful to pick one type of electronic gadget and play out the scenario of what would happen if the gadget carried the tag to map out how it would be used. You then might find that tagging a percentage of goods can give you the data you need instead of tagging the entire production line. And what else could you do with the data? I'm kind of thinking visualisations as in 'Information is Beautiful' http://www.informationisbeautiful.net/ that could be used in environmental campaigning in which case you might only need one tag to tell the story of a product's journey.
Good thinking. Since the tags are extremely small I don't think the resources added will be too large to outweigh benefits. But it is definitely worth researching!

I like this idea because it has a data collection and measurement component to (1) get a baseline assessment of the current problem (2) provides an opportunity to evaluate progress over time, (3) educates consumers about recycling options, and (4) it is based on standards that already exist. Excellent idea!
Thank you!

I love the concept however I have a doubt:In the long term there would still be millions of phones , computers etc that might be fitted with RFIDs but would need to be put somewhere. How does one tackle the low demand for older products issue?

Thanks for the thought! When I was writing this, I was mostly concerned with how the e-waste recyclers could track massive amounts of waste more effectively. By low demand do you mean consumer demand or demand from recyclers? The key is that when consumer demand is down or gone, we need to get the devices to the right recyclers. So these tags could help collectors sort and send more effectively. So the problem that I didn't address fully in this concept it how to get the device from consumer to collector. If this makes it to refinement I will flesh it out more!
Simplistic & Executional. Overall outstanding concept.
Thanks!

Great to see you float this as a separate concept Rob, in addition to being a complementary technology for both Vincents RRR concept and the technical data component of my recyCOOlable system database.Also can see this as spawning complementary scanning devices specifically for monitoring movement of a wide range of products in the WEEE Stream.Another similar technology that could be adapted to purpose is the humble ibutton.

comments.text: High-quality recovery for recycling is important where products can no longer be re-used. WRAP is researching how products could be collected and processed to enhance their value for high-recovery operations instead of mixing all products up and risking losing that value. Work from the  TU Berlin suggests that up to 75% of gold in e-waste is lost if it's passed through a conventional e-waste shredding process. WRAP estimates that 8-10 tonnes of gold are put on the UK market in electronics every year. That's worth about 250million - imagine losing 75% of that!
This is a great inspiration Barbara and a wonderful complement to Kelly's http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/inspiration/e-waste-economics/  Do they recycle/reprocess common materials too?

comments.text: Hi Greg - I think this is a good concept, but one suggestion would be to somehow provide this information to customers at the end of the product's life. When customers purchase electronics, I think they might have a tendency to throw some of the non-essential paperwork/materials away. Also, there's always a chance someone just misplaces the flier or the pre-paid packing slip over the life of the product. Maybe make this info available for download on the company's website??
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

This is a great idea! I've also been thinking about the "Keep America Beautiful" organization. One of their main areas of focus is litter reduction. I feel as though any campaign against e-waste could reach out to this organization for inspiration or potential partnership. The overall e-waste challenge would benefit from a refreshed version of the "Don't be a litterbug campaign" (http://www.flagstaff.az.gov/images/pages/N1357/ECE%20Cityscape%20LitterBug.jpg) from the 60s & 70s. Despite its simplicity the campaign was very successful in reducing litter (http://www.pps.org/reference/excerpt-pick-up-the-litter-paint-over-the-graffiti/)
Great thinking around raising awareness at a key touchpoint, Greg!

Great idea to extend this to all electronic items Greg!I have in my hand an example of what Samsung currently includes in some of their cellphone packages - a pre-paid postage satchel for recycling my old phone, battery and charger through the MobileMuster ( http://www.mobilemuster.com.au ) initiative that is "the official recycling program of the Mobile Phone industry" in Australia,a site I have referred to in Meena's Neighbourhood E-Waste Champion concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/neighbourhood-e-waste-champion/ ) for other reasons.However looking further at the satchel it says"MobileMuster Accepts - all mobile phone handsets, batteries, chargers and accessories including PDAs that are mobilesMobileMuster DOES NOT Accept household or other batteries, home phones or any other non-mobile electronic components or devices"It does say that if I have more than one mobile to recycle I can download another pre-paid mailing label or use the designated drop off points.This seems to fit the bill for cell phones but I haven't yet seen a broader initiative - it certainly should apply to home phones, answering machines and so-on up the scale.

Totally, and it also serves to educate the exact person that needs to be educated, the consumer who now has something to throw away.  Adrian Franco really hit the nail on the head with his box concept.  Its nice to know Samsung is doing this, however I think education is also needed.  Its too easy to just dump things and have no idea the repercussions of throwing everything away.  Thanks for the info!

Yes I agree Greg - the education is vital. I know in so many households the recycling satchel too would find its way to landfill along with the mobile it could have retrieved.All of these initiatives (like Adrian's boxes) are necessary, especially in our 'convenience' society, but consumers need constant reminders about this which is why I devoted my first concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/recy-cool-ability/ )to linking the process (for items from mice, keyboards and hair dryers right up to the newest 'smart' fridges) with an existing campaign (Energy Star ratings) but at the same time trying to target kids as consumers of the future and a positive influence on their peers and elders.

slow_tech.description: Creating a label for long lasting technology.
slow_tech.creator: 8082a75025cb51e513aff379783121c9

comments.text: This is a great concept. It takes some of the responsibility off of the user and places it on the tech-companies. My concern is it's profitability and buy in. I wonder if, rather than producing more durable electronics, consumers could participate in an insurance program, and companies commit to fixing their product until it's truly dead.

Hi Margaret, thank you for sharing your great feedback. Also electronic tool leasing came to my mind. Its more common in B2B business where the company takes care of their own product and you pay for using it - so they have a great interest in having long lasting products, good maintenance and cheap repair costs. Here I see the possibility to establish services around Trusty Tech for supporting the movement of long lasting electronic devices. Id like to extend my concept here during the refinement.

Would we be able to use the brand on existing items?  Electronics already in existence that are still working well after many years e.g. a ten year old modem that is still working well could be "Back-Branded" to signal to potential re-users. It would give a lot of kudos to companies to have their existing products already listed as long lasting and encourage them to think about how they could do it again.

That's a very interesting suggestion Leandra - I guess it depends on how it would be administered since just providing an open licence would mean all and sundry would apply the brand whether or not they were designed or built to last.Perhaps it could be covered with a dual licence where one is issued to manufacturers with strict criteria and an open licence intended for users to endorse long-lived products. In this latter case it would be possible simply to download and print a label of suitable size (probably based on SVG.

That is a very interesting conversation, Leandra and Paul. Giving a signal and branding products who have proven to be long lasting could be an addition. The idea of the dual licence is intersting. Im thinking if the labels should look slightly different then - in order to be able to distinguish them.

Yes I guess I meant to imply that they would be distinguishable but I wasn't sure quite how - colour, wording or shape spring to mind. Diamond shapes are often associated with quality, purity, lasting value - maybe that shape could be licenced to manufacturers (or vice versa) - I guess its something for the branding 'experts' that I'm sure are out there in OpenIDEOLand.

Great analogy drawn from the Slow Food movement, Sabine! My first thought was that word 'slow' sounds a bit odd in the tech space. Was wondering if Long Tech might be a possible alternative? Looking forward to what others might suggest here too and seeing this idea grow!

Hi Meena, thanks for sharing your thoughts. I also was wondering if slow tech would bring up associations like low performance. So Im really curious to more opinions. I already like your suggestion 'Long Tech' a lot. Also 'Pure Tech' came to my mind. Im really looking forward to work on this.
Nice one, Sabine! I'm digging Pure Tech too.
Thank you. I just updated my post. Looking forward to other suggestions.

Hey there, how about 'Trusty Tech' as an alternative? (Going for the alliteration, obviously...) Or, to address Meena's point in a another way, how about one of these: 'Tech with a Future''Future Tech''Tech For Tomorrow Too' (TT2?)
'Tech with prospect'? Hm, maybe I'm taking it too far... :)
I like 'Trusty Tech' .

Hi Hannes, thank you for your great suggestions. And thank you Leandra for sharing your opinion. Now really one is spoilt for choice. I like Trusty Tech and Pure Tech a lot.Im curious about other opinions.
Hi Hannes and Leandra, I added you also to my virtual team. Thank you for your great contributions.

Love the concept Sabine!Another complementary way to identify items - those that will last.I don't have figures to back me up but I'm convinced that most of us could manage for quite a long time with technology from 3 or 4 years ago if it was resilient.I can't think of alternatives to "pure" and "slow" at the moment (if ever 'lol'). But will keep thinking about the development of this.
Thank you, Paul. I also would like to use some items longer, if they would last. So 3-4 years sounds reasonable for me.

Hi again Sabine,I have suggested to Marie No ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/hold-on-to-your-device-and-save-the-green-deposit-system-for-newly-purchased-electronics/ ) that you compare notes.I think the two concepts could be complementary. At the point of sale for retail electronics there would be an opportunity to 'promote' both her deposit but also the lifespan of a given product - longer lifespan could become a 'selling point'.

Hi Paul, thank you for linking the two concepts. I think they would go very well together - one label which indicates long-lasting products to customers and one concept for tracking how long people use their products and providing incentives to those who use their products also very long.

digital_data_transfer_and_elimination_se.description: At the end of a mobile phone's (first) life a data transfer and elimination service will encourage users to hand in their old phones to be re-used, re-furbished or re-cycled without having to worry that personal data is either lost or misused.
digital_data_transfer_and_elimination_se.creator: f0b001a81c949c3db7420fdd0e57427d

comments.text: Nice idea Anne! I especially like that you've honed in on one specific consumer pain point and designed a concept to resolve that. Do you have a sense of what this service would look like? Would consumers have to go somewhere to have their data scrubbed? Could it be an add-on service that consumers pay for when they first buy their phone? I'm curious to hear what you think.

Hi Ashley, thank you for your comments. I did think about writing something on legislation that stops EU countries dumping their e-waste in places like Ghana (there seems to be a legislative loophole) but my personal interest lies with bottom-up/ user behaviour type stuff. I live in the UK which apparently is one of the top countries for phone take-back schemes but even there only a fraction of old phones are recycled or re-used. The way I imagine this to work (but Im all ears for suggestions) is that someone would walk into a mobile phone retail outlet with an old phone, possibly looking for a new one. There, data could simply be taken off the old phone before it is collected by the retailer or if a new phone is purchased, data could be transferred onto the new device. There might even be a financial incentive to hand in phones. Alternatively, someone might just want to delete or transfer data to give the phone to a friend or family member. Someone I spoke to yesterday even suggested that he would be happy to pay a fee to have data taken off a phone to be able to pass it to someone else. I think what you said about this being an add-on service is interesting. I guess from a business point of view it might even strengthen brand loyalty.In the UK you can check how much money you can receive for an old phone through a number of providers online. Then you register your details, they send you an envelope, you post the phone and they post you a cheque. Im not sure how the concept could work with online take-back schemes like this but as I said earlier, this only accounts for a fraction of discarded phones.

Wonderful Anne!Great and practical concept in the context of making 'safe' all sorts of devices that may have personal data. Also very sensible suggestion to determine the extent to which data sensitivity is a factor in people's disposal decisions.Interesting provocations too Ashley.

Maybe consumers could go into a drop-off point, and on the wall they can plug in their device and a memory stick, press a button, all data is then transferred to the stick and it confirms the device is clean.  Then they put the device in a drop-off container. May be a bit technical but I would certainly be more than happy to do that! I like you idea, best of luck :)

Congratulations on making the refinement shortlist Anne!I will look at linking some of your comments from above, together with this concept to some others, particularly those that incorporate an element of residual value.This service is needed at a variety of stages in a device's life-cycle. I have friends in the Philippines who are often in need of ready cash so have a tendency to 'pawn' things from PCs to CPs - in one case they pawned a netbook then failed to make the interest payments and lost the family photos, on a previous occasion they got the device back but when we examined it there had obviously been some use of it while in 'pawn'. I think Gail's idea of a plug-in point for some devices (like CPs) is worth incorporating in the concept, and possibly extending the service to other points at which transfer of ownership (either temporary or permanent) occurs.

In this comment ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/chargers-and-cords-exchange-box#c-1718d3a3c83c1bdb93fe53468a609557 ) I suggested that a number of other concepts provided potential locations for both the exchange service and for your transfer and elimination service. The potential for marketing this service is huge but I particularly like the prospect of combining/partnering with other concepts out of this challenge.

As you refine in this next phase, we encourage you to think about how your might research and learn more about this hurdle. the light saber option seems easier to put in place :-)I need to spend some time reading the tablet option but it sounds an interesting option.This leads me to the question: how can we get people who are not hacker to feel that they can do it, and how can they get support in doing it?Maybe there would be a way to start prototyping your concept by providing some examples as you did in your description and in your reply to my comment.

What if you could see recipes posted by a local hacker space, then you could decide to either follow the instructions or, take a class? comments.text: A great idea. It's useful to keep clear focus on the two separate requirements: design for repair/re-use and design for recycling. Design for re-use is fairly straightforward. There are some key principles about modularity, physical access in the product and availability of cheap parts. WRAP has published some design guidance and case studies on products that demonstrate these principles [www.wrap.org.uk/content/buying-guides-durability-and-repair]Design for recycling is tougher - you have to know what the process is going to be. In countries like Japan items are disassembled on "reverse production lines". In many other countries products are shredded then sorted by magnets and automatic plastic sorting machines. So design for recycling might focus on how parts separate from each other, and whether the pigments in the plastics enable traditional systems to identify them (e.g. black pigments can prevent separation on infrared separators)

Cradle to cradle design is definitely a key part of the solution. What about designing things so that you can fix them instead of throwing them away? For example, build spare parts for the toy robot so you can replace broken bits without throwing the whole thing away.

comments.text: I think, this is one is really hitting on the tip of one of the iceberg of this problem. May be consumers should not be responsible for having a device he has not manufactured repaired. May be manufacturing companies should be taking responsibilities on a problem generated on a consumer by their product, as companies already know before they sell a product that it will die, sooner or later. May be manufacturing companies should not be making money out of this and instead facilitated the users of their devices put the device back on a positive flow of materials. May be manufacturing companies should assemble devices so that they are easy to dis-assemble the device and put the material back into another manufacturing process. And may be consumers should only be able to choose to buy those products whose manufacturer takes the responsibility on the device material at the end of its life. May be there should only be a 'responsible end-to-end manufacturing and de-manufacturing process' and just a 'responsible purchase selection criteria' by consumers.

Great inspiration. This reminds me at my customer experience when I tried to replace the battery of my ipod shuffle. I went on the homepage of Apple and found out, that the replacement of the battery is exactly the same price then buying a new one. This was quite a few years ago - but I just checked the pricing on the Apple support page and for the ipod shuffle nothing changed: http://support.apple.com/kb/index?page=servicefaq&geo=United_States&product=ipod The price for a new one equals still the costs of buying a new one. I see the benefit of the company in more sales and also in high repair costs due to the hours needed to repair it. Seen from the waste perspective and the amount of waste, it is still not the best solution.

This is a great inspiration. I recently got my phone fixed by a local repair company - it's amazing how easy it can be. There's also growing information on how householders can fix things - places like www.ifixit.com
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Similarly, FLOR applies this concept to carpeting. They sell carpet in tiles, so you can replace just the pieces that are worn or dirty. They even have a program in place, so you can return and recycle the pieces you no longer want. http://www.flor.com/recycle

I love this analogy. The majority of the time, if something breaks, our society has learned to throw it out and buy new. I think the key is that we only look to repair options when the replacement cost is high - like cars, and also computers. I've seen electronics repair shops begin to cater specifically to smartphone users now that the initial costs of unsubsidized smartphones are creeping to $500. Workstation computers used in high-end design and rendering tasks have often been built with swappable internal components, to allow for greater flexibility and customization as technology advancements outstrip purchasing ability. Rather than buying all-new cell phone bodies whenever a manufacturer releases a new model with spec upgrades, it would be awesome if we could choose to buy just that improved screen or camera lens.

Hi Cynthia, agreed, it's all about the perceived value isn't it?Non-profits such as CERES are doing a brilliant job trying to make firms include sustainability factors in their accounting principles (http://www.ceres.org/what-we-do/ensure-honest-accounting). If environmental costs and impact on society were to be included in accounting principles then cell-phone repair/customization would become a far more attractive option for cell-phone makers.Also, I live in Australia where smart phones cost up to $800 and where it is expected 90% of all mobile users will be smart phone users by 2015 (http://www.telsyte.com.au/testingsite/?page_id=706), i.e. huge market.If we consider that:1- the above market prediction are more or less applicable to many other markets worldwide,2- the smart phone market is actually composed of a software and a hardware market; and that,3- the real value of a smart-phone resides in its operating system and the apps available for download (i.e. the software market),.. we can then imagine the apparition of low cost, modular and sustainable (biodegradable?) devices  for every day users that may want to upgrade/customize their device regularly, up to premium products composed of more high-tech, durable units to cater for professional users.To conclude, it would be interesting to revise the 'one product for all' concept currently adopted by most cell-phone makers.
Of interest: mobile repair is alive & well in India: http://postconsumption.posterous.com/delhi-mobile-repair

Awesome to see this happening Meena: where there is a need, there is a market.It'll be great to see cell-phone makers directly embed this concept in their business model too.It could potentially benefit the environment and safeguard human health by reducing e-waste but also cell-phone makers and consumers by opening new revenue streams and offering customizable products, respectively.Picture a modular phone with clip on accessories for example, i.e. an underwater lens or, why not, an holographic screen (http://www.yankodesign.com/2009/06/10/no-tangible-screen-for-this-mobile-phone/)

comments.text: I like this idea a lot.  Building on it, I was thinking about how I've seen a lot of people, including myself, find devoted tasks for old devices.  Perhaps in terms of interface, phone developers or app developers could consider new uses for obsolete phones.I have an old iPhone which I use strictly as a music player... perhaps there are other interesting applications which could be explored by the app community.  Some sort of network of d-i-y projects/instructables for old devices of every make might lead to a whole community of this type of thing?Imagine logging on, putting in the make of your obsolete phone, and finding all kinds of downloadable DIY projects to build interesting alarm clocks, music players, wall displays, streaming video player wall-mounts, some kind of dedicated interactive device for the kitchen, smart tv remotes, etc etc.  With these interesting ideas in my own quick brainstorm, I imagine a DIY community could take the concept pretty far.
What you describe (as far as I can tell) was indeed posted as an offshoot here: http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/rewire.com/
Oh yeah - you're right!  Love this platform.  Commented my support there :)

Nice brainstorm - you and I seem to think somewhat alike.  I never thought about alarm clocks, interactive devices for the kitchen, or wall displays though!   Very neat.  Would you mind if I added your brainstorm above (with my ideas I made in comments below) to the rewire concept?

Go ahead and add it (you can credit me if there's a spot for that).  I was thinking a bit more about this and I think the key concept is that moment of discovery.  When you get a new phone, you not only get a new phone, but you also get the opportunity to repurpose your old phone... and so you begin to adventure online to find a cool project.  Could be a useful appliance or just a cool art piece or visual display or anything that the DIY community comes up with!
I added your ideas to the rewire concept.  I really like your post above -- feel free to repost that on the rewire concept page. http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/rewire.com/

This is a really good idea!  Could this possibly apply to other items, for example gaming systems? I would certainly not mind installing multiple emulators and ROMs for old systems (such as NES, SNES, N64) on an old PS2 with a harddrive and the open-source code your plan would force Sony to release.  Then I could have all those systems I grew up with in one unit...otherwise that old PS2 is useless. I'm just pulling that out of the air, but my point is this can probably apply to electronics outside the phone/mobile realm (with a little creativity).I wouldn't mind teaming up with you on this idea and exploring it further, if you like.

Absolutely! I used the term "smart devices" which in my mind are basically anything that comes with a reasonably sophisticated operating system...and gaming systems are a great example of that (which is awesome because I couldn't come up with any other examples at the time. :) Gaming is an interesting example because companies concentrate so much on new systems, yet I get so much pleasure out of playing Mario Kart on GameCube. It's a console with quite a lot of life left in it, and most people probably wouldn't throw it away...so why not make new games for it? Moreover, I wonder if programming for those games may be easier today because we can use 2012 programming tools for a 2003 system.Your particular vision hits me as slightly more complex, because it would hypothetically allow for the junking of the PS2 console once you have an open source emulator, and that seems to fly a bit in the face of this challenge. I'd be happy to create a team. What other thoughts do you have?

Mostly, the thoughts I had were other ways to reuse these devices that (unfortunately) have a life of 2 years, thanks to cell contracts and frequent hardware upgrades.  I thought about how someone like me who doesn't have a smartphone (I don't want to get used to it just yet while I can still live without a data plan :) ) still wants to have, say, an in-car GPS unit that will give turn-by-turn, spoken directions.  Is the GPS functionality in a smartphone only available with cell service? or can the smartphone be used "posthumously" as a GPS unit?  If this is possible, why would I want to go out an buy a Garmin GPS unit when I can buy someone's old iPhone 3GS for $30 and use that?If it the GPS functionality does require a cell service, I suppose there's a possibility for a company to come in provide that service, but it's certainly not as ideal.

Another use for an old smartphone was inspired by an app provided by the Apple app store - Remote.  This app allows your iOS device to control iTunes on your computer wirelessly.  From the kitchen, you can change the song/video on the computer in the other room which is connected to your stereo (or even connected to your TV).  Anyway, why not use your old smartphone (or buy someone else's old smartphone for cheap and use it) as a remote with a touch screen?  Some people have remotes that program their TV, stereo, DVD/aux players, lights, etc.  Why not use an old phone to do this instead of spending a bunch of money on yet another electronic device?I'm not sure how feasible these ideas are, but I'm mostly just brainstorming on your wall here...

Another detail to the previous post: An old smartphone could be used as a home media device.  It may be "outdated" according to your carrier's commercials, but it's got a good amount of memory in it and a good processor.  So someone, with it now being open-source, can create and sell a program for it that will do just that--make it into a media device you can plug into your TV/stereo unit, or your car.  The idea is it would be different than a cell phone--you would leave it where it is most of the time, and disconnect it only when you need to change out the media on it (if it doesn't have something like a mini-usb connection this program could utilize).In your home stereo, the once-smartphone can play media from its own memory, or it can connect via your wireless network to a service such as youtube or hulu or netflix or amazon prime or whatever.  These phones have the ability to connect to HD tvs anyway, and its simple (and cheap) enough to convert output from the audio (headphone) jack to a stereo.In your car, this could sit in the trunk (where many stereo systems have you put your 5-disc CD changers) the whole time and your car stereo's controls can go through the media (much like they can now with an iphone connected, only you wouldn't have the hassle of having to connect and disconnect every time you get in/out of the car.)  (It's true that this would prevent you from talking on your existing phone through the stereo, but is that feature as commonly-used as the commercials would have us believe?)  If you didn't want it in the trunk, the device has a touch screen and could be used as the stereo, to switch songs or whatever right where your volume control and clock are.Again, there are plenty more considerations and details to think through, but here are some more ideas on how to reuse these definitely-not--obsolete devices.
I've also got some ideas on how all of this can work into education, but I'm thinking I'll click the "build on this" button on this concept rather than further pollute this space :)

Answering your first question first, GPS doesn't need a data connection. It needs to have the maps/addresses to route with. Smart phones use a data connection to get these maps, but there is no reason that they couldn't be loaded into a huge app (a couple of gigabytes for the US for instance) and then the phone can be a GPS without data connection.You remote idea is good. Your home/car media device is excellent...it solves a problem I have right now. I have a car that doesn't have an aux port on its radio for me to plug my iPod into. Until now, I didn't realize that I could just install my iPod as a second stereo basically...possibly adding a second set of speakers, for cheaper than a new radio.Feel free to pollute away! :)

Great discussion here guys!From my point of view it would be great to breath new life into a range of devices that have otherwise reached their use-by date, specifically older PDA's.I'm not quite sure how one loads an alternative OS on some of these devices but I know of one guy who I think would love to tinker with them (he wrote the original Winsock software - that MS finally had to pay him 'something' for). Hi James, I really like your idea to release the operating system code. I was just wondering if they have to release the whole code or if interfaces and some key-information would be sufficient? That might be easier to convince the manufacturer. I also thought about the timing - 3 1/2 years might be already to late since a lot of phones are only used for 2 years. Thats also when the warranty normally expires. So what about opening the system with the expiry date? Maybe you can use some of my thoughts for the further development of your concept. That's an interesting question....and I suspect that there would be situations in which the whole code may be required, and in other instances only parts of the code would be sufficient. This concept is not meant for people who are on the regular two year phone cycle. Those people get a fresh phone every two years, and at the end of two years their phone tends to be still quite usable and just as it is becoming slow, the person gets a new phone. This is meant for 3 year old and up phones--like my iPhone which is not used with a big carrier--I'm not in a position to get a phone contract and pay a lot for phone service and get a new phone. Eventually I will get a new phone, and perhaps this 4 year old iPhone will find itself in the hands of someone even more unfortunate than me. :) This concept is especially for them: perhaps they are in a 3rd world nation and my craptastic phone will be a lifeline for them. I'd love to provide them with newer software so that they can get the most use out of it. So I went with 3 1/2 years. I thought 3 years was too short, and manufacturers would think that those devices would be in too much competition with their new products.

comments.text: Hi Franklyn,I really enjoyed reading your idea and think recycling rare earth minerals from e-waste is incredibly important but I have a few areas of concern I was hoping you could address, especially as it pertains to the environmental footprint of this solution:(1) While the US is among the largest producer of e-waste (http://kiwiscience.com/JournalArticles/STOTEN2009.pdf), the Basel Convention (which the US has signed but not ratified - http://www.epa.gov/osw/hazard/international/basel3.htm) is meant to limit the transportation of hazardous materials from developed countries to less developed countries. If you are operating in developing countries with lower wages, where is the e-waste coming from that you will be recycling? If it is domestically is there a high enough level of waste being produced to support your business?(2) If you are shipping e-waste from the markets that produce the most, how are you off setting the environmental impacts of shipping it from these locations and shipping the recycled materials to the areas that will use them in new products? Where are you considering locating facilities and how does this cluster production and recycling if at all? There are some great insights into this as well in the UNEP report on recycling e-waste (http://www.unep.org/PDF/PressReleases/E-Waste_publication_screen_FINALVERSION-sml.pdf) specifically throughout Section 2Best of luck!

A lot of the other ideas currently posted talk about collection and awareness, which I think is something that we sorely need at this point. One really good collection idea I think is the Deposit Program idea (http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/encourage-consumers-to-bring-back-electronics-with-a-deposit-program./). Check it out!This Golden E-Waste idea, if implemented, would complement all the collection/awareness ideas. But after really thinking this over, I think that although this is a great entrepreneurial opportunity, it may not be wholly implementable by uswe've probably all got our own jobs anyways! But if I were not still in school, this would certainly be something I'd go for.Perhaps rather than trying to pull financial support and start our own company, we could talk with companies like ERI and see for how much they would buy E-Waste. I truly believe that this idea, what ERI is doing, is the end solution to the E-Waste problem. Money out of E-Wastea whole, burgeoning, nascent industry! Ah well, more opportunities will come...!We, with our awareness and collection projects, could potentially be suppliers for their E-Waste demand.I think that collection and awareness cannot be standalone projects; they must be placed in the overall recycling/financial context.

I thoroughly agree that an integrated approach is desirable and that awareness (marketing/media) are vital components - I also think that pursuing 'Golden E-Waste Recycling' is worthwhile, certainly conceptually.Although I suggested (in the other thread) that time was getting short you will in fact find that you can continue refinement into the beginning of evaluation if it becomes necessary.

Welcome to OpenIDEO guys!Agree that this is thoroughly researched and well presented argument.As you say the costs of setting up a single recycling process is huge and of course there are some already in existence that, as you say, are turning a profit.I'm interested in the economics involved (although I'm not an economist) - and I do agree there is a window of opportunity to enter the recycling market profitably.  At present the profitability in recycling arises from the negligibly small cost of raw material input (i.e. the e-waste): being largely transportation cost (you can either pay employees to collect 'free' raw materials, pay casual collectors in lieu of collecting it yourself or pay consumers to deliver product to you).Where is the tipping point - the price at which buying back say a typical mobile phone gives the smallest acceptable return on investment?At the outset of this challenge I asked some questions of an inspiration contributor who is the CEO of an ABS plastic recycling firm (as he suggested the last, bulkiest and one of the more difficult components to recycle). From his replies it became apparent that everything has to be done on a very large scale to make it profitable - their 'product' is high grade recycled ABS suitable for feeding back into the manufacturing stream. Clearly they are profitable and partner with metal recovery firms in Britain, Europe and China. I broached the question of downscaling and was informed that they were looking at it from the perspective of pre-processing as it was presently not economic to consider small scale full-function recycling.At the moment recycling profitability relies mainly on consumer 'goodwill' - that is goods returned for no cash benefit to the consumer.Taking the ERI example a quick check of 2010 shows profit of $10m on turnover of 120m pounds of e-waste (figures from the article you quoted) - converting this to profit per 100g yields a figure of approximately 2 cents. My Samsung mobile phone weighs 108g (possibly including battery which of course is an input cost already factored into the profit).At 2c per phone the industry will continue to require 'free' materials for input and there is no real commercial incentive for the consumer in returning goods as recycling raw materials.This is not exactly the outcome I was expecting (or hoping for) when I began the exercise but it is useful to know.Given that profitability presently relies on economies of scale the real opportunity lies in developing smaller, more efficient facilities that can compete (closer to their input markets).Looking at the 'subsidies' raises a whole new range of figures that I will leave for another day.Thanks again for your input and hope to see you in future challenges too.

Paul, I've posted a comment above - what do you think?Regarding profitability in scale, I agree. However, note that although ERI profit seems infinitesimal on average, ERI is operating in the US. In developing countries, labor costs would be lower, and the supply of E-Wasteis such an unwanted supply that it has to be illegally smuggled in! The plastic and metal recycling industry is already quite large in China at the moment, but E-WasteAh! That truly is an opportunity! But of course, this may not be the most implementable project out there. After all, very few of us are based in China.I talk a little bit about my thoughts on the collection stage problem in the other comment.

Sorry for slow reply.I agree that labour costs in developing countries are lower which provides a greater opportunity. Taking ERI as the benchmark I'm not sure how much information is available on labour as a percentage of operating costs, but if there accounts are public we might be able to do a back of envelope calculation on reported gross labour costs. There is a firm in India that supplies equipment for crushing circuit boards and extracting both ferrous and non-ferrous metals - I'm looking for the link (which foolishly I didn't save). Eparisara is another I just found through your links in the concept (link below). As well as capital cost for that they might provide some idea of the number of machine operators required for various scale operations. Another firm that manufactures plant is Titech ( http://www.titech.com/ ) - I notice they have a presence in China (?Xiamen is Google map reference). Perhaps they too have information on basic manpower required for operation, and they have 'broad statement' descriptions of what the equipment will do. They appear to focus on sorting and separating.Given OpenIDEO's suggestions in their congratulatory note and the now short time-frame until evaluation begins I suggest you perhaps expand your process diagram a little to concentrate on dismantling and processing steps perhaps to compare some manual dismantling together with crushing as means of initial separation (see this page for Eparisara ( http://www.ewasteindia.com/processes.html ) where they describe their process - this could be augmented by utilising information from Joe Lee's 'Mint' type concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/mint-for-e-waste-management-what-s-my-electronic-footprint/ ) which might provide information on materials in various components that can by-pass the crushing process. Also a possibility to evaluate alternative methods of metal extraction such as bio-extraction ( http://blueoakresources.com/ ) - especially as this technology is emergent and may be looking for opportunity in developing countries.This is another Indian link which is associated with Sims Recycling in USA ( http://www.ewaste.in/F1290/the_process.html )On the question of 'pitch' to investors - I have no experience of this but I guess I would rely on the suggestion of lower labour costs and the comparison of e-waste to ore as a source for precious metal. Gold is one commodity that is fairly stable in good economic times and rises in worsening economic conditions. I don't know, but I suspect that precious metal recovery alone might contribute to return on investment.There are some links around for pitching to venture capital investors - I don't know how good the advice is.

Congrats on making the Refinement phase Top 20 shortlist! We were really impressed with your thoughtful analysis and discussion on recycling issues  and we're really looking forward to how you continue to build and edit it. During Refinement, we'd like to see you hone in on exactly the recycling model you're envisioning  and, like you mentioned, how exactly you'd pitch this idea to investors.
