I think this is on the right track. The problem, as you're saying, is that it's such a scale economy. I have been to neighbourhoods in Delhi where several city blocks are removing metals from e-waste to be processed somewhere else in the country. All this is happening on an unregulated market. In order for a community to realize such a venture maybe we need to look at crowd-investment. I have no doubt that it would pay off.

"Despite the 21 billion dollars of gold and silver embedded in modern electronics each year, not to mention copper, tin, cobalt, and palladium and other metals, only a fraction of which is ever recovered. For example, 80 to 85% of gold in e-waste is lost due to crude (and dangerous) dismantling processes in developing countries and ineffective collection systems in developed countries (which are the source of most e-waste)." http://www.fastcoexist.com/1680312/landfills-are-the-mines-of-the-future

Thanks for commenting!! Indeed! The actual technical processes would have to be quite refined in order to make an actual profit. I've recently been walking around Beijing quite a lot, and there are just SO MANY trash collectors. They're not employed by the government or anything, but they collect bottles/old electronics. They're everywhere in Beijing. If we can pay for e-waste, I have no doubt that it will galvanize LOTS of poor people in large cities to collect e-waste.

Very well thought out idea. I came to a very similar conclusion when I did some research this Spring on the carbon impacts at products' end-of-life.When equipment reuse is not possible, demanufacturing and recycling activities not only reduce the volume of materials entering the waste stream but also the energy consumed and emissions generated during new product manufacturing. As you mentioned above, recycling one metric ton of circuit boards yields at least 40 times the rare metals retrieved from one ton of ore. And in order to minimize mobile GHG emissions from trucks, recycling centers should be chosen such that the material transport distances are minimized. For example, in 2008 Waste Management announced a partnership with LG and Sony to locate e-waste recycling centers within 20 miles of 95% of the US population.

Corporations, the major purchasers of electronic devices must be induced to actively manage their waste streams.Based upon voluntary activity, manufacturer takeback programs are inconsistent with one another.  Responsibility rests upon the organization to ensure that EOL electronics are managed using safe and environmentally sound processes. The R2 (Responsible Recycling) Standard addresses specific considerations such as: health and human safety, handling of components containing hazardous materials, and the legal transfer and trade of products. E-Stewards certification follows stricter requirements. In addition to the R2 Standard, recyclers must not only have ISO 14001 certification but also exclude toxic waste from landfills and incinerators as well as export to developing countries. To maintain certification, recyclers must additionally submit to at least one on-site audit per year.

Hey, I think this is a GREAT idea! I love how this is a mixture of both public awareness AND practical action.But a couple of questions I would ask would regard:1. Scalability: one single e-waste truck could service how many streets a day? If it serves to collect, repair, inform, all at the same time, it may be difficult for it to get very far every day. In a small community I think this would work great. However, when you increase the scale of this, I think problems would arise. Realistically, who would want to work a job as an e-waste recycler? If you are an educated engineer student, this internship may be fun for a few weeks but I doubt you'd last long termmaking a minimum salary. You'd probably have to be paying this multitalented driver/engineer/educator/recycler a standard if not high salary.2. Money Who pays the salary for the driver? Who pays for the trucks? Who pays for the printing of the pamphlets, the gas used by the trucks, the training of the recyclers? Donations seem unrealistic when this concept is scaled up. Partnerships seems more realistic. Perhaps companies with green inclinationsDell, Applemay sponsor something like this. But if we go for sponsorship, the question of how truly effective this initiative is, what RESULTS it will produce may arise. I feel that perhaps one possible point to think about is how to make this project itself sustainable. Call me cynical, but I don't believe in altruismespecially when that empty stomach starts growling. For this to be sustainable and scalable, I think that the people involved have to get something more than moral justification for their efforts. Some point down the line, someone HAS to be making money or gaining something.3. Does this tackle the real crux of the problem? I think a bigger problem that may be considered is what actually happens to the e-waste that is produced. The e-truck will prolong life cycles of electronics (but not prevent the inevitable e-waste production), and collect e-waste. What happens to the e-waste it collects?  Perhaps that is the bigger question.This idea is excellent, for informing the community about e-waste is indubitably important. Community and grassroots initiative are super effective. Perhaps if this idea were implemented in conjunction with a business approach to recycling (http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/golden-e-waste-a-commodity-more-valuable-than-gold-ore/), we could create a sustainable model for taking care of e-waste!!=)Franklyn

Franklyn has linked the golden e-waste concept here which is very relevant, In the article quoted there it has some real figures for recycling which show that profitability in the whole process depends largely upon the 'waste' nature of the product undergoing recycling (i.e. it relies on donation of the product) BUT in the same article it refers to a front end charge applied in some US states that return value to cover cost of collection - since collection is an established part of recycling process the E-Cycle Truck could, in part, be funded through performing both functions. Since it would be contributing to extending device life perhaps the 'front end' tax regime could be adapted to incorporate the community service involved.
Alternatively perhaps existing recycling collectors could devote some resources to the E-Cycle Truck

I think this is a great idea. Reliable data on what one owns and the energy cost of those items will hopefully lead to better decisions about disposal and future purchases. Maybe I just like cute dashboards too much, but I'd certainly like to see the impact of all the tech I own graphed nicely!On disposal: Its probably quite hard to find good data on how to recycle items, but easier to find the makeup of devices. Using this info a site could recommend the best kind of disposal: reuse, recycle or toxic (e.g. batteries).On future purchases: People wouldn't even need a personalised dashboard, but rather a page where they can compare the device they have and the ones they are considering buying. That would be a good start to the project I think.Joe, what is your idea of a minimal prototype? It would be quite easy to put together an online dashboard with some generic products (some smart phones, laptops, tvs etc). It could show their makeup (highlighting dangerous metals), cost to recycle and energy cost while in use. I think it would also be great to provide people with disposal options, since that could be a central part of the benefit provided to users. Great idea making the consumer aware of their personal impact. I haven't read anything about what others have already operating or proposed (is this already being worked on?) but I think it could start at the point of purchase. If there was something like a colored footprint icon containing a number (Green is better than yellow or red, lower number means less e-impact) would make the prospective purchaser aware of the environmental impact of a product. This is similar to the efficiency rating sticker one might see on a refrigerator or freezer except its an e-waste indicator. Defining the criteria for these numbers and impact ratings would be part of the process you already proposed. Basically it would be a physical sticker that matched what was in the database used for your online app. It would bring awareness to people who may not be likely to use an online app but still want to buy a digital clock.Forgive me if you already proposed the physical labeling of products somewhere in your proposal, I am currently in a state of caffeine induced creativity so I jumped straight to the comments section to get my thoughts into words before they are gone forever.

If I remember correctly, there are some concepts around labels, and I agree - ultimately it would be great to raise awareness at all points of the consumption cycle - awareness, preference, purchase, usage, etc.  Seems like increasing transparency and information at all these touch points will help consumers make more sustainable choices.

Hi Joe, I really like your idea to have a dashboard to see the impact of myself as a consumer - and then see the impact of the single product as well. So for me its great to see the impact from both sides. As a consumer I might have one product with lots of impact or a pile of products with less impact. And for my decision, which device I will add to my "collection of electronics" I can use product labels.Paul integrated already proposed labels in his E-Resources concept. There you can find an overview: http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/e-resources/ Im looking forward to see your concept evolve.

Now if only we could make this effortless for people to view... =)  Thanks for the link to the E-Resources concept! That would be also great to have the possibility to add new purchases in web shops instantly. While constantly adding and deleting your electronic devices to your dashboard you get some sort of e-device diary. And see if your environmental impact improves or not. The better you do, the closer you become to be an e-champion. Great game!

comments.text: Excellent proposal Greg!According to Mike Biddle (founder of MBA Polymers http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/inspiration/responsible-recycling-of-the-difficult-material-to-recycle-from-e-waste-plastics/  )there is considerable resistance to incorporation of recycled product (especially plastic) - he makes the suggestion that there is a need to "prime the pump" and"US government procurement policy could provide a huge market for electronics and electronic appliances with high recycled content and thus can overcome these concerns. One key component of such a policy would be a clear preference for products with at least 25% post-consumer recycled material content."Such a policy would provide a basis for setting the targets you propose.The R2 standard seems to be focused on the safety and health aspects of recycling, which is fine, but could be extended to include re-use of recovered materials as 'closed-loop' inputs.Past experience shows that voluntary compliance will only take us so far and some legislative mandate will be necessary (however distasteful that may be ideologically).

By the way Greg I like your image and would like your permission to incorporate it with one from Ting-Han's inspiration( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/inspiration/building-a-brand-for-201c-made-from-e-waste-201d-/  )for a complementary concept I would like to launch soon.

There might be a need for compromise between the two where products that contain particularly hazardous materials like mercury are individually identified, rather than other toxins which might only emerge with totally inappropriate handling.

comments.text: There is greater cash value and environmental benefit in re-using products rather than recycling them. This retains the rare earth materials in use without having to invest more energy in recovering and recycling them.However, when items reach their end of life and are no-longer re-usable then recovery and recycling is the best option. Understanding which countries these products are likely to arise in is important.

Hi Kelly - I like the second paragraph of your post. I wonder if there are ways to make it easier for firms to 'mine' from our e-waste rather than from the natural environment? It would also be great to show people how many tonnes of ore is required to produce a tonne of metal from nature vs. from e-waste (I haven't been able to find the answer to this)

Hi Quinton = I agree but I'm not surprised that you can't find an answer to the question of comparative abundance of metals. Besides not being as 'sexy' as how many Facebook customers prefer MacDonalds to Burger King it would be an extraordinarily difficult comparison to make. However there are some advantages to mining e-waste as Kelly points out - costs of both extraction and production will drop but the challenge will be to resist the temptation for economies of scale and concentrate on low to medium scale processing.Mike Biddle's company is involved in recycling some of the hard plastics see his inspiration( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/inspiration/responsible-recycling-of-the-difficult-material-to-recycle-from-e-waste-plastics/ ) He suggests they are looking at pre-processing as a means to down scaling.

Hi Paul - thanks for the link to Mike Biddle's inspiration. Using less than 20% of the energy compared to virigin petrochemical plastics makers, this looks like a great example of it being more efficient to recycle and 'mine' the e-waste stream rather than the natural environment. Preprocessing as a principle is a great way to overcome the need for scale everywhere and aggregate materials for scale intensive processes later in the production cycle (and make those scale intensive activities competitive).

An interesting perspective on this problem is reported here( http://english.cri.cn/7146/2012/06/29/1942s709306.htm )As you say Kelly USA has 13% of reserves but little or no production (ostensibly because of the environmental hazards) - China has 23% of reserves but huge production.Concerns over dependence on overseas production prompted a USGS Report in 2010 ( http://english.cri.cn/7146/2012/06/29/1942s709306.htm ) so it may be that there is a rethink on local production - particularly as production costs begin to rise in China (average labour costs there will not remain static).

This is an interesting inspiration.Necessity being the mother of invention the restriction of supply will ultimately lead to innovative solutions that do not require rare earth minerals.However in the short term it will have the beneficial effect of making recycling of rare earths more attractive.

Here in Australia one state has been running plastic and glass bottle deposits for many years. There have been many suggestions lately to extend it country wide but Coca-Cola lobbies very heavily against it.Many years ago there used to be a small deposit on glass beer bottles which would be returned for washing, sterilising and refilling. It was very popular, especially with scouts and junior sporting clubs who would collect and return them to support their activities. The practice died out with the introduction of aluminium cans without a deposit even though some beer still comes in glass bottles.The challenge in re-introducing such a scheme is legislative because competition puts downward pressure on prices - so manufacturers won't apply deposits voluntarily.

comments.text: Great concept, DFA! I can really see this concept taking off and developing into a sophisticated exchange system. I understand that this is only the start-up phase so my points are out of scope; however, I wanted to share them so you can keep them in mind during your refinement stage. If you can consider some of these point, then future growth may come more naturally as the boxes and number of chargers/cords grow:-An electronic inventory system to keep track of the type of charger/cord. People can search by charger/code type or by the product that they are looking to find a cord/charger for (e.g. Galaxy S3 phone, the boxes may not contain any charger for the S3 but they have an S2, which can work). A few of these computers can be set-up around the area. (I know this is looking way down the line).-The inventory list should also show the location (i.e. the box number)In the mean time. I think looking into the design, structure, and organization of the box can be helpful before implementation.-The optimal box shape and size should be determined through testing and specially designed to hang or organize all the cords/chargers to avoid tangling and to facilitate easy retrieval.-It would be beneficial to have portal boxes so you can build them up when inventory increases or switch them around based on the environment or when inventory decreases. Hope this helps!

Great ideas guys!Just a couple of comments. Given as one of your other concepts indicates - safety is important too - it might be necessary to have the donated items tested as working and electrically safe. Your collection boxes for these items  would need to be like those you are designing for the Urbana cellphone/battery recycling project. You might then need to have a separate distribution point for the tested items sufficiently secure to prevent mixing of tested and untested items and allowing people to readily identify the suitability of recycled items for their purposes..Given the litigious nature of modern society (especially in USA) I suspect some safety would be mandatory as in the absence of knowing where the items originated it might make either the stores or the service promoters liable for any injuries.

Hope you're able to add some refining before we switcht to Evaluation soon!Hannes, congrats on your Top 20 concept! We especially liked your fresh take on incentivising certain purchase behaviors among consumers. As you've noted, this is a big idea! Hannes I think this is a most thought provoking idea!Like you I'm not an economist so I don't know how this would affect prices.Logically your concept makes a lot of sense and would, I think, generate considerable recirculation of devices.It's a long time since I have thought about the intricacies of the retail process and what drives the release of new products.I wonder if we have Ideators in this challenge who are involved with selling the gamut of devices that will end up as e-waste to provide some input.Some of us have drawn on analogies in the automobile industry where product releases are in many instances similarly spaced. The housing market moves more slowly but like automobiles there is considerable residual value and useability in pre-owned houses.At the other end newspapers and periodicals have a very short life-cycle and are often of very low value once superceded.Perhaps we have some participants here who can bring background and experience to this concept, which deserves discussing fully.

Hi Paul, thanks a lot for your interesting thoughts. It's a great idea to look at comparable (and non-comparable!) 'product' markets for insights! That hadn't occurred to me at all.Since you brought up the automobile industry and the housing market, that made me realize a (maybe) crucial difference here: While with an old house, and even with an old car, people easily know that there is still some significant value in them, that doesn't seem to apply to cell phones for example. The pace of the market is so fast there that people indeed seem to treat their electronic devices very much like newspapers: If they do recycle them, then mostly because they think that they're not worth anything anymore. In the case of the newspapers that may be true, but not so much with electronic devices: It doesn't easily occur to us, that we should _not_ recycle them because they're not worth anything anymore, but _precisely_ because they are still worth _something_! Maybe not to you, maybe not to your neighbor, maybe not to anyone in your neighborhood, but very likely for someone out there who otherwise needs to buy a new or has to do without one. With that in mind, two things would need to be done, I guess: a) raise awareness of the remaining value of old devices, and b) provide some market mechanism that directly or indirectly brings together sellers/donators and (re)buyers. Of course, many of all the great concepts here are already striving to do that.An upside that I see with the 'buycycle' idea is that it introduces a new kind of 'give and take' principle at the very (temporal) moment in the market cycle, where a) people are already interacting with the market anyway, and where b) they can relatively easily be convinced of the usefulness of (the imposition of) the trade in / buycycling: Since they actively want something, they will be more likely to be okay with making a contribution to the society and the environment (as compared to other moments of trying to 'approach' and incentivize them).Sorry for the slight digression... Your comment obviously inspired me to think further on all this... :)Best,Hannes

Just a few comments (not thought through yet). I agree there is a need to raise awareness of residual value - both Robert Caruso's Deposit program ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/encourage-consumers-to-bring-back-electronics-with-a-deposit-program./ ) and Marie No's Green Deposit ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/hold-on-to-your-device-and-save-the-green-deposit-system-for-newly-purchased-electronics/ ) concepts create residual value, so they might be complementary to BuyCycle in some respects - going further the idea of a database accessed through website and app that monitors a residual value for each product, based on initial purchase makes this integration a possibility. I think the introduction of any of the concepts related to extending life requires a residual value and this will of course ultimately come from initial purchase price - balancing this would be not only preserved value in the secondary marketplace but also hopefully products that last their extended lifetime.

Thanks Paul, again interesting thoughts  and I mostly agree with what you say. I think an important insight here could be the awareness of two different, although coincident, residual values: an individual one and a social/environmental one. It seems to me that many of us lose sight of the latter or even confuse the individual value ('individual' including friends and family here) with the overall residual value. So I think this distinction, and/or circumstance, should definitely be something worth addressing in a potential awareness campaign. While I agree that some residual value will ultimately have to "come" (or be derived from) the initial purchase price on the level of economic incentive, I do think that residual value can also come from, or does exist, in other areas as well: precisely because individual and social/environmental value, although somewhat correlated, are not always necessarily identical. The challenge is, I think, to make people see those hidden values, and act upon them of course. Especially when they have already decided to replace a device, then "donating" the social/environmental residual value doesn't even cost them anything really.

I concur completely - and this is some of the thinking now going into Mira Rao's Marketing Campaign concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/marketing-campaign-to-raise-awareness-and-provide-solutions/ ).

That will make a more reasonable exchange and allow people to still have as many electronics as they can afford.

A used battery is not the same as a used Ipod, which is different from a used toaster, again different from a used AC... comments.text: Helping consumers to shape their understanding of e-waste is the first step to build awareness of the issue.  Your idea of providing a website for information on what materials go into electronics, what can be re-used and how to safely dismantle and properly recycle certain parts is brilliant!  1.    At the point of sale, electronic manufacturers/retailers should  ignite the conversation on the cause by supplying a link that comes with your receipt/ order number on how to re-use/recycle your old item.  One example would be partnering with existing platforms such as: www.earth911.com making E-Waste more visible. Once consumers understand why recycling e-waste is important and how it impacts the environment, they will be more prompted to take action.  Here is key to facilitate to them the steps on how to recycle, where to drop off.  2.    One idea would be to have a zip code locator at the point-of-sale, where a couple of locations appear as an option to drop off their old electronic.  Also, some manufacturers/retailers or mobile providers are engaging consumers in the cause by offering them 'gift card' credits on new purchase or having a free mailing program available for the old items.  These types of programs should be incentivised or supported by governmental policies. Finally, once the awareness and the steps on 'how-to' recycle are there, keeping the conversation going through social platforms and having the collaboration of celebrities by sharing their stories (as the"Hall of Fame"mentioned above) represent great examples to engage consumers and positively influence them.  3.   Sports and pop-culture figures have proved to be 'influencers or trendsetters' - one example is the active model and UN Goodwill Ambassador Gisele Bundchen, who lends her image and fame to several green related cause (http://blog.giselebundchen.com.br/en/geral/iniciativa-para-diminuir-o-efeito-estufa/).  These types of collaborations sparkle awareness, curiosity, call-to-action and keep conversations flowing on/off-line.
All three fascinating ideas are inputs to create a sustainable policy that prevents e-waste rather than react to established electronics supply/manufacturing practices.

Rather than selling people *ready made* electronic devices, I think it would be fun to sell it to them in parts, so they are encouraged to put it together themselves.  Each part would be labelled (name, country of origin and composition) and good customer service groups would be put in place (to assist if need be).  By having people put together their own device, the idea of the 'black box' is removed AND they are more likely to go looking for parts if the device breakdown.  // with Ikea.
What a great idea! Maybe you'll add it as another concept to the challenge? :)

I agree that there is some confusion over the definition of e-waste (?WEEE) and many of the suggested solutions tend to reflect this. There is no lack of general information available on the nature, health and environmental impact of e-waste and indeed on many established procedures but, as you correctly point out it is limited in acceptance both in the general community and the manufacturing/distribution industry.Your idea for a dismantling website was what I thought Cansu might be working towards in his Explode'em concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/explode-em/ )or aspects of Kelly's DIY ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/build-a-diy-community-to-recycle-e-waste/ )which also could be built on for relating stories of creative re-use.Utilising packaging in creative ways would be a great option, perhaps if the parts map came in the form of a kid's game about recycling it would give marketing departments a new angle for on-the-shelf appeal of the packaging It could be printed on the inside although that would require dismantling part of the packaging.  I'm currently looking at the packaging for my Samsung cellphone. It came in two boxes - the inner box is the original black packaging for the general market which has been enclosed in a white box designed for the pre-paid market.Other possibilities spring to mind like word puzzles or Sudoku forming part of a competition which could be a feature of return use of the packaging as suggested in Adrian Franco's ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/send-old-cellphones-to-recycling-facilities-in-the-boxes-of-their-replacements/  ) concept.

comments.text: Another interesting avenue is the Charging Pad concept highlighted here (http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704409004576146341266125026.html). In an ideal world, wouldn't it be nice if there were no chargers at all?

Manufacturer's now started combining chargers and USB, i.e. charger  USB + an adapter = a charger. This saves money and cluttering of accessories. But some times because of technology upgrade, compatibility does go away. Giving room for up gradability may not always be possible though since it may result in bulkier or un- aesthetic design. But standardization would definitely be helpful.

I think IEEE develops standards around the design of chargers and adapters for power and safety considerations. The challenge lies in connector design which serves two purposes:1) most importantly the power rating of chargers and adapters needs to match the requirements of the device and designing a unique connector ensures that the device and power source match appropriately;2) following from the first point - a unique (and perhaps patentable) connector ensures use of proprietary power sources (including batteries) - leading to the 'need' to buy 'brand' power sources.For external chargers and power sources it would be possible to match connectors and power specifications across the industry.To some extent power adapters and chargers conform to a small range of input and output specifications . On the input side the two most common are 240-250 volts and 110 volts representing the two most common domestic sources of power. On the output side the most common seem to be 12v, 9v, 7.2v, 6v 3.5v with currents of about 100ma, 200ma, 500ma, 1amp and 2amp. To cover this range would require about 25 unique connector configurations (there are currently more than this on the market so even extending the range would not be difficult). Another area of standardisation needed in conjunction with this is pin configuration. A two pin connector is usually provided as a female on the charger/adapter end with either inner positive/outer negative or the reverse. If one of these could be agreed as "the" required standard that would remove another barrier.The issue is complex but not insurmountable and this concept (adequately marketed) would give impetus to achieving sensible and sustainable standards.

We have a small, manageable range of domestic power plug and socket arrangements around the world, in part linked to the supply rating - similarly we have two common ways of connecting light bulbs to the supply (bayonet and screw) - we can do the same for charger and adapter connections.

comments.text: Hi Sabine, I like where you're going with this! Can you explain a bit more about what you mean by 'breaking points'? I'm curious to see how this evolves with time. Thanks!

Hi Ashley, thank you for your great feedback! With "breaking points" I had for example built in batteries in mind which are designed to last only a defined time like 2 years. Or a printer which has a software that reports an error message at a defined time. So the "breaking point" would be the part of the device which makes the device not working anymore. And some devices break most of the time in the same way. To find these out and share solutions, like a software patch, would be great. Im also curious to see how this evolves.

Thanks for explaining  I think it's very smart! Kind of like a catalogue to track how long certain products last, and the common causes for their break down. I wonder if there would be a way to share this ne data with electronics manufacturers  they might find this kind of user insight helpful in their future designs?

Thanks for sharing your thoughts! I was also wondering if electronics manufacturers would like the platform - or would not like it at all? At least not, if they find their products there. Since  the documentation "The Light Bulb Conspiracy" got an insight how planned obsolescence is used to increase sales I was not sure, if manufacturers would like to get this feedback over a public platform. But I really like your idea about using the information for better designs in the future. Im wondering if the manufacturers would like to go there - of if consumers could make them go there.Im curious about your opinion on that.

Hi Sabine - I like your thinking here. There is definitely a need to identify planned obsolescence in electrical and electronic devices (including things like manipulation of operating systems and the other side of the coin like as you say with software patches and in James Moyer's concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/keeping-older-smart-devices-usable-by-encouraging-the-development-of-fast-software-for-them/ ))Here we have a magazine and website called Choice ( http://www.choice.com.au/ ) which has a reputation for its fearless independence. I think yours is an idea that organisations like Choice would embrace.Often manufacturers don't like unfavourable comparisons but the smarter ones at least tend to fix the identified problems in the next model. Reporting on planned obsolescence and the breaking points (planned or otherwise) might encourage companies to increase the life of products and actually enable them to introduce what the auto industry refers to as after-market enhancements.To think about cell phones it is clear that manufacturers have the capacity to apparently quickly respond to changes in network architecture (3G to 4G for example). I reality the network architecture changes far slower than the circuit design changes needed to adapt to them and manufacturers are aware very early of directions the networks are taking. Similarly developments in some hardware like processors and touch screens occur far more slowly than the circuitry and software to take advantage of them - some of this lag time could easily be devoted to enabling existing products to embrace these changes too, even if it means swapping out some components, upgrading memory etc.In thinking a little more about this I am reminded of the notion of "crippleware" and trial versions (like Microsoft products) that require a tweak (usually involving money) to restore full functionality. Although frustrating to the (non-paying) user it does demonstrate capacity to build in future use.

Hi Paul, thanks for your great feedback. I like concepts, where consumers use their voice to help companies to design better products.You are right, that the website should be independent - like Choice. And Id like to give the website a collaborative aspect like Wikipedia - where consumers can share information and make entries and give hints. Afterwards there should be a verification of the information. Consumer and also industry should find reliable information on Tech Leaks. Concerning the business model I saw at Choice, that there is payable content. Also donations could be a solution. Advertisements are contrasting the independence of the site. I like your analogy to the car-industry for changing parts and to trial versions concerning software. In order to exchange parts afterwards easily the initial design should make it possible - just thinking on my ipod shuffle where the battery change costs as much as a new one since the exchange is quite difficult. I also like the idea to update the functionality with software patches. Here I liked James Moyers idea a lot to have open access to the platforms after a defined time. Then software developers would have the change to make a business out of updates for old products. Looking forward to the further development of this concept.

Despite the frustration of an interminable wait for my dial-up to load pages I was struck by the structure of the MobileMuster site in terms of the potential for links within the community ( http://www.mobilemuster.com.au/recycle-a-mobile/?zoom=0&qprev=7019&q=7019&maplocality=147.44605%3A-42.88936%3ACLARENDON+VALE%3ATASMANIA )The fact that I 'struck out' when displaying my locality demonstrates both the point of Daniel's inspiration and the need for your concept.I'm not sure my Wordpress experience is yet quite sufficient to prototype something like this (I'm really still at the 'plug & play' stage) but it looks to have some potential. Perhaps someone else in the community could run up a rapid prototype we could discuss along with the toolkit contents.As for branding - this (I believe) is Anne Kjaer Riechert's specialty although perhaps not their design. Her opinion (if she is about) might be useful.

Hi Paul, when I looked at the Mobilemuster page, another homepage came to my mind: "Mundraub" http://www.mundraub.org/?language=enIn this page public fruit trees are listed. The intention is to prevent this fruit from rotting. I like the intuitive handling of the side. In analogy e-waste could be classified (screens, mobile phones, batteries, etc.) since the space required for the collection can vary a lot. You could switch on and off the collection points for the e-waste you want to recycle.

That's a great analogy Sabine and the fruit tree idea is great in itself (makes me think of private fruit waste too - on a pizza delivery recently I saw so much fruit going to waste that could have been shared with the community).Back to e-waste - I think the model is even more appropriate than MobileMuster.I live in a low socio-economic area of my city and while we have recycling bins collected fortnightly the general rubbish bins are collected weekly and many overfull. I think there is enormous potential for collecting many items of e-waste (not just high tech electronics - kettles, clock radios, vhs and audio cassettes). Schools are a natural collection point for many of these little things.  One item per child that the household is throwing away, times 400 or 500 kids, once a month for each of the schools in my area - there are actually 5 within twice the radius of the map you saw - that probably represents a volume worth the recycling firms time to collect from 5 points reasonably close together.Sorry I'm waffling a bit.A kit modified for the kids might prove fruitful.
Loving the fruit-laden discussion, guys!

I like the idea of including schools and universities in the network. Especially for schools the kids would develop an awareness of e-waste early on. Plus the school is a place where they go 5-times a week - so there are plenty of opportunities to integrate the recycling easily in the daily life.That remembers me of my time at school when we had "green teams" in class. There groups of kids went out to collect waste either in nature. Or they picked up recycling waste like paper (old newspapers for example) from elderly people in the community who could not walk to the recycling bin anymore. From time to time they got some tip.

I really like the concept Meena, and I like the builds as well. Great one Sabine with the fruit map! I came across another food-related one recently too, the app-based foodsharing.de by Taste the Waste. Totally think something similar could be useful to integrate into this concept. The location based aspects supports potential community building and leveraging potential synergies, coordination and collaboration. I could also totally see this being a great cross-generational effort. I see, like you said, kids walking with small items to school, tjen perhaps once a week or month a few kids and adults coordinate and take a shopping cart through the neighborhood collecting everyone's e-waste and rolling it down to the school collection point for example. It really opens up for a combo of manual/physical and digital/virtual tools to be utilized - very useful in our day and age I think!Lastly for this comment, I also agree that this could be a very successful spreadable and scalable concept with a simple brand and toolkit that can be open-source expanded, refined and developed. Nice wheels in motion here!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Great concept. I like the aspect, that everyone can be active and set up a local collection point with the toolkit. We can make this the starting point of a really great community. With the right brand it is something for everyone and not only for people which are already part of the eco-movement. I also like, that a broker can be everywhere - your neighbor who sets up a bin in the laundry room but also a teacher, who sets up a bin at school or a shop owner, who has it in his shop.In smaller villages it could be also temporary - for example two times a year, in spring and in autumn.
Grat builds, Sabine. Will add something along those lines to my post.

Many existing 'charity' organisations here have both collection points and collection services for a range of reusable products from clothing to furniture to electrical and electronic goods. These then end up in op-shops and the like. Similarly we now have 'trash to treasure' type shops at our tip faces. With many items they are able to determine how much 'life' is left in a product but electronics pose a particular problem such that they are reluctant to accept all but a small proportion. The development of a kit suitable for everyone would provide these organisations with additional tools but also, more importantly, remove the present 'breaks' in the chain where even these organisations and their clients can see no alternative (but landfill) for some products.

Love the 'community' aspects of this.In the Voting challenge we discussed various support networks for poll workers, volunteers, community workers and organisations.This could be an aspect of the website too, not only to adapt the toolkit but also to share experiences directly.

I like this idea a lot. I used to collect old cell phones at my university and send them off to be recycled. I would receive a few bucks from the process, but it wasn't much incentive. Communication was poor and I had to ship them via UPS. The idea that there would be an online community is great! Being connected to a local e-waste facility makes a lot more sense than a centralized system. And being rewarded with local vouchers provides a great way for local businesses to get involved!One idea for a rewards system in developing country could be cell phone 'minutes'. I once travelled to Ghana and I noticed that there were stands everywhere celling cell phone minutes, even in the more remote northern region. The Champions could be rewarded with free calling time. And if a cell phone stand operator wants to be a Champion themselves, well then now they have more minutes to sell!

Great idea to hear about your experiences and ideas! My main thought here was to keep the money local (eg. cafes) but I can imagine that cellphone minutes could work well as incentives in many low-income communities too  like where I worked a few years back in Dharavi, Mumbai: http://bit.ly/dharavi
Perhaps handlers can also be hired through neighborhood non-profits who work with challenged populations or the homeless
Great concept Meena!I can see this being taken up through schools, neighbourhood groups, municipal councils and linking to broader campaigns from many places.
Loving your thinking about broadening the reach, Paul! Am about to add something along those lines to my post.

I'm looking to add a link for Neighbourhood E-Waste Champions on the labels and the associated website - while the label website will have some information about the labels and the product data behind them it will be aimed differentially at children and grown-ups. For the kids it will be a kind of portal to a range of resources including Neighbourhood E-Waste Champions, some of the educational and kids friendly sites featured in the inspirations etc. Similarly for adults a link to the appropriate part of your website would be included.It seems to me a good idea for some of the emerging concepts to complement one another.Similarly Fabio Calzavara's Recycling Network could be incorporated in the broad awareness/action process.

I really like this idea. You can start small, but it scales easily. It allows advocates to make a difference and help remove barriers for people who are less conscious. Seems like it would be easy to do and could have an immediate impact.

Hi Paul - I was thinking of having the e-tailer providing a second shipping sticker with each shipped product (similar to how Amazon provides a sticker for product returns) to recycle e-waste. This way the vehicles would not wait and not return empty overall  (e.g. I know for my own apartment building there are deliveries from one online retailer or another most days, so while I may pick up and drop off on different days, overall there could be a mix of pick ups and drop offs on most days so the trucks don't return empty).In terms of different product sizes between old and new, I hope it can be solved. It's so easy and for now, there are still plenty of stores to stop by to drop off stuff. Great way to put the right information right in the consumers hand! There's no excuse of "I didn't know where they collect these, I'll just throw it away."Personally however, I'm not a fan of QR codes. To read one I have to whip out the phone, type in my code, find the app, wait for the camera to start up (it always takes longer than I expect) and then snap the photo. That said, this is clearly better than requiring the user to head to Google or Bing, or something like Earth911 if they are aware. I just wonder if RFID (radio frequency id) or NFC (near field communication) could provide a quicker solution without the need for changing product aesthetics. These two technologies are not yet commonplace though. Perhaps down the road...

Thanks Rob and great build!Agreed that there's the potential for other technologies like NFC & RFID, when they become more commonplace.Will refine the idea & add you to my virtual team when I get a chance.
+1 for multiple ways of identifying a device

As usual Vincent - excellent concept!This introduces a step for possibly extending a product's life where some of the other concepts (including mine) focus on final end-of-life processing.I had thought about incorporating an app in my labeling concept but settled for just extending the EPA database with information from the manufacturers.There could easily be a direct link between product code and category from an EPA database and any of the extended options you suggest (reuse, revamp, repurpose, rent, resell, etc.).

Vincent, I think this is a great concept! As others have mentioned, it seems like you could make access to information more universal by making the QR only one of the possible ways to access information. A numerical code, or simply a searchable online database would also be great resources. Overall, I think the ability to provide custom-tailored information to people based on their location is key. I feel like people would be be much more likely to re-sell, or recycle their electronics if they can learn of convenient drop off points near where they live/work. Perhaps it would even be possible to build an app where different resources related to e-waste could be mapped for easy visualization?

True Emily and Fabio's Recycling Network is a proposal in this direction ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/the-recycling-network/  ). As with past challenges there is great potential in the integration of several concepts, drawing on the strengths of each in a synergistic way.

Hi Vincent,I love the idea and I think it will clearly help recycling by providing easy access to users. I like the fact that you could also do it using a scanning device at various locations. From the comments below, the usability and access to QR codes (via smart phones) seems to be an issue. I have to admit that I tried once or twice and never succeeded. Yet if it was easy I will do it as I have a smart phone. But we need to think of people who do not have a smart phone. You suggested other options to have access to a scanning device or using text messaging on a phone. Could we also do this using the text messaging code on a website and receiving an email?This could be options to explore while keeping in mind other technological options (as suggested by Rob).Looking forward to seeing the updated version.

Hi VincentNot having a smartphone I am somewhat ignorant of their operation and this seems a good opportunity to ask a pretty basic question. I assume the scanning app is a standard feature of today's smart phones so these could be scanned with virtually any smartphone. Correct?

Yup, right on Paul. Most smartphones have the hardware (camera) & software (many QR & barcode apps for IPhone, Android, Windows, etc.) to support.Hopefully, as mentioned in the concept, text messaging would also enable RRR's from more basic phones as well.

Thanks Vincent I'm glad about that because given the plethora of developed apps I tend to worry that such important public benefits that deserve widespread promotion might (if dependent on specific apps) get lost in the melee.

This proposal is a great platform for the consumer to take the responsibility into their own hands (literally). Utilizing both a need to know information data base as well as the ability to proactively find out the individuals options is very well thought out. The awareness/ad campaign could be an awesome opportunity to localize the look from city to city. There is also an opportunity to take this beyond just the QR code and into an information campaign that compounds the brand on multiple levels. Great concept!
Great stuff, Vincent! After getting to the pirate bit, I imagined the rest of the post being spoken to me in a pirate accent ;^)
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
This is a wonderful idea! I wonder though, does this even need QR codes? Just having a central database that people could use to figure out what to do with their old electronics could be very useful.

This gives a more defined purpose for the QR code included in my labeling concept, which I admit was somewhat hazy. I think QR coded items could co-exist quite happily with direct access to a central database.Part of my thinking in including a QR code in my concept was that a radio program here asked the question "do apps like Google goggles make QR codes obsolete?" The consensus seemed to be 'yes' because they didn't explore the question beyond location based QR coding.

comments.text: Congrats on making the Refinement phase Top 20 shortlist! We really loved your thoughtfulness around how different stakeholders (users, recyclers, companies, partners) would work together and the great app mockups you created. As you continue to refine in this next phase, perhaps you'll consider how this app can provide increased transparency around the electronics lifecycle  might there be a mapping component, for instance, that helps people track where their e-waste was eventually recycled? Or what if the app could actually tell the history of the device you're using, ie: where it came from, what it's made of, etc? For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/ewaste-top20 and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine(Note: We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Congratulations on making the refinement shortlist Fabio!I made the following comments on Marie's 'Green Deposit' concept that link this concept to hers and possibly to Hacker's Kitchen and Rewire.com"Talking of The Recycling Network I think these two concepts are compatible and complimentary - this one potentially extends product life whereas Fabio's look to reward the recycling process too. There could be a 'final' credit only available on recycling with purchasers/owners eligible for this whenever the product is recycled, but if the product is recycled 'early' then the other credits are lost.One thing that might be necessary is for OEM's to provide a 'transferrable' warranty for the lifetime of the product not just 12 months - this might help to encourage them to design products with 'realistic' lifetimes.I can also see this concept being complimentary to Robert Caruso's Deposit Program too( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/encourage-consumers-to-bring-back-electronics-with-a-deposit-program./ )- they could simply be applied at different price points.Both concepts could be applied across the full range of e-waste including electrical products like hair dryers and fridges.If the database is created (based on product/serial number or similar unique identifier) the Recycling Network could be used to monitor extended use through Hacker's Kitchen and Rewire.com too."This is the link to the quoted comment: ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/hold-on-to-your-device-and-save-the-green-deposit-system-for-newly-purchased-electronics#c-0badce9e7e74f15ed5b7560d45d51de0 )

Great idea and concept!http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JyWJTEy6ov8&feature=plcpReverse vending machines are a new trend in recycling that directly engages people in areas of congregation and rewards them for that engagement. I think it would be great for these reverse vending machines to be customised for e-waste that can be collected conveniently.
Excellent idea Fabio!I especially like the comprehensive map and the award of points that can be spent as social responsibility.
I can see this dovetailing with Meena's Neighbourhood E-Waste Champions as a complementary concept, especially for those places where smartphones are only a small percentage of the market.
Thanks for your comments, Paul! And I agree with your observation, the smartphone platform must be just a part of it, the concept must have a wide range...
Hi Fabio! A person who is not bothered about the environment, how do you propose to make him use this application? What would attract him to use it. Just a curiosity ! :) .
Who are the affiliated Depots? How do they ensure that devices are actually dumped and not scanned for free points?

Probably organisations like those that are currently R2 certified and as suggested through Greg's Track the Bulk Flow concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/track-the-bulk-flow/ )which might incorporate an audit function.
Great insight Paul (and Greg too)!
And I think having an independent organization to audit the process would increase the program credibility
I just think that, instead of being a new network just for this, it could be an app to existing networks (and so be kept alive no matter which social network becomes hot)
Yes it can be, Helena! The network is a concept that takes it further and way more complex...

Agreed - social networking per se is a poor option. If we look at ways to integrate this and many other related concepts a stable platform probably supported by organisations like EPA and its international equivalents springs to mind (also see answer to John's question).
Yes Paul, I guess we can apply the concept in a more developed and accurate way by analyzing different partnerships - not only their role as project or network sponsors.
App-ilicous! And indeed  it connects well with the Neighbourhood E-waste Champions idea (only takes it a lot further ;^)
Yes Meena, I think both concepts take each other further!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

HEY! YOU GOT 6 APPLAUSE ALREADY I MEAN HOW MANY DO YOU WANT...oh wait I have 8. Carry on. :)
Lol - by discussion I meant consolidating these ideas.Have a guess at how much your old Iphone might be worth as 'scrap' (ie. what is it worth as input to the recycling stream?).
Recycling steam as in taking it apart and salvaging the precious metals/rare earths?
Yes - or to put it another way how much profit per phone would a recycling company make - as a ball park figure?
Man...that would have been amazing to know at the beginning of this challenge! :) (Answer: I don't know and I haven't done enough internet searching yet to figure it out.)

Answer - something in the order of 2c to 8c - based on a back of envelope calculation using figures from this concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/golden-e-waste-a-commodity-more-valuable-than-gold-ore/ ). And that leaves no room for a return to the consumer because the recycling profitability is based on donated/discarded items.In my mind makes extending its life in some other way very worthwhile! Wish I had done the figures earlier too.
Hmm. Did anyone put up a concept of just taxing e-waste based on how much is in the device?

Short answer seems to be no - some suggestions for subsidies and incentives. According to the news article from which I got the figures California charges consumers between $6 and $14 for some consumer electronics but it doesn't say which and what the basis of the fee is. It says this is used to subsidize both the collectors (at about 20c per lb) and recycling processors (about 28c per lb). I don't know if the full amount is returned in subsidy but if we extrapolate and say $6 for a cell phone, and just over 40% of that subsidizes collection, it would approximate a basis for $2.50 returnable deposit (  http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/encourage-consumers-to-bring-back-electronics-with-a-deposit-program./ )
I actually pondered creating a tax based on the 3 factors you explored in what I shall call your Penguin idea. But then I didn't. Oh well.
I expect you can include it as a refinement to one of the concepts that make the refinement stage. It might be attractive to EPA and State Department too.

8, eh James? Question: how do I un-applaud something? I'm just kidding. :)Nice discussion here, guys.  I was thinking more about your ideas and the scope of this concept.  What if rewire received used phones to work on?  We could get a "Donate your old smartphone to science" type of campaign going (with a better slogan).  In addition to that idea, maybe all donations (whether they are old phones or money) would be credited as the "financial backing" I refer to.   Rewire can recycle the phones it can't use (and keep the money made) while it keeps the phones the students can use...and any monetary donations go (with the money earned from recycling) into funding the ideas.  Anyway, I'm sort of all over the place, so hopefully this makes sense.  Tell me what you think.

And, Paul, in terms of consolidating ideas during the refinement stage, there's a good amount of similarity between your penguin concept and my calorie menu concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/e-rating-a-lesson-from-fast-food-menus/ ).  There may even be room to include Rob's deposit program concept ( http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/encourage-consumers-to-bring-back-electronics-with-a-deposit-program./ ), but that's slightly more of a stretch.As for James' open-source idea, I think it goes without saying that it can be combined with this Rewire idea.   (Rewire won't work the same without that being a part of it.  People can still come up with new ideas for how to use old electronics, and the process can work that way...but the smartphone recycling would not be happening, which is the one of the areas of most concern.)  Anyway, those are my consolidation thoughts at the moment

Hi Andrew,Have just read this latest post - and I think I am following it but since its 1 am here I will sleep on it and let you know tomorrow (my time).Just before I do though I take it we are still talking about re-purposing the broad range of devices through the "rewire" innovation process.

Re - consolidation I'm heavily into integration of orphan concepts into those that make the refinement phase whatever they may be. I tend to look at the synergies involved that can contribute to either overall solution or at least major aspect solution (e.g, re-usability, or longevity)

The second post is a more general discussion of synthesizing ideas--the first thought is possibly combining my other (Environmental Rating) concept with your Penguin concept (and also possibly with the deposit program concept) [links provided in that post].  Hopefully that clarifies.We'll talk in the morning (er, your morning :) ...It's 9 AM where I am)

Awesome!  Just linked things on my end as well.

The Collaboration Map is a great visual tool to see the links (at least for you lucky people with broadband access - its too slow on my dial-up) but it is limited to the 'fact' (i.e. A is linked to B) and I'm interested in the 'how' (e.g. rewire.com and James' idea are linked because his idea opens software reusability). I sometimes use a tool called CMaps ( http://cmap.ihmc.us/ ) which can be used interactively online. I use it more like the Collaboration Map than using their pedagogy but it focuses on what the links are about and gives me an overview (also allows me to group concepts that achieve similar purposes e.g  in this challenge the labeling/branding concepts). I essence its similar to your flow diagram and mind maps (which are another useful tool in these challenges.I haven't done one for this challenge yet but here is one I did for the Amnesty challenge ( http://cmapspublic3.ihmc.us/rid=1K1S4SRW0-1SJ351Q-W8P/Amnesty.cmap ) - you need the application running on your PC to make it interactive but you can publish them publicly for anyone to see.OpenIDEO might be able to host a CMap server and perhaps help to turn virtual teams into 'real' teams. The server is available free to universities and educational institutions but I'm not sure of the cost implications for OpenIDEO.

I think collaborating with universities is a great idea - this concept is perfect for a student-run group looking to innovate.Maybe I missed it, but if it isn't a university-funded student group, where do you think the funding for rewire.com would come from?

As for the funding rewire would be perpetually funded, meaning whatever rewire gives to the proposed innovation projects is returned once the project finds success. comments.text: I like the dual benefits in this. The obvious side effect of the explosion in cheap electronics is the problem of e-waste, and this will go some way to repurposing that.But the cheapness of electronics has also made us look at them as disposable and as a means of accessing a service rather than a thing: a drive through window instead of a restaurant. So, while in my dads day electronics were an investment and people would learn how they worked, we dont do that anymore. Adding to the example above is the story of William Kwamkwamba. William grew up very poor in rural Malawi with little access to formal education. Nevertheless, he and his best friend would take apart discarded electronics and try to put them back together again, initially for fun but as they taught themselves more as a means of earning some extra money. The lessons he taught himself there  and the appreciation he built for the value of experimentation - were to become the foundation from which he grew his knowledge until he had built a fully functioning wind turbine that charged a car battery and powered lighting in his house; making it the first house in the area to have such a luxury. (http://www.ted.com/speakers/william_kamkwamba.html)  Read: The Boy Who Harnessed the Wind

Great Share there Brendan!! Thanks!! William's story is so moving. He solved a wicked problem using waste. Amazing example of how e-waste can be used  in such a creative and constructive manner. Brendan can you please post William's story as an Inspiration for this challenge?I totally agree with you regarding the point made earlier. You are right about electronics designed as disposable items. Annie Leonard labels it as "designed for dump". The amount of e-waste generated today is mind-boggling due to this very reason and creative re-ruse will not handle it completely. However, as you said, e-waste can be used to solve social problems as demonstrated brilliantly by Willam's example. A large portion of the E-waste generated today is still completely usable. Recycling prevents them from being used constructively as it again re-enters in to cycle of creating products. Creative re-use channels some if it to a valuable cause i.e. solving social problems.
Enjoyed checking these out, Waris!
